The pictures of the Fraulein von Waldenburg, who was a daughter of the Prince August of Prussia, were sold the other day at Berlin, when Horace Vernet's picture, representing "Judith with the Head of Holofernes," fetched only 90. It originally cost 1,200, and a few days before the sale it was valued by experts at $400.
MONTREAL, April 17.--The frauds perpetrated by McLachlan Brothers upon the customs have been the talk of the city for the past week.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., April 18.--Archie Sawyer, aged 10 years, the youngest son of the Hon. W.H. Sawyer, was drowned in Grass River, at Canton, yesterday afternoon. While playing with several other boys he ventured out on the narrow protection of a wall on the river bank, whence he fell into the water. The body was recovered.

Apri1 18.--At 10:30 o'clock last night Dewitt Perry, residing five miles west of the town of Richford, in the northern port of Tioga County, arrived at his home in a drunken condition, mounted the stairs to his brother Richard's room, and pulled his brother twice out of bed. NIAGARA, FALLS, Ontario, April 18.--J.E. Robinson, the Angelica (N.Y.) Bank cashier, is still here. In an interview this evening he said that the report that the bulk of the money was dropped in the Chicago wheat market was false.

LONDON, April 18.--There was an increased demand for discount during the past week at 1 for three months and 1 to 1 for short. The Stock Exchange loan rate to next account is 2 to 2 . Business on the Stock Exchange was dull throughout the week; yesterday, without a notable decline in prices, there was an absolute stagnation in dealings.

Eight little children, forming a Sunday school class at Morris Dock, New-York, have subscribed their savings amounting to $2.35, to the fund for the erection of a monument to Gen. Grant. "A fund," to use the words of their spokesman, "that they all delight to honor." THE TIMES has received the money, and it will be promptly forwarded to the officers having control of the fund.

George Roe, of Newark, N.J., was found dead on the sidewalk on Fifth-avenue, at an early hour yesterday morning. He had been spending the evening with friends, and was on his way home, when attacked with heart disease. He was for 17 years Cashier of the Hackettstown National Bank, and subsequently of the North Ward National Bank of Newark.

The Catholic Church celebrates on Palm Sunday the triumphant entry of the Redeemer into Jerusalem, five days before His crucifixion. Archbishop Corrigan officiated at the ceremony of blessing the palms in St.Patrick's Cathedral, at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

PARIS, March 30.--On Thursday a dispatch from Goritz announced to the Marquis de Dreux Brege, and through the Marquis to the world of "faithful ones," that at 10 A.M. the Countess of Chambord had joined her loved and lamented spouse in another and a better world, all of which was qualified as "the horrible calamity which we so dreaded."

BALTIMORE, April 18.--Louis Praeger, a merchant of this city, and his 12-Year-old daughter were struck by the Memphis express on the Western Maryland Railroad, about 3:30 o'clock this afternoon, while walking over some trestlework about two miles outside the city limits. Mr.Praeger died in a few minutes, and his daughter's legs were badly mangled.

Nearly a thousand Germans who want to have Sunday a quiet day assembled yesterday afternoon in the Lee-Avenue Congregational Church, in Brooklyn. It was not precisely absolute silence wanted on Sunday, but they objected to having saloons and stores open and work going on on that day.

A singular phenomenon occurred at Yankton, Dakota, Friday afternoon. It became suddenly very dark, and for a few moments grew cold rapidly, and a great groaning was heard overhead--a noise like a cyclone, creating dismay. Soon, however, light came from the south, the clouds floated off northwest, and all was quiet. The darkness lasted but a few minutes.

MALDEN, Mass., April 23.--In compliance with the petitions of leading citizens the license for a sparring exhibition here issued to La Blanche, "The Marine," and McCoy has been revoked.

A suit for an accounting of the stock of the American Contracting and Dredging Company, in which Moses A. Slaven and Henry B. Slaven, of this city, are largely interested, has been commenced in the United States Circuit Court.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 23.--The Connecticut Reporters' Association held its annual meeting at the Winthrop Hotel, in Meriden, today.

NEWBURG, N.Y., April 23.--J. Jones, proprietor of the Orange County Stock Farm, near Warwick, which he recently purchased of C.P. Huntington, the Pacific Railway magnate, will hereafter make a specialty of raising heavy draft horses, to be a rival of Backman's celebrated Stony Ford Farm.

LONDON, March 28.--One might write at great length, and with a guarantee of interest in the subject itself, about one phase of life in London which the title of "India in London" suggests, which has never, I believe, got into type, were it not that it is the kind of subject which ought not to get into type.

The purchase of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad by C.P. Huntington is recognized as a direct and powerful blow at the trunk line pool, and predictions are freely made that it will cause the pool's disrupture or a terrific cutting of rates.
The sale of registered Jersey cattle at the American Horse Exchange was concluded yesterday. As on the previous days the attendance was large, but, except in one instance, prices continued poor.
The potato is not in France that homely esculent that it is in the British Islands. There are as many ways of preparing it here as there were in Goldsmith's time of cooking a nettle top.
WASHINGTON, April 23.--Capt. Cyrus S. Roberts, Seventeenth Infantry, has been relieved from duty in the Department of Arizona and ordered to join his company.
TROY, N.Y., April 23.--The Delaware and Hudson day express, due in Troy at 2:25 P. M., met with an accident near the car shops on Green Island to-day.

MORGANFIELD, Ky., April 23.--At 10:30 A. M. to-day Robert Fowler was hanged here, in the presence of 5,000 persons, for the murder, in August last, of Miss Lydia Burnett near this place. Fowler spent a quiet night.

HOLYOKE, Mass., April 23.--The two months' strike at William Skinner Son's silk mill continues. The Executive Board of the District Assembly, Knights of Labor, has sanctioned the request for a boycott, and will notify every assembly in the district.
One hundred members of Cerneau Consistory, No. 1, of thirty-second degree Masons, occupied prominent seats in the amphitheatrical circle at the Brooklyn Tabernacle last evening.
QUEBEC, April 23.--The Regatta Committee has chosen George Hosmer, of Boston, to meet Hanlan for a three-mile scull race on Lake St. Joseph on June 24, for a purse of $1,500.

The blood-red ribbon of the Communist was abroad early of the Williamsburg water front yesterday. With the first streak of dawn the pickets of the striking sugar house men were astir in Kent-avenue patrolling their beats. Soon after daylight they were joined by crowds of the strikers, who gathered in the shadow of the big refineries to discuss the outlook.
ITHACA, N.Y., April 23.--The Cornell baseball nine was selected this afternoon from among 18 competitors, who had been practicing throughout the Winter.

The attorneys in the breach of promise suit of Luoy B. Horine against Nathan E. Harrelson continued to take depositions in the Clerk's office of the United States Circuit Court yesterday, but there were no new developments of any particular interest.

HUNTSVILLE, Texas, April 23.--The examination of W.H. Roe, charged with poisoning his wife on April 7, was concluded yesterday. Roe was remanded to jail without bail to await the action of the Grand Jury.

LANCASTER, Penn., April 23.--Dr. E.E. Higbee, Superintendent of the Soldiers' Orphan Schools, has written an open letter to Gov. Pattison in response to the latter's letter severely criticising the conduct of the schools.
A special service will be held at the Five Points House of Industry to-morrow afternoon at 3:30, for which an elaborate musical programme has been prepared, in which the children will participate.

The Duval system is to be introduced to Londoners early next week, and most of them who have crossed the Channel are familiar with its great advantages in the city of its origin. Duval was a butcher in Paris who conceived the idea of selling good bouillon to workmen at cheap rates.
NEW-ORLEANS, April 23.--The Louisiana State Pharmaceutical Association completed its annual session last night.

News from Munich states that the members of the royal family have taken the resolution to request the King to settle as soon as possible his financial embarrassments in the interests of the Crowd, and to return to his position at the head of the Government.

The committee appointed to devise means for the protection of the first mortgage bondholders of the Shenandoah Valley Railroad Company has suffered a set-back by the unexpected resignation of Mr. E.N. Howell, of this city, who, as Chairman of the committee, is credited with most of the progress that has been made for the benefit of these bondholders in the much-mixed affairs of that corporation.
MONTPELIER, Vt., April 23.--The Republican State Committee met here to-night, with a light attendance.
PITTSBURG, Penn., April 23.--At a meeting of the Connellsville coke syndicate to-day the price of coke was advanced to $1.50 per ton for furnaces, $1.60 for dealers, and $1.75 for foundries.

NEW-HAVEN, April 23.--Two or three strangers, representing themselves as the agents of the New-York street railway companies, are visiting this city and other parts of Connecticut ostensibly bent on employing men to go to work to become horse car drivers and conductors.
The River and Harbor bill that has been the subject of debate for two or three days in the House was made in the old way.
Lord SELBORNE'S criticism of Mr. GLADSTONE'S Irish scheme is one of the most severe and damaging of the attacks which the project has sustained.

LEE, Mass., April 23.--While the funeral observances were being conducted yesterday afternoon over the bodies of five of the victims of the flood at East Lee, the body of Alice White, 12 years old, was found in the debris.
The New-York Hare and Hounds Club will have its annual cross-country paper chase from Hughes's Hotel, Central-avenue, near Woodlawn, this afternoon.

FORT WORTH, Texas, April 23.--Henry Norton, at work for the Fort Worth and NewOrleans Railroad, tried to board a construction train to-day near Mountain Creek, but lost his footing and was pulled under the wheels of the train, a number of cars passing over him before the accident was discovered.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 23.--At Defiance, Ohio, Frederick Hillerman, 30 years old, went out in a boat with his wife and two little children to fish in the Auglaize River. The boat capsized about 30 feet from shore and all the occupants were drowned.
PHILADELPHIA, April 23.--George Daut is dead in the third story room over his brother's saloon, at Fifth and Powell-streets, and his young wife is dying at the Pennsylvania Hospital.

MASSILLON, Ohio, April 23.--George Carting, while working a circular saw yesterday, fell on it. One arm was cut off at the shoulder and his whole left side so completely torn and lacerated that the workings of the heart were plainly visible. He cannot recover.
AUSTIN, Texas, April 23.--The Grand Jury to-day found an indictment against James Phillips, Jr., charging him with having murdered his wife, Eula Phillips, last Christmas Eve, in this city.
Bessie Bell, a colored child, and her aunt, Desdemona Giles, who is only 8 years old, had trouble with little Tommy McCue.
Mr. Hubert Jerningham has published the "Reminiscences of an Attache," in which he recounts various traits of notabilities with whom he has been brought in contact.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 23.--Tthe non-partisan Senate committee, to all intents and purposes, has ceased to exist, and in its stead the committee that investigated the Cincinnati election cases is as intensely partisan as the two political parties that are contesting for the control of the State Senate.

CHICAGO, April 23.--George L. Dunlap filed an answer yesterday to the bill of the Executors of the late Perry H. Smith, who sued to recover $70,000, which they claimed as Mr. Smith's share of the profits of the Indiana Elevator.

A mass meeting of Anarchists under the auspices of the Workingmen's Rifle Club, was held last evening at No. 9 Second-avenue, and Johann Most, the professional king killer, was the principal speaker, and he did his best to arouse all the evil passions and bloodthirsty feelings of his audience.

OSWEGO, N.Y., April 23.--M.S. Burnett, of Lockport, agent of the National Masonic Insurance Company of Buffalo, was brought here to-night under arrest, charged with grand larceny in the second degree.
After a contest marked by heavy batting the Athletics won another game from the Metropolitans at the new St. George grounds on Staten Island yesterday.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 23.--William Nessen, a Dane, over 60 years old, suspecting intimacy between his buxom young wife and his son Joseph by a former wife, at 2 o'clock this morning fires two pistol shots into her body, and placing the pistol in his mouth, blew out his brains.
CHICAGO, April 23.--The Chicago Board of Trade and the open board were closed to-day, it being Good Friday.

PARIS, April 23.--One hears whisper that there are surprises in the Salon, now within only a few days of opening, but then there are always these whispers, and the miracle comes but rarely.
LONDON, April 23.--Lord Selborne, Liberal, in a letter to the Times, attacks certain features of Mr. Gladstone's Home Rule bill.
CORK, April 23.--John Neill has been arrested at Cavan for the murder of Daniel Neill at Clonakilty, County Cork, on April 3.
PARIS, March 25.--The Hotel Rambouillet of the present day, the almost royal residence of Mmes. de Nerville and d'Aubernon, has recently made a great change in its usual programme.

NYACK, N.Y., April 23.--After many weeks of deliberation the members bf the flock of the Rev. Dr. Bristor, the indicted clergyman of Spring Valley, have succeeded in organizing a separate church body, to be known as the First Congregational Society of Spring Valley.
PHILADELPHIA, April 23.--William Bush, a young colored man, murdered his wife, Mary, this morning at her home in a court running back from No. 704 St. Mary-street.
CHICAGO, April 23.--The Trustees of the Chicago University today elected Dr. R.L. Harper to the Presidency of the institution by an unanimous vote.

CHICAGO, April 23.--The Daily News's Springfield (Ill.) special says: "The store of Mr. Watkins, at the town of Bolivar, was burned Wednesday night and the body of the proprietor was discovered in the ruins. PHILADELPHIA, April 23.--Constance S., the famous Holstein heifer of the Record Farm herd, died on April 21 of rupture of the stomach.
CHICAGO, April 23.--The strike of the Lake Shore switchmen came to an end to-day, and both sides are claiming a complete victory.
PENSACOLA, Fla., April 23.--The sham battte to-day was a complete success. The advance was repulsed, the batteries taken, and a complete route followed, brought about by a successful flank movement.

TRENTON, N.J., Apri1 24.--An oil and freight train belonging to the Pennsylvania Railroad Company collided at New-Brunswick on Feb. 7, 1885. Some oil took fire, and a blazing stream ignited Janeway Co.'s wall paper factory, which was burned to the ground.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 24.--At the Driving Park in this city, today, the dog race between Clothesline and Drake Carter, for $500 and the Championship of America, was won by the former in two straight heats. Time, first heat, 0:11 ; second, 0:12 . The distance was 200 yards.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 24.--Dairy Commissioner Tatem will take office next Saturday, and will begin a vigorous onslaught upon the dealers in oleomargarine and the boarding house proprietors who use butterine without complying with the new law. He will be aided by the creamery managers. The fine is $100 for the first offense, double for the second.

BALTIMORE, April 24.--Col. E.W. Dennison, who formerly kept the Tremont House in Washington, was arrested in this city to-day on a charge of having forged notes, said to amount to $8,000. He consented to return to Washington with Detective Brannan, and is understood to have confessed to the crime.

CHICAGO, Ill., April 25.--Mrs. Sterling and her daughter and Miss Whalen, the victims of the oil can explosion in the Sterling House last night, died after several hours of intense suffering.

They want to start in June, when the tea trade begins.
ROME, April 26.--The Chamber of Deputies has been dissolved. The general election for members of the new Chamber will be held on May 23.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 26.--The appointment of O.R. Fyler, of Torrington, to the office of Insurance Commissioner, which was announced to-day, confirms the probabilities of the situation, after Sperry's retirement, as given in THE TIMES.

ERIE, Penn., April 26.--The Odd Fellows of Erie to the number of 2,000 celebrated the sixty-seventh anniversary of Odd Fellowship this evening with banquet and ball. Dr. H. S. Jones and the Hon. Benjamin Whitman were the orators of the evening.

BATAVIA, N.Y., April 26.--Mrs. Anna Waidelich, of Francisco, Jackson County, Mich., arrived here late last night on a train on which she had declined to pay her fare. At this station the conductor turned her over to police officers, who had difficulty in getting her from the coach.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 26.--Late this evening, while Col. Eugene Tisdale, river editor of the Daily Chronicle, was crossing to the levee he was struck by a switch engine of the Morgan Railroad and knocked down.

LONDON, April 26.--At the Newcastle Spring meeting to-day the race for the Gosforth Park Juvenile plate for 2-year-olds was won by C. Perkins's ch. c. Eglamore. J. Barry's br. f. Audit came in second and F. W. Lambton's brown colt by Uncas, out of Wee Lassie, third.

OTTAWA, April 26.--It was stated here today that the American fishing vessel seized at Boddeck, Cape Breton, had been released by order of the authorities, but the news was not confirmed. It is thought that the reports of the seizure are exaggerated, and that the vessel was merely notified to leave the place. The Government is expected to make a statement regarding the matter to-morrow when the House reassembles.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., April 26.--The Miners and Laborers' Amalgamated Association paraded and held a mass meeting to-day. At an early hour this morning a fire broke out in the organ factory of Hilborne L. Roosevelt, at No. 149 West Eighteenth-street. The firemen had the flames under control in a few minutes, but much damage was done to the stock by smoke and water. Mr. Roosevelt's son estimated the loss from $15,000 to $25,000. It is fully covered by insurance.

BOSTON, April 26.--The death of the widow of Wendeil Phillips, who has been for so many years a confirmed invalid--indeed, during almost, her entire married life--is announced. She died in the old home on Common-street, where Mr. Phillips passed away two years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26.--A large audience was present to-night to witness the initial performance of the American Opera season in this city. The audience included many of the fashionable people of the city, who have not been seen in public since the beginning of Lent.

CHICAGO, April 26.--The number of bushels of grain in store in the united States and Canada April 24 and the increase or decrease compared with the previous week will be posted on Change to-morrow as follows: Wheat, 44,554,832; decrease, 1,264,232. NEW-ORLEANS, April 26.--James Parker, a member of the New-York Bar, argued in the United States court to-day in favor of a libel against the British steamship Haverton for running down a pilot boat in New-York Harbor. The case was taken under advisement by the court.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 26.--In the Law and Equity Court this morning Judge Harris brought in an opinion in the case of Cochran Fulton against John M. Atherton, all the parties being big whisky men. The suit was for a settlement of accounts.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 26.--At midnight last night 12 masked moonshiners entered Manchester, Coffee County, and, proceeding to the house of D. W. Purdam, burst in the door. Breaking into his bedroom, the mob fired at Purdam, who, with his wife and children, was asleep.

Five bags of the Oregon's mail, which were washed ashore early last week near Pope's Island Life-saving Station, on the coast of Maryland, were received at the general Post Office in this city Saturday afternoon.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 26.--Capt. Alexander, of the British steamer Renard Hall, arrived to-day, and reports that when he left Port au Prince, on April 6, the people were greatly excited over a pending rovolution. In Yucatan he found the country suffering terribly by the devastation of the locusts.

BUFFALO, N. Y., April 26.--The first big grain fleet of the season from Lake Michigan ports arrived yesterday, and other vessels are stringing along slowly to-day. Up to noon 1,500,000 bushels of grain had been received. The elevators are busy unloading vessels.

WASHINGTON, April 26.--Representative Belmont to-day submitted the report of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs recommending the passage of the bill introduced by himself to reform the consular service.

At the Star Theatre last evening Miss Fanny Davenport and company began a series of farewell performances for the season, the play being "Fedora." The audience was quite large and the interest displayed was most gratifying to the performers.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 26.--A divorce case of unusual interest has been disposed of in the Superior Court, at Tolland. The parties are from Stafford Springs. Mr. Samuel Fairfield, the defendant, is a Stafford lawyer, though now and for the past few years practicing his profession in New-York.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 26.--The big strike of the carriage makers so long expected came about to-day. The union's order affects painters, trimmers, and blacksmiths, and was obeyed by all of them.

ALBANY, April 26.--Speaker Husted made a move in behalf of the Thomas or Gas Consumers' bill to-night, which will insure its being placed on its final passage at an early date, probably to-morrow.
HARTFORD, Conn., April 26.--The principal feature of the secret meeting of the officers of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers at the Allyn House to-day was the address of Chief P. M. Arthur.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 26.--A telephone company is being formed in Louisville which will probably give the present monopoly some lively competition. Dr. F. H. Brown, of NewYork, arrived in the city last night, and is at Alexander's Hotel, his purpose here being to form the new company.

WASHINGTON, April 26, 1886. The President has vetoed the Senate bill "for the promotion of anatomical science and to prevent the desecration of graves." The bill applies to the District of Columbia only.

TRENTON, N.J., April 26.--Levi D. Jarrard, formerly a leading Republican politician of this State, died in the State prison this afternoon. He was the Collector of Middlesex County two years ago, and spent money freely at the Fall election to carry the Board of Freeholders for the Republicans.

BARRYTOWN, N. Y., April 26.--Dennis Bracken and Gilbert Dyckman were flagmen on the Hudson River Railroad. They took turns doing night and day duty, a week on and a week off.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 1.--This town has picked up the reputation lately of having more strikes than any other city of its size in the country. Very likely it deserves it; at any rate the labor problem is in everybody's mouth.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 1.--John A. Lyons, a well known stove dealer of this city, was instantly killed this afternoon by Samuel Marley. In addition to his stove business Mr. Lyons was a manufacturer of tinware, and disposed of a portion of his product by having it handled through the rural districts from wagons, one of which was driven by Marley.

MONTAGUE, Texas, May 1.--For years the southern part of the Indian Nation has been the herding place for cattle stolen in North Texas and driven across Red River. Five hundred outlaws are engaged in this systematized theft of cattle. In the past two years 27 cattle thieves have been caught and lynched in the Red River valley.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 1.--The Right Rev. Charles F. Robertson, D.D., Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Missouri, died this afternoon after an illness of two months. He was stricken with apoplexy when about to board a train at the Union Station on March 2.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., May 1.--The body of a woman, about 60 years of age, was found in the whirlpool at Suspension Bridge to-day, and was identified as that of Mrs. Craner, of Chippewa, Ontario. She was visiting friends at the bridge and is supposed to have fallen into the river.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 1.--A special to the Chronicle from Tombstone, Arizona, says: "The casualties in the late bloody raid by Apaches, as far as is known to date, include 19 killed and several wounded. One girl was taken property was destroyed and a great number of animals were carried off."

NORWALK, Conn., May 1.--The search for the missing Frank H. Cole, of Georgetown, still continues as vigorously as ever. CHICAGO, May 1.--East-bound freight shipments for the week amounted to 17,626 tons, against 16,883 tons last week. This increase of 743 tons is due solely to the moving out of freight which accumulated during the Lake Shore strike, and which was much greater than the increase itself.

ROCHESER, N.Y., May 1.--A telegram received this morning at the Warner Observatery from Prof. Brooks, of Phelps, N.Y., announces the discovery by him early this morning of another comet. He describes it as bright, with a fine tail. It was in the constellation Pegasus, in right ascension 23 hours, declination north 21 . This gives to Prof. Brooks both the first and second Warner comet prizes of the year of $100 each.

Lawrence E. Myers, the pedestrian wonder, who for eight years as an amateur runner delighted the people of the United States, Canada, and England by his superb form and matchless speed, last night opened his career as a professional by handily beating W.G. George, the English crack, in the first of a series of international races.
WASHINGTON, May 1.--The home club won the rubber game of the series with Philadelphia to-day by clean hard hitting and perfect fielding. Shaw pitched a great game and was splendidly supported.

On April 27, 1836, the Rev. Noah Porter was ordained and installed Pastor of the Congregational church at New-Milford, Conn. He continued his labors there seven yearn. Last Tuesday was the fiftieth anniversary of the ordination, and by request of the members of the congregation President Porter will deliver a sermon commemorative of the event in the old church to-morrow morning.

It has been said in the papers that young Seymour went to school to Capt. Partridge, in Connecticut, and that he there acquired that fine, graceful, and easy step and upright carriage that made him in after-life a man of such splendid presence.

The inevitable "opposition ticket" for the annual Stock Exchange election came on yesterday. It does not put up any competitor against Commodore James D. Smith for the Presidency or George W. Ely for Secretary, but confines itself to candidates for the Governing Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 1.--A subcommittee of the House Civil Service Committee to-day called at the residence of E.N. Hill, the witness who testified that he had been employed by the House employes who are charged with improper official conduct to secure the passage of the appropriation for the Jeffersonville levees.
The only eight-hour movement in Newark was by the German Typographical Union and by the carpenters and joiners. They demand an answer by Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1.--The season of American Opera at the Academy of Music closed to-night with "The Marriage of Jeannette" and Dehbes's ballet, "Sylvia." Every seat in the house was sold, and the aisles were crowded to the doors.

PARIS, April 5.--There are no hero worshipers as inveterate or as convinced of their own enthusiasm as the French. They have lionized Liszt to their heart's content, and they are now prepared to do the same thing for Rubinstein, whose first concert comes off to-night at the Salle Erard.

The New-York Dog Show will open in the Madison-Square Garden on Tuesday. As heretofore it will be under the auspices of the Westminster Kennel Club. The indications are that the show will be the best that has yet been held, as the entries already surpass, both in numbers and quality, those of any of its predecessors.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 1.--Something new in the history of the Yale Law School occurred to-day, when Miss Alice Jordan, the first and only lady member of the school, made a plea before the moot court. Miss Jordan acquitted herself with credit, and was loudly applauded by her fellow-students, who filled the court room to overflowing.
NEBRASKA CITY, Neb., May 1.--Lee Shellenberger, a substantial farmer, and his wife were arrested last evening for the murder of the farmer's child, the stepchild of the woman.

CHICAGO, May 1.--A special dispatch published here this morning asserts that chinch bugs have appeared in the wheat fields near Centralia, Ill., in enormous numbers, and growers are fearful that the promising crop of this year will be entirely destroyed.

Mr. C.M. Anderson, of California, who won the long-distance equestrian championship of the world from J.M. De Leon at San Francisco in 1880, was one of the spectators at the Brighton Beach races yesterday. He is matched to ride against John Murphy at Fleetwood Park on May 22.

HARTFORD' Conn., May 1.--The greatlocal event of next week will be the first reunion of all ex-members of the Legislature. It will take place on Wednesday and, from returns received, it is expected that over 2,000 persons who have been members of either the Senate or House will be present. BROCKTON, Mass., May 1.--Since the coming in of the new municipal government action upon the renewal of liquor licenses has been persistently postponed. All licenses expired last night. Mayor Whipple has notified the dealers that the law against selling liquor without a license will be strictly enforced.

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company will to-day inaugurate a new system for the prompt delivery of baggage to be known as the "special delivery system," which will supplement the present mode of handling baggage and is designed to relieve passengers of all care and anxiety regarding their baggage in transit, as well as to secure speedy dispatch and prompt delivery in special cases where it is desired.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 1.--There was an active demand for clearances at the Canal Collector's office to-day. The amount of grain shipped is probably the largest for the opening day ever known. Clearances were issued tor 127 boats, with cargoes aggregating 734,840 bushels of wheat, 65,700 bushels of corn, and 45,045 bushals of barley malt. Of the wheat, 12,000 bushels were for Lockport, and the remainder was for tidewater.

CHICAGO, May 1.--The efforts of the Commercial Club of this city to have the proposed United States School of Artillery situated at Chicago have reached a point where the success of the undertaking is practically assured.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 1.--D.W.C. Carroll, Receiver of the Newcastle Northern Railroad, filed a petition in the United States Circuit Court to-day, asking for leave to soil the Newcastle Northern Railroad. He alleges that the road is insolvent, and is daily depreciating in value. The creditors have all agreed that this is the best method to recover their money.
PHILADELPHIA, May 1.--One hundred and eighteen young medical doctors and 41 dentists were graduated to-day at the annual Commencement of the Department of Medicine of the University of Pennsylvania.
The remainas of Patrick H. Lalor, a well known builder, of Harlem, who had been missing since Feb. 2, were found last evening in the East River, at the foot Ninety-fourth-street.

The doors of the excise offices are still closed against the three new Commissioners appointed by Mayor Grace. Regardless of the Board of Aldermen the Mayor yesterday appointed Charles H. Woodman, John Von Glahn. and William S. Andrews to succeed Commissioners Haughton, Mitchell, and Morris, whose terms of office expired at midnight.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., May 1.--Grover Cleveland took out a marriage license here today. Grover is a Polander by birth, is 35 years of age, and bears some personal resemblance to the President. It is to the latter fact that he owes his name, his original cognomen being too unpronounceable for the people at the mines at which he works. He lives in Shenandoab.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 1.--The ruin of the "Up-town News Agency," the disappearance of whose proprietors was told in to-day's TIMES, was completed this morning when Constable Higgins attached the agency's shop in the interests of creditors. The Curtises, who ran the concern have not yet been found, and the number of their customers is said to run high up into the hundreds.

WATERBURY, Conn., May 1.--While the first Eastern League game of the season was being played here to-day, Waterbury against Meriden, every prominence surrounding the grounds was covered with people. The best deadhead position was a large shed, just outside the fence, back of third base.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 1.--Dr. William A. Hammond, of New-York, formerly SurgeonGeneral of the United States Army, was married at 12 o'clock to-day to Miss Esther Dyer Chapin, at the residence of Mrs. Frances J. Vinton, grandmother of the bride.

MONTREAL, May 1.--The Recorder gave judgment this afternoon in the case of Rice, Sharpley Co., jewelers, Notre Dame-street, charged with exposing in their windows two statues, copies of Michael Angelo's "Night and Morning," the original of which is to be found in the chapel of the Medici.

The will of the late ex-Senator Dennis McCarthy, of Syracuse, disposes of an estate worth $275,000. It as dated Aug. 15, 1885, and witnessed by Representative Frank Hiscock and Frank A. Hiscock. James J. Beldon is one of the Executors.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1.--Charles P. Tasker, a fugitive from justice apprehended recently in El Paso, Texas, was to-day brought into court and committed to the county prison for trial. There are two indictments against him, charging him with indorsing the name of his uncle, Stephen P.M. Tasker, to promissory notes for $5,000 each and uttering and publishing the same.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 1.--The Railroad Commissioners, who will on Tuesday next begin their annual Spring examinations of railroads, are investigating 57 accidents to persons on railways not reported to them last year by the companies, but mentioned in the newspapers.

The racing season at Brighton Beach began yesterday, and between 2,000 and 3,000 people ventured to the seaside to enjoy the sport, though a chilling easterly wind made Winter overcoats a necessity. The racing was notably close and exciting, and but one favorite succeeded in reaching the winning post first.

CHICAGO, May 1.--The heirs of Stephen A. Douglas have commenced another suit in the Superior Court against the Union Mutual Life Insurance Company to have the sale of the Chicago University property set aside.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 1.--Rector P.H. Whaley, of St. Thomas's Church, will not need to say harsh words to his congregation to-morrow. Last Sunday he told them pointedly, just before his sermon, that he understood that there was a paper in circulation inviting him to resign. "You can't put me out," he said: "I hold the keys, and I will preach here if I have to preach to bare walls."

BOSTON, Mass., May 2.--Gen. Paine's yacht Mayflower, the rival of the Puritan, is completed. She will be launched on Wednesday or Thursday.

LONDON, May 2.--Discount closed at 2 for three months and 1 for short. There is an increased prospect of an advance in the Bank of England's rate. Further withdrawals will compel the bank to take action in order to retain its store of gold. The American gold import goes mostly to France.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 2.--Hugh Connor, aged 50 years, engineer on the steamer Wilkesbarre, plying between here and Nanticoke, on the Susquehanna River, was found dead at his post this afternoon. At the time he died he was in the act of putting coal on the fire in the furnace of the boiler. Heart disease is said to have been the cause of his death.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 2.--What might have been a murder and a suicide in East Toledo, tonight, resulted only in the latter. On Saturday night the watchman at the Maumee Rolling Mills, named George Pibel, was discharged, and Paul Loman put in his place. About 7 o'clock this evening Pibel entered the mill and shot several times at Loman, but without effect, Pibel then turned the weapon toward his own heart and shot himself dead.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 2.--Our people have the laugh on Gen. Hazen. A few weeks ago Col. James B. Miles, of Helena, Ark., who has made a careful application of statistics of temperature, humidity, and hydromatic velocity, as compared with levee work and crop sections, predicted a rise in the river at his point, for which most people were unprepared, and his prediction has in the main come true.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 4.--A 2-year old daughter of August Kutscher, of No. 259 Franklin-street, met with a peculiar accident tonight. She was walking along the floor with a slate pencil in her mouth when she slipped and fell. The pencil penetrated a blood vessel in the back of the head and the child died in 10 minutes.

COLUMBUS, May 4.--A large number of politicians are in the city to-night, drawn together to witness the struggle in the Senate to-morrow morning, when the effort will be made to oust the four Democratic members now holding seats from Hamilton County.

CHICAGO, May 4.--A conference was held at the Lumbermen's Exchange to-day between the Lumbermen's Committee and a delegation of the striking employes. The special business of the delegation was to get the reply of the lumbermen to the circular of Friday. John Schmidt, a member of the delegation, said to a reporter as he came from the meeting: "They want to starve us.

One of the curiosities of journalism in this city is the aggressive stand which has been taken by a clique of newspapers against one of their most influential contemporaries, THE NEWYORK TIMES. This clique comprises the Tribune, the Sun, and the Mail and Express, with the Post and the World as occasional adherents. On Wednesday, most of the journals pointed out that THE TIMES had received $1,200 for printing ...

The Sunday Tribune of New-York, which is printed Saturday for New-England circulation, had a special yesterday describing Col. Trull's funeral, the story of which is calmly and circumstantially told as if it had taken place on Saturday! This special was written--the technical term for it is "faked"--at least 24 hours before the procession started. The inadequate accommodations at the church were complained of in advance, and other great and prophetic thoughts are noted.

Three little children at South Hope on Wednesday obtained some pills, the medicine of the Rev. M.M. Stevenson, and, playing they were sick, swallowed several. One of the girls, aged 6, the daughter of P.P. Rokes, died three hours later in terrible agony. The others are very sick, but will recover. The pills are supposed to have contained strychnine.

The bill before the Legislature for the widening and extension of Elm-street was considered yesterday by the Board of Street Openings. H.C. Stetson, in behalf of interested property owners, favored the scheme.

Stephen Foley, a laborer, complained at the Tombs yesterday that his son Cornelius was incorrigible. Justice Patterson issued a warrant for the young man's arrest, and an officer went an hour later to the fifth floor of No. 66 New Chambers-street to serve it.

Henry Fortmand, 16 years old, a clerk employed in a grocery store at No. 128 Tenthavenue, was shot in the right side of the head last evening by Adolph Schwandman, a fellowclerk, while the latter was practicing at shooting with a revolver at a canned tomato box in the rear of the store. Fortmand was taken to the New-York Hospital, and was found to be seriously wounded. Schwandman was arrested.
WASHINGTON, May 4.--Brig.-Gen. Gabriel R. Paul (retired) was stricken with paralysis yesterday, and is now in a dying condition.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4.--The American Iron and Steel Association has compiled for the information of members its annual statistical report and review of the iron trade for 1885 and the first four months of 1886. The Spring trade of 1885 was light, and there was a widespread feeling that it was inexpedient to purchase any material in advance of actual requirements.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 5.--A Portland special says: "Late advices from Victoria, British Columbia, state that the damage done the Canadian Pacific Railway in the mountain region was much more extensive last Winter than reported. Several miles of track were carried away, some bridges destroyed, and the damage cannot be repaired before August."
The Third-avenue strike of 20 days was settled last night in a complete victory for the company.
The quaint three-story frame house at No. 175 Floyd-street, Williamsburg, was the scene of a double tragedy--a murder and a suicide--yesterday afternoon.
The sale of Senator Stanford's trotting stock was continued yesterday at the American Institute Building in the presence of a large number of representative breeders and horsemen.

BOSTON, May 5.--The Rev. Francis G. Peabody was elected by the Overseers of Harvard College, at a meeting to-day, Plummer Professor of Theology, the chair which has been unfilled. Mr. Peabody was formerly Pastor of the First Unitarian Church at Cambridge, but of late has been a lecturer in the Harvard Divinity School. He is a graduate of Harvard of the Class of '69.

FRANKFORT, Ky., May 5.--While discussing the question of a House bill granting certain privileges to a natural gas company before a Senate committee last night, Mayor Lewis E. Harvie insinuated strongly that a certain gas charter of the city had mysteriously disap peared.
CHICAGO, May 5.--The dead are: Policemen M.J. Deegan and Nicholas Shannon, both of the West Lake-street station; Citizen Charles Keisler, No. 167 West Indiana-street, shot through the heart.

LONDON, May 5.--This was the second day of the Chester meeting. The race for the Chester Cup was won by the Duke of Beaufort's 5-year-old gr. b. Eastern Emperor, with Mr. Leopold de Rothschild's 3-year-old b.c. Beaver second, and Lord Bradford's 3-year-old ch. c. Sir Hamo third. There were nine starters.

FORT WORTH, Texas, May 5.--Litigation over the Daggett 320-acre tract increases. Yesterday a new set of heirs, claiming under the John Childress certificate, filed suit for possession of the entire tract. The suit is against W.J. Boaz and 400 owners of lots in the tract. Gardner Ruggles, of Austin, brings this suit.

The Senate in Executive session to-day closed as calendar of nominations. The only confirmation made public is that of Z.M. Zulick to be Governor of Arizona. The nomination of R.S. Dement to be Surveyor-General of Utah, adversely reported from the Public Lands Committee, was recommitted. The relection of Charles R. Pollard to be Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of Montana is officially announced.

There were very few people on the grounds of the New-York Athletic Club yesterday when W.G. George, the English champion, did a trial three-quarters of a mile, the distance he is to run L.E. Myers in Madison-Square Garden next Saturday evening. F.J. Kilpatrick, his backer, held the watch.

The boycotters arrested yesterday for trying to starve out Mrs. LANDGRAF turn out to be such recent importations into this country that they are unable even to speak the language, much less to understand American institutions.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 5.--In the District Court of Washington County this morning Judge McClure filed his decision on points raised in the contest over the claims for $500,000 special preferred stock made by Seymour, Sabin Co. against the Northwestern Car Company, of Stillwater.

Mrs. Anna Loughlin, aged 23, whose face was recently horribly disfigured by vitriol, was tried yesterday in the Court of General Sessions, before Judge Cowing, upon an indictment charging her with assault in the second degree.

The watch which was stolen from Gilbert Dykman, the flagman, who was murdered in a shanty two miles north of Rhinebeck on April 25, was found on Tuesday in the pawnshop of August Behren, at No. 96 Atlantic-avenue, Brooklyn. The watch is a silver one, of Waltham make.

CHICAGO, May 5.--Before business men had reached their offices this morning August Spies, the editor-in-chief of the Arbiter Zeitung; Michael Schwab, the associate editor, and Christian Spies, August's brother, and a workman in the office were locked up in three cells in the basement of the City Hall, and the news of the arrest was flying like a November gale through the city.

CHICAGO, May 5.--Mob violence again asserted itself in the southwestern par of the city this morning. About 9 o'clock groups of men, women, and children began to gather at the corner of Eighteenth-street and Centre-avenue, and these groups soon aggregated 3,000 persons. On one of the corners is the drug store of Samuel Rosenfeld.

St. Phoebe's Mission Home, a handsome stone and terra cotta building erected on De Kalb-avenue, opposite St. Felix-street, Brooklyn, by Mr. A.A. Low in memory of his daughter, Miss Harriet Gilman Low, was dedicated yesterday afternoon. The structure cost $50,000.

The strike of the Marvin Safe Company's employes was ended yesterday by a compromise. The firm has consented to a reduction of the hours of labor to nine hours on five days of the week and eight on Saturday.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 5.--David Lott died at Port Jervis yesterday of pneumonia at the age of nearly 87 years. Mr. Lott was born at Franklin Furnace, N.J., and was a water boy in the war of 1812 with Great Britain.
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 5.--A conference of citizens interested in the movement toward perpetuating the memory of the late Gen. George B. McClellan by erecting a monument was held here to-day.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 5.--James B. McConnell, who has been for nearly 20 years confidential clerk and cashier for the shippers' cotton press of Samuel Boyd and Richard Herrick, was arrested this morning on an affidavit sworn out by the former gentleman for embezzlement.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 5.--Superintendent Dobbins, of the Life-saving Service, reports that high water all along Lake Ontario is becoming a serious matter. The body of an unknown drowned man, about 40 years of age, was found floating in the water at new Pier No. 44 North River, early yesterday morning. The man was about 5 feet 7 inches in height, with brown hair, and wore a dark suit, a cardigan jacket, a white shirt and collar, with a silk tie. The body was taken to the Morgue.
The body of Charles Walters, an artist, of this city, was incinerated at the Mount Olivet Crematory, Long Island, yesterday without ceremonies. The ashes were sent to his friends.

Francis B. Lane, a young clerk employed at the wholesale liquor store of A. Coxe Co., No. 82 Front-street, did not go to his work from April 27 till yesterday. On arriving at the office he walked into the arms of Post Office Inspector Riley, who wanted him on a charge of having stolen a check for $26,854.09 from a letter sent through the mails.
Mr. William Ordway Partridge will read scenes from Shakespeare's "Julius Caesar" at Chickering Hall this afternoon. Miss Maud Morgan will vary the programme by her performances on the harp.

PARIS, May 6.--M. Granat, Minister of Posts and Telegraphs, has granted a charter to a French company to lay a new cable between Brest and New-York, via Guadeloupe. The State guarantees a portion of the capital on condition that the cable be manufactured in France and be laid by French vessels. The charter requires the sanction of the French Parliament.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 5.--During the past week wheat receipts at Minneapolis have been exceptionally large, coming in at the rate of from 125 to 150 cars a day, and as yet there is no sign of a let up.

Fifteen charming young ladies, wearing pale-blue gingham dresses and pretty white caps, were graduated last evening from the Mount Sinai Training School for Nurses, at Nos. 850 and 852 Lexington-avenue.

CHICAGO, May 5.--Mayor Harrison was early at his office to-day, and among his first visitors were a number of old citizens who happened to meet on their way to business and decided to visit the Mayor and offer him their services in any direction they might be needed.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 5.--Counsel for the Journal and Courier to-day filed a substitute complaint in the injunction proceedings against the boycotters setting forth the claim that an injunction is the only process by which the paper can be saved from further injury to its business. Arguments on granting the injunction will probably be made in a few days.

HAMBURG, Penn., May 5.--An extensive mountain fire is prevailing between this place and Port Clinton. A sheet of flames extends along the top of the Blue Mountains for several miles, and the sky is obscured by the dense smoke. Serious damage to timber is reported.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 5.--The ranks of the strikers have been recruited to-day by men from the smaller factories, and it is now estimated that 20,000 are out. About 500 striking freight handlers from other roads marched in an orderly body to the Little Miami yard a little before noon.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 5.--One of the most horrible murders ever perpetrated in Cuyahoga County occurred in this city to-day. The victim, Lizzie Wolfe, was a beautiful German girl 18 years of age, living with her mother and stepfather, George Kades, at No. 334 Gardenstreet.

CHICAGO, May 5.--The collision between the police and the Anarchists last night was brought about by the leaders of the latter, August Spies, Sam Fielden, and A.R. Parsons, endeavoring to incite a large mass meeting to riot and bloodshed.

Frank H. Clements, an actor playing with the Modjeska Company, disappeared from Newark last Saturday evening, and up to late last evening had not been heard from by the manager of the company or any of his friends.

A tall young man, Paul W. Fabricius, who was once employed as a salesman in Baldwin Co.'s trunk manufactory, in Newark, was tried before Recorder Smyth, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, upon an indictment charging him with an attempt at suicide. On April 21, in Madison-square, he shot himself twice, using a seven shooter.

Miss Laura A. Weber, daughter of John Weber, was married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Church, by the Rev. S. Tuttle Smith, of the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, to Oscar Balthasar Weber. Arthur F. Wendt was the best man. There were no bridesmaids.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 5.--Shortly after 2 o'clock this afternoon one of the walls of the Brackett Block, in Minneapolis, a five-story building, to which an addition was being made, fell out, and crashed into the basement which had been excavated for the new portion, burying a dozen workmen beneath the ruins.

Almost a riot took place at Mrs. Landgraf's bakery at No. 157 Second-street last evening. Shortly after 7 o'clock, when the day's work was about ended, four infuriated Bohemian women burst into the shop.

The Board of Aldermen yesterday, by a vote of 13 to 10, declined to accede to the request of Mayor Grace to be allowed to withdraw the nominations of Excise Commissioners Woodman, Andrews, and Von Glahn, who have since their names were sent in been appointed outright by the Mayor.
ERIE, Penn., May 5.--The trouble at Edinborough between the two factions of stockholders of the State Normal School continues unabated.
The New-Yorks will play here to-day. All the games in this vicinity were stopped by rain yesterday.

A. Frank Smith, a shipping clerk in H. L. Judd's brass foundry, at Front and Adams streets, Brooklyn, left his desk yesterday morning, went up to the second floor, and there cut his throat with a penknife.

Shortly after 7 o'clock last evening George Cortissos, aged 31 years, a clerk in the Post Office, was taken to the Chambers-Street Hospital suffering from the effects of a blow. During the day he had quarreled with James Halpin, the head porter in the Post Office, about a matter relating to the Mutual Aid Organization, to which both belong.

The decoration of Gen. Grant's tomb, in Riverside Park, on Memorial Day will be an international as well as a national affair. Spain, England, and Mexico will be represented by offerings to Gen. Grant's memory.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 5.--Preparations are already on foot to make the coming Commencement at Cornell the most brilliant in her history.

Resolutions condemning the action of the Chicago Anarchists were offered by a delegate at a special meeting of the Central Labor Union last evening, but they met with no sympathizers and were promptly laid on the table. The sentiment of the meeting was in favor of condemning the police, and a committee was instructed to present resolutions of that nature at the next meeting.

LONDON, May 5.--The news from Burmah to-day is very sensational and shows that the natives, with the assistance of the Dacoits, have, temporarily at least, got the better of the British army of occupation. One dispatch states that the insurgents have got possession of Mandalay and have destroyed by fire no less than 4,000 houses.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 5.--An interesting case was concluded yesterday in the United States Circuit Court before Judge Billings. Ben Wasserman, a ticket broker doing business in this city last Winter, coming here from St. Louis, sold the return portion of a ticket to Cincinnati over the Louisville and Nashville Railroad.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 5.--A suit involving the control of the Roman Catholic cemeteries on Metarie Ridge was decided to-day by Judge Rightor, in the Civil Court. It has involved a grant deal of scandal and on one or two occasions almost a resort to violence.

At James G. Johnson's well known establishment, No. 8 East Fourteenth-street, special attention has been given this season to the millinery department. A large room has been handsomely fitted up where at present is displayed some of the richest specimens of what the Parisian milliner is capable of originating in bonnets and hats.

NORWALK, Conn., May 5.--The marriage of Mr. Edward H. Matthewson, of the firm of Lounsbury, Matthewson Co., shoe manufacturers, at South Norwalk, and Miss Gracie Crofut, only daughter of Mr. A.J. Crofut, of the firm of Crofut Knapp, hat manufacturers, took place at the residence of the bride's parents at 12:30 o'clock to-day.

ALBANY, May 5.--The Senate Railroad Committee submitted to-day its final report upon the Broadway Railroad investigation. Chairman Low, after it had been read, said the District Attorney of New-York City had sent him this communication asking to have the committee's time still further extended:

CHICAGO, May 5.--Another great strike was begun this morning. The 1,700 men employed in the Deering Harvester Works stopped work without notice or warning of any character and without having made any demands.
ALBANY, N.Y., May 5.--The favorable showing made in the last quarter of 1885 by the leased lines of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company is continued in the first quarter of 1886.

WASHINGTON, May 5.--The Spring meeting of the National Jockey Club will begin at Ivy City to-morrow and continue on Saturday, Monday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday. The first race will start at 3 P.M. and five races will be run each day.
The New-York State Commandery of the Military Order of the Loyal Legion held its annual meeting last night at Delmonico's. The officers chosen for the ensuing year were:

George W. Cann, a private in the Thirteenth Regiment, obtained an order from Justice Dykman yesterday ordering Capt. W.L. Warson, of Company G, to show cause why he should not be compelled to give a certificate of discharge to Mr. Cann. The order is returnable on Saturday.

Mr. Edwin W. Martin delivered a lecture fast night in the lecture room of the School of Mines at Columbia College on "Adulteration of Food." The lecture dealt with only the commonest frauds practiced with ordinary articles of consumption.
The schooner yacht Nokomis, which arrived yesterday from Norfolk, was run into off Clifton by the schooner H.H. Pitts.
PECOS, Texas, May 5.--E.J. Simpson, manager of the Aztec Cattle Company, came in to-day from up the river, and gives a gloomy report about the herds that started on the trail via Pecos River.
NEWBURG, N.Y., May 5.--The Newburg Board of Aldermen last night agreed with the bondsmen of the West Shore Railroad Company ...

Frank A. Hayford, the young mate of the American bark C.C. Sweeny, on his arrival here on the steamer Colorado late Tuesday night, was handed over to United States Deputy Marshal Jeffreys and taken to Ludlow-Street Jail. Hayford is charged with shooting Frederick Grunfass, one of the seamen of the bark, while the vessel was lying at Havana waiting for her cargo. The mate expects to prove a case of self-defense.

On an examination of the machinery of the Vandalia two crank pins were found to be defective. This will necessitate some repairs to the main shaft. Commodore Chandler is of the opinion that the vessel will be detained here for some time.

A special meeting of the Chicago and Atlantic Railroad Company was held yesterday to act on the unexpected resignation of H.J. Jewett as Presieent. James H. Benedict, who is the representative of Amsterdam bondholders, was chosen as Mr. Jewett's successor, and Thomas B. Musgrave was made Vice-President.

WASHINGTON, May 5.--Mr. George Jones, of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, was the first witness called before the telephone investigating committee to-day. He said he was related to THE TIMES as an owner and had a small voice in its editorial management.
There is trouble in the County Democracy organization of the Fourteenth Assembly District.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 5.--A fair estimate places the number of members and exmembers attending the legislative reunion in this city to-day at about 2,000. These, with their families and friends, made an assemblage of not less than 5,000 visitors.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., May 5.--The friends of ex-Vice-President David Davis are greatly alarmed over the present condition of his health. About a weak ago Mr. Davis noticed a soreness on his left shoulder, which at first had the appearance only of a small pimple, and he gave it little thought.

CHICAGO, May 5.--No specific charge was made against the four anarchists when arrested to-day, but when Coroner Hertz impaneled a jury, of which J.J. Bodenoch, a flour and feed merchant, was Chairman, to determine the cause of Officer Deegan's death, it was decided to bring them in custody before that body.

Three of the men indicted for conspiracy and coercion in annoying George Theiss, of the Alhambra saloon, in Fourteenth-street, surrendered themselves at the District Attorney's office yesterday, and bail in each case was fixed at $500. Two of them procured bail.

A silver tobacco box which John Alden carried in his pocket when, in the storied courtship of Miles Standish, he presented to Priscilla Mullins the Captain's proposal of marriage, is now the property of Mrs. M. McFadden, of Allegheny City, widow of the late John B. McFadden. Mrs. McFadden is a lineal descendant of John Alden, belonging to the ninth generation in the regular descent.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 6.--In nearly every cell at the Central Police Station to-night there is a socialist or rioter. The prisoners number 20 in all. The pretension of the Chicago Anarchists to speak in the name of the laboring men of that city has been promptly rebuked by the trades unions there, and there is no doubt that if the chiefs of the murderous gang were left to the disposal of real workmen they would give them short shrift.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 6.--The brief season of American opera, four performances, began to-night with "Orpheus and Eurydice," at the Academy of Music. The opera, which was given for the first time here, was much admired, and the elaborate representation given by the American Opera Company was certainly a great surprise to the fashionable audience present, although they had been led to expect great things from the company.

Mr. Blake, the leader of the Opposition in the House of Commons to-day moved his resolution approving Mr. Giadstone's home rule measure for Ireland, and was followed by the Hon. The Brooklyns won from the Baltimores yesterday at Washington Park in the presence of 3,500 spectators. The contest was a heavy patting one, and the lovers of old-time games enjoyed it immensely. In all 40 base hits were made and the circuit of the bases was made 23 times.

Count Andor Szechenyi, Jr., was arrested in Vienna last night under the following dramatic circumstances: A couple of years ago the Count, who is a young man of 22, married the daughter of a Russian landed proprietor, the lady receiving a handsome dowry from her father.

Fursch-Madi sang in her own majestic style Weber's "Ocean, thou mighty monster" and the grand aria of Fides in "The Prophet." Mme. Roberti was heard in the florid mad scene of Ambroise...

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6.--The Harvard nine was defeated this afternoon for the first time by a college nine since 1884. The victors were the Columbia College nine, who easily defeated Harvard by the score of 5 to 0. Nichols and Allen, the regular Harvard battery, played for the first time this season.

The Exeter (N.H.) Gazette claims that men of New-Hampshire struck the first blow in the American Revolution, and declares that there are men now living in Durham, that State, who received the full account from some of the actors. "The deed was performed," the Gazette says, "by 14 men of Durham and Madbury,...

The annual meeting of the Civil Service Reform Association, at No. 21 West Twentyfourth-street, called together a goodly number of gentlemen who are interested in that cause last evening. BOSTON, May 6.--At least 2,000 people gathered in and about the Lawley's ship yard at City Point, South Boston, to-day, to witness the launch of the Mayflower, Gen. Charles J.Paine's new sloop, from this spot, where her famous mate, the Puritan, took the water a year ago. It was a crowd composed of all grades of society.
In the Hudson County Circuit Court yesterday John Cannon received a judgment of $4,000 against the North Hudson County Railroad Company for damages sustained on one of the company's horse cars.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 6.--The back of the strike has been broken. It is due in part to the remarkable energy on the part of Mayor Smith and in part to the half hearted disposition of the strikers. While there are more men out to-day than there were yesterday, it is evident they will not long remain out and that violeonce is improbable.

A conference as to the proposed introduction of technical and industrial education into the public schools of the city was held last evening between the special committee of the Board of Education and a number of ladies and gentlemen interested in the plan.

At a meeting of the Chamber of Commerce held yesterday, Mr. Augustine Smithcalled attention to the onerous and vexatious system of so-called rag disinfaction imposed on a large class of importers by the Health Officer of the Port. Mr. Smith said:

The bill to take Lloyd's Neck from the town of Oyster Bay, Queen's County, and make it a part of the town of Huntington. Suffolk County, has passed both branches of the Legislature and is now in the hands of the Governor.
Liberty of speech is the right of every man in this country, but liberty of murder is the right of none.

In response to an invitation for "an interchange of views on the subject of our Municipal Government," accompanied by the declaration that "it seems most desirable that some systematic movement should be inaugurated whereby the evils existing in the administration of our Municipal Government may be remedied," about 100 well known men assembled last night at...

NEW-ORLEANS, May 6.--The Cromwell Line steamship Louisiana, Commander E.V. Gagor, from New-York, arrived in port this afternoon. She has completed the quickest trip ever made between New-York and this port. She sailed from New-York at 4:35 P.M. on the 1st inst., passed Sandy Hook at 5:30 P.M., experienced strong easterly breezes to Cape Hattoras, and thence had good steaming weather.

Coroner Menninger, of Brooklyn, was called on last night to inquire into the death of John H. Bristol, which occurred at his home, No. 235 Union-street, on Wednesday night. Mr. Bristol was 48 years old, and was a grain inspector in the New-York Produce Exchange.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., May 6.--The Morse arson case, the biggest case this town ever saw, took a new turn to-day when Officer Roger S. Austin brought Frank H. Morse here from Trenton, N.J. Morse has been out on bonds for several weeks, his first case having gone over to the October term of the Superior Court.
NEW-ORLEANS, May 6.--Particulars have been received of a murder which occurred yesterday in the Court House at De Kalb, Kemper County, Miss., when George Huff was slain by Knox Stennis.

Railroad earnings were reported as follows in Wall-street yesterday: Louisville and Nashville, for the fourth week of April, $326,085, a decrease of $16,320 from its corresponding period of last year.

During the past few days, while excavations were being made at Peterborough Cathedral with a view of testing the foundations of the south transept, four massive stone coffins were discovered about five or six feet below the surface.

The largest German gun has just been mounted on the fortifications at Wilhelmshaven. Its weight is 70 tons, length 33 feet, diameter of bore 14 inches, weight of charge nearly 3 hundredweight, weight of shell over 7 hundredweight. It is the largest gun ever turned out by Krupn.

LONDON, May 6.--Lord Hartington has consented to introduce in the House of Commons a motion to reject Mr. Gladstone's Home Rule bill on its second reading. The Conservatives calculate that 87 Liberals are pledged to support Lord Hartington.

CHICAGO, May 6.--The strike at the Deerng Harvester Works is ended. The men were satisfied yesterday to accept ten hours' pay for nine hours' work, but were prevented from returning to work by outside strikers. To-day Mr. Deering promised to give them an advance of 15 per cent, and to consider eight hours a day's work.

The old Board or Directors of the New-York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad was re-elected yesterday without change, except that James M. Hartshorne was chosen as successor of Charles F. Bound, who declined reelection. Frederick A. Potts was made President and S.V. White was elected Vice-President...

The steamer Powhatan, which has been in commission for nearly 16 years, is to be put out of commission upon her arrival at the yard. It was at first thought that she might be repaired sufficiently to warrant her remaining in active service, but, because of general unseaworthiness, she will be permanently consigned to rotten row.

WASHINGTON, May 6.--The House of Representatives has done what it can to make the River and Harbor bill, which takes over $15,000,000 out of the Treasury, a law. Mr. Holman tried hard to-day to have the bill sent beck to the committee with instructions to cut down its items until their aggregate should not exceed $8,000,000.

The attendance at the dog show in Madison-Square Garden yesterday was good, though the place was at no time uncomfortably crowded. The excellence at the exhibition was generally spoken of, and it is expected that to-day, which is the last of the display, will see a large and interested crowd of people looking at the dogs.

Capt. Anderson, of the British bark Siddartha, which arrived yesterday, reported a peculiar thunderstorm on April 27, while on the northern edge of the Gulf Stream. The sky was quite clear at the time and the sun shining brightly, although there appeared to be a thin mist about the ship. Suddenly there appeared a vivid flash of lightning, accompanied by violent thunder. The compass was caused to vibrate perceptibly for a period of 15 minutes.

WATERBURY, Conn., May 6.--The May term of the Superior Court opened here to-day, and counsel for Henry Bergh, of New-York, defendant in the case of the heirs of the late Carrie J. Welton against Henry Bergh, Executor, made a motion to remove the case to the New-Haven Superior Court for trial. Judge Beardsley, after hearing arguments, granted the motion.

Republican primary election will be held in all the Assembly districts of this city today for members of the District Committees, delegates to the County Committee, enrolling officers. Inspectors of Election, and officers of the enrolled Republicans. In the great majority of the districts but one ticket will be offered, but contests will be had in the Fourth.

The Point Lookout Clubhouse, eight cottages, 1,000 acres of beach, the Marine Railroad, and all the property of the Long Beach Construction Company at Long Beach were sold under forclosure, yesteday, by Sheriff Mitchell for $14,000, Representatives of Austin Corbin were the purchasers. Austin Corbin now controls the whole of Long Beach.

PITTSBURG, May 6.--The Pittsburgs "whitewashed" the St. Louis Browns in a brilliant but one-sided name this afternoon. Morris pitched for the home team, and he never was in better form. The Pittsburgs had little trouble in solving the curves of Foutz, and at times batted him freely. Both teams played a good fielding game. The attendance was 2,500. Appended is the score:

There was a fair attendance at the Brighton Beach race track yesterday, and the sport proved to be very interesting, although the favorites were generally successful. The second race was the only surprise of the day. On it a mutual pool dividend of more than $91 was declared to the holders of tickets on Endover.

Five thousand perons witnessed an interesting game of baseball on the Polo Grounds yesterday, when the New-Yorks won a contest from the Washington Club. It was the first appearance of the new League club, and when the members came upon the field they ware warmly greeted. W.H. Marks, of No. 47 Skillman-avenue, Brooklyn, was drawing a dirt cart along Johnson-avenue, in than city, last evening, when three drunken men attempted to get on it. Marks drove them off, and they began to throw stones at him. Finally Marks picked up a large stone from his cart and threw it at his tormentors.

Rollin Boycotter Squire, instead of R. Misnomer Squire, should have been the name of the deputy to whom Maurice B. Flynn kindly permits the city to pay $3,000 a year to run the Department of Public Works. Under instructions, doubtless of his Boss, the mucilaginous deputy has boycotted THE TIMES. He yesterday sent out a public document to the newspapers supposed to be friendly to his interests.

Charles Sauer, of No. 280 Fourth-street, Williamsburg, who is one of the non-union workmen in the Brooklyn Sugar Refinery, started to visit a friend on Meserole-street last night, when he was attacked by Charles Steider, of No. 199 Johnson-avenue; Jacob Steider, of No. 152 Johnson-avenue, and Philip Sceizer, of No. 12 Judgestreet, strikers. They beat him unmercifully before an officer came along and arrested all three of them.
M. Jacques Bertillon, head of the Statistical Office of the Department of the Seine, has marked and adopted a suggestion made not long ago in the Daily News.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 6.--The arrest of a notorious character named James Williams on suspicion of knowing something of the murder of Gilbert Dykeman in the flag shanty is exciting considerable talk. Some years ago Williams aided in the Thorn robbery, during the perpetration of which old man Thorn was gagged and afterward died.

A number of striking wire workers who were gathered about Wolff's factory, in East One Hundred and Eighteenth-street, at noon yesterday attacked Henry Miller, one of the new hands, and severely beat him. Some of Miller's fellow-workmen came to his assistance and succeeded in getting him in the factory,...

COLUMBUS, May 6.--The desertion of the majority of the Ohio Senate, and their crossing of the border into Canada and Kentucky leaves the Legislature in a condition never contemplated. CHICAGO, May 6.--The Chicago men outbatted the Detroit players to-day, and won a game from their opponents by figures of 5 to 1. Clarkson pitched strongly, and he was ably supported. The playing of Pfeffer and Burns was of a good character. The score follows:

To catch and successfully land a tarpon turning the scale well at 125 pounds is a feat which not often falls to the lot of the amateur fisherman to perform. Mr. William Dunning, of No.10 East One Hundred and Twenty-ninthstreet, recently succeeded in doing this at Sanibel Bay, Florida, and the fish is now on exhibition at E. Von Hofe's store, No. 97 Fulton-street.

EMPORIA, Kan., May 6.--The worst rain and hail storm ever known in this vicinity swept over the country just west of this city this forenoon. It struck the west-bound Santa Fe train at Elmdale with such force as to break all the glass on the north side, and even the slats of the blinds were broken by the huge hailstones, which are represented as being as large as apples.

Over 2,000 brave and fair friends of the Twenty-second Regiment gathered in the galleries of the armory, in Fourteenth-street, last night, to watch the skill, strength, and contortions of over 200 of NewYork's most prominent amateur athletes.

DETROIT, Mich., May 6.--Stride matters remain largely unchanged from yesterday. The situation inthe western part of the city, where the strike begun shows the Michigan Car Works and the Detroit Steel and Spring Works still closed, with the men showing no disposition to return. In the eastern end of the town the Peninsular Car Works and the Pullman Car...

The passage of the Aqueduct bill in its amended form yesterday is a surprising performance. Only five votes were recorded against it in the Assembly, and those were cast by County Democrats from this city. The amendment was concurred in by the Senate with only five negative votes, those of CULLEN, DALY,...

BOSTON, May 6.--It is said that Wellesley College has received a legacy of $100,000 as the foundation of an endowment for an art school building. It is understood that the donor wishes to remain unknown.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., May 6.--An unsuccessful but well planned attempt to burn a whole section of this borough was made about midnight last night by unknown parties. Fires were simultaneously started at three different places in the Fifth Ward, a section built up entirely of wood. Fortunately the flames were discovered before they had gotten full headway, and were extinguished without causing serious damage. There is no clue to the incediaries.

The examination of Mr. Clarke, the Tribune correspondent, was continued by the telephone investigatingg committee to-day. Nothing of importance was elicited. The committee will decide to-day whether or not it will examine any more witnesses.
