CHICAGO, May 6.--"The air is surcharged with electricity," to borrow a phrase used by Mayor Carter Harrison this afternoon. He was in an uncommonly communicative mood, and he described the situation pretty accurately when he said: "I think the worst is over, but the troublesome element is, still alive, and may boil over at any moment."

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 6.--The only business transacted at the Protestant Episcopal Convention to-day was the balloting for the Assistant Bishop of the diocese. On the second ballot Dr. Phillips Books received 69 votes and Dr. Davies 61, with 33 votes scattering. There was very little change until the fifth ballot.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 6.--In Naugatuck this noon Miss Kate Weavine was killed while at dinner. A piece of meat lodged in her throat, and before it could he extracted she was choked to death. She was the daughter of James Weaving, and was 25 years old.
From a very small beginning Best Co.'s Lilliputian Bazaar, Nos. 60 and 62 West Twenty-third-street, has become one of the most noted establishments in New-York.

An inquest on the death of Patrick J. Gleason, a Special Deputy Sheriff, who fell from a Sixth-avenue elevated railroad train on Saturday night, while it was moving south from the Park-place station, was held yesterday by Coroner Nugent. The jury was composed of ten men, and one.

FORT WORTH, Texas, May 6.--The subcommittee of the special Congressional investigating committee arrived here this morning at 9 o'clock in a special train from Denison. The subcommittee is composed of Messre. William H. Crain, of Texas, Chairman: John H. Outhwait, of Ohio; Abraham X. Parker, of NewYork, and James Buchanan, of New-Jersey,...
"Don Caesar" is drawing well at Wallack's, and Mr. McCaull expects Dellinger's operetta to have a long run.

The Century for May is one of the best of recent numbers. Apart from its war papers, it is valuable and extremely readable. The war papers include the promised one on Antietam by the late Gen. McClellan. It is only a fragment, but the interest of it is still considerable. Gen. D.H. Hill's account of the battle of South Mountain is valuable also, though in another...

The Metropolitans won an interesting contest from the Athletic Club at Staten Island yesterday. For seven innings the score remained 1 to 0 in favor of the visitors, but in the following inning the Mets made a spurt and secured the 2 runs necessary to win.

The annual meeting of the American Ticket Brokers' Association is to be held on Tuesday of next week in Cincinnati. The officers of the association are O.P. Blake, of Davenport, Iowa, President; F.T. Lindenberger, of...

NEW-ORLEANS, May 6.--Yesterday morning W.P. Green, a wealthy and influential planter of Terre Aux Boeuf, in St. Bernard Parish, just below this city, was shot by as unruly negro named Robert Smith, who refused to go to work when ordered.

The large and valuable library of Congressman Abram S. Hewitt was almost entirely destroyed by fire, water, and smoke yesterday at his residence, No. 9 Lexington-avenue. Mrs. Hewitt is in Europe, and Mr. Hewitt, in her absence, was making alterations in the house. An annex was constructed last year, and the ground floor of it was handsomely fitted up as a library.

Justus H. Schwab, the yellow-haired Socialist, entered the District Attorney's office yesterday and declared that he came to offer himself as bondsmen for John Mollenhauer, of No. 58 First-avenue, one of the men accused of boycotting George Theirs, of the Alhambra...

CHICAGO, May 6--11:55 P.M.--Two alarms of fire have just been turned in simultaneously --one alarm from Ashland-avenue bridge, in the lumber district, the other is from State and Harrison streets, the centre of the city's lowest quarter. If incendiary fires were to be started by Anarchists it would be difficult to choose two other locations from which equally disastrous conflagrations could spread.

The people of New-Rochelle were busy yesterday discussing a possible elopement and comparing notes to get at the facts, which are somewhat shrouded in mystery. Christian Becker is one of the oldest inhabitants of the village, and has a large factory at Davenport's Neck, on the Sound, where many years ago he began the manufacture of "balances and weights of precision," as his circulars announce.

Since the letter of District Attorney Martine urging the continuance of the Broadway Railroad investigation was made public, a good deal of curiosity has been excited in regard to Mr. Martine's purposes in the matter, and especially in relation to "Scott," the witness whom it is proposed to examine to-morrow.

There is a natural disinclination on the part of the men who have thrown up their situations in the Third-Avenue Railroad Company to apply for re-employment. It would be much pleasanter for them if the company should apply to them to return to work on their own terms and if they should go back in a triumphal procession.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 6.--Sight drafts on New-York, 20, telegraphic, 25.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 6.--Four indictments were presented by the Grand Jury to-day against Joe Elliott, the forger, who was captured in Naw-York some months ago.
ROME, May 6.--It is officially announced that the Archbishops of Rennes, Rheims, Sens, Baltimore and Quebec, are to be created Cardinals.
ALBANY, N.Y., May 6.--The General Term of the Supreme Court has decided against the city of New-York in the action brought against the State Board of Equalization.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 6.--On the 4th inst. the California Refinery reduced the prices on all grades of sugar. Yesterday the American Refinery met the cut and went a quarter of a cent better. To-day the California Refinery met the American Refinery's cut and dropped prices a quarter of a cent lower.

OTTAWA, May 6.--Canadian canal statistics for 1885 show that the policy of reducing tolls to a nominal rate has not increased the business of the Dominion canals. The total revenue from the canals was $27,000 less in 1885 than in the preceding year.

McGhee, planter and lawyer, of West Feliciana, on the subject of interblending all the evangelical churches into one Christian body. WASHINGTON, May 6.--The first day of the Spring meeting at Ivy City Course was far more interesting than anticipated early in the day. The sky was overcast and there were several light showers of rain, but shortly afternoon there were indications of a favorable change and the trains reached the course well laden. All the events proved of interest except the last.

Mrs. Landgraf was in a state of terror yesterday lest more women should besiege her in her little bakery. The most disagreeable event of the day occurred early in the afternoon. Mrs. Landgraf looked out of her door, and saw a body of men marching down Secondstreet in double file. They were her old tormentors, headed by the boycotters, who are under bail.

The Executive Committee of the pianomakers at Sturtevant Hall, No. 351 East Seventeenth-street, reported last evening that 200 of the Steinways' employes had quit work in the afternoon and joined in the demand for shorter hours.

Mayor Grace yesterday announced that, notwithstanding many rumors to the contrary, he was not a candidate for renomination. ALBANY, May 6.--The supplemental charges against Judge Donohue, after one more struggle against them on the part of the Judge's friends, were introduced in the assembly by Mr. Kruse, of Cattaraugus, to-day, and referred to the Judiciary Committee, to be considered at the same time with the charges of the New-York Bar Association.

The Third-Avenue Company ran cars yesterday without any of its old men, because the old men thought they had been sold out in the agreement published yesterday, and refused to allow themselves to be delivered as goods.
PHILADELPHIA, May 6.--The Philadelphia Club had very little trouble in defeating Boston to-day.

The fur hat pouncers employed by the Yonkers Hat Manufacturing Company and in the factory of John T. Waring Co. have organized a Fur Hat Pouncers' Association. The following have been elected officers: President --William J. Garrabrant; Vice-President--William F. Garrison; Secretary--William Oxley; Treasurer--George Howell.

The Baptist Social Union of Manhattan Island departed last evening from the usual custom of giving a monthly dinner, and instead held a ladies' reception at Delmonico's. The large room was tastefully decorated with flowers and palms, and a collation was set by Delmonico. About 250 persons were present, besides the officers of the union and the Executive Committee.

Again the New Princeton Review leads off with a literary article. The last number had Mr. Lowell's criticism of Gray, and the present one has a paper on " Wordsworth's Passion," by Titus Munson Coan. Passion, Mr. Coan admits, was not the most obvious trait of Wordsworth's verse, and yet he succeeds in showing that Wordsworth had passion.

The contest over the will of Joseph B. Hoffmann, of Brooklyn, who left all his property, aggregating $50,000, to his daughter, Mrs. Stuck, to the exclusion of his other daughters, Mrs. Droll and Mrs. Gundlock, was continued in Surrogate Lott's court yesterday. The only important witness was Mrs. Mary Swandeila, who testified that she and Mrs. Stuck once saved Mr. Hoffmann from burning to death.

NYACK, N.Y., May 6.--Great interest has been manifested in the Bristor case to-day, and a large crowd was in attendance. Several witnesses for the defense were put on the stead to corroborate the testimony given yesterday, but the main feature of the day's proceedings was the testimony of Dr. Bristor himself. He said he was born in Baltimore.

MUSKEGON, Mich., May 6.--The Muskegon Shingle and Lumber Company's mill, the largest on the lake, shut down this morning owing to blockade by the Chicago strike. The mill has been running day and night, employing 180 men and cutting 1,000,000 shingles a day, and has 6,000,000 piled on the dock. There have been no shipments for a week, and the mill will not start up until the strike ends.

ATHENS, May 6.--The Greek Cabinet met this afternoon to discuss the collective note of the powers demandine more precise utterances that Greece will disarm. It is believed the Cabinet will refuse to yield to the demand.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6.--Easton, L.I., will anchor the tug-of-war team at the Mott Haven games. He will also play goal for the lacrosse team. H.E. FORT SULLY, Dakota, May 7.--John Murphy, alias J.J. Harrington, of Company D. Eleventh Infantry, was murdered last night by some unknown person. His corpse was discovered about midnight. HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 8.--The House of Assembly has been in session all day discussing the resolution favoring the separation of Nova Scotia from Canada. Long and able speeches were made by the Hon. Mr. Fielding and others in support of the measure.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 8.--The annual Woodford oratorical contest at Cornell University took place at the armory last night. There were six contestants for the prize of $100. mr. E.D.A. Delima, of New-York City, was awarded the prize by a committee of judges from the Faculty.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 8.--Jesse Gaines Edwards was to-day acquitted in the Marion Superior Court of the alleged murder of his wife in 1854. He was at that time a man of 44 years. Besides his wife and several children a young man, Daniel Majers, and his sister of 16 Summers, were inmates of his family.

Large numbers of the strinking sugar workers in Williamsburg and Greenpoint returned to the refineries yesterday, but nearly 2,000 are still out, and say they will remain out for a month yet. The police think the back of the strike is broken, and that their services will not be needed after another week.

JACKSON, Miss., May 8.--Frank Benoit's farmhouse, 12 miles west of here, was burned yesterday. Nothing was saved. In the house were three children, aged respectively 1,3, and 5 years, who perished in the flames. The mother, working on a distant part of the farm, on seeing the house burning ran to the house, and would have rushed into the fire had she not been restrained by a neighbor who arrived at the same time.

WASHINGTON, May 3.--Congressman Long, ex-Governor of Massachusetts, will go to Worcester this week, with his two daughter, to see his intended bride. The girls will remain with her until the wedding day, May 25, and the Governor will return to his duties in Washington on Friday.

FRANKLIN, Penn., May 8.--The Eclipse Oil Refinery, one of the largest in the oil region, was on fire to-day. The fire was controlled after 800 barrels of oil had been consumed and the wool bleachers entirely destroyed. A tank of benzine took fire, but was quickly extinguished. The loss will not be heavy.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 8.--A brilliant aurora is visible in this city to-night. It consists of an arch of green light in the north, with streamers that are at times of intense brightness. The streamers were visible a short time after sunset.

LANCASTER, Penn., May 8.--John D. Skiles, Assignee of Amos S. Henderson, banker, to-day filed his account of the estate. The assets, after deducting all the expenses, are $92,242,71 and the liabilities $330,000. The creditors will receive between 25 and 30 cents on the dollar.

GILMER, Texas, May 8.--Monroe Cyrus went into Winnsborough recently and got on a protracted spree. His father went after him and took him home. While the lather was upbrading his son for his conduct the latter seized a gun and shot his father twice, inflicting mortal wounds. After the shooting the son fied, but a posse is in sharp pursuit. The excitement is intense.

DUBLIN, May 8.--The Express, (Conservative,) commenting on the alleged Wolseley threat, says that one result of the passage of the Home Rule bill would be to clear the army within 24 hours of some of its best officers, "who," adds the paper, "would not go alone to Ulster." The Express also declares that military strategists are already studying Irish maps and Ulster history.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 8.--Robert Montgomery and W.C. Bailey, formerly employed by the Missouri Pacific Railroad at Greenleaf, Kan., were arrested there yesterday morning charged with wrecking the Missouri Pacific freight train at Wyandotte, which cost two lives. The prisoners were taken to Wyandotte yesterday afternoon. They claim ability to prove their innocence, but the officers appear certain that they have two of the supposed trio of wreckers.

DETROIT, Mich., 8.--The Post Office at Manistee was robbed last night of nearly $5,000, including $1,700 in stamps, $1,300 in currency, and $1,800 in bank stock deposit certificates.

TORONTO, May 8.--The drivers and conductors of all street cars in the city went on strike this morning at 5 o'clock. The cause of the strike was that the street car company refused to employ any man who was a member of the Knights of Labor, notwithstanding their promise to recognize the Knights when the last strike was settled.

BERLIN, May 8.--It is stated that the Vatican will postpone the appointment of a Papal Nuncio at Berlin until the Ecclesiastical bill becomes a law. The communications that have passed between the Prussian Government and the Pope on the subject show that there is still some variance between them, but it is expected that an arrangement will be effected at an early date.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, May 8.--harry McFadden, an employe of the Chicago, Burlington and Northern Road, and Miss Addie Taylor, both of Savannah, Ill., while out riding last evening in some way entangled the buggy wheels in the brush on the riversbank and the whole outfit tipped over. The young people were both drowned. Their bodies have been recovered.

ATHENS, May 8.--Germany, Austria, England, Russia, and Italy have notified Greece that a blockade of her ports has been ordered. This has been established by the foreign fleets, extending from Cape Malia to Colonna and from the Gulf of Corinth to the most northern point of the Greek frontier.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8.--The motion for a new trial in the case of Achille Onofri, the professional acrobat who beat to death his little stepdaughter, Lottle Cooke, was called for argument before Judge Hare in the new Court House to-day. Counsel for the prisoner said that they did not wish to argue the points, as they had been duly discussed at the trial and would finally have to be passed on by the Supreme Court.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 8.--Judge Barr this morning brought in an opinion in the case of the United States against, John B. Thompson for tax on 1,065 gallons of whisky, amounting to $958.50. He holds that Thompson must pay the tax.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., May 8.--A large crowd of representative colored people particpated today in the ceremonies of laying the cornerstone of the Southern University Building on Magazine-street. CHICAGO, May 8.--Officer Timothy Flavin, who was one of the policemen wounded by the explosion of the bomb which the Anarchists threw into the column of police in Desplainesstreet on Tuesday night, died at the county hospital this afternoon. The valuable setter dog Leo, owned by Dr. D. Safford, rendered valuable service to his master yesterday afternoon. The Treasury Department is informed that the board appointed to appraise the Public Stores in New-York has fixed their value at $810,000 and arrangements are being made to secure a new lease of them at an annual rent of 8 per cent. of that amount.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 8.--Four men while at work reparing the bridge tunnel to-day were seriously, but not fatally, injured by the explosion of a gasoline lamp, by the light of which then were working. The men were horribly burned about the heads and hands, and three of them sustained serious internal injuries by inhaling the flames from the lamp. They were taken to the City Dispensary, where their wounds were dressed.
Verdi has returned to Italy. He came here to arrange about selling the copyright of his opera, "Otello," and to buy farming and garden implements, plants, and seeds.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., May 8.--The Democratic Convention of the Second Congressional District to-day nominated J.C. Beard to fill the vacancy caused by the death the Hon. Michael Hahn. Capt. Henry N. Martin is the regular Republican nominee.

TORONTO, Ontario, May 8.--Judgment was given here to-day in a case which has excited great interest in sporting circles in general and among admirers of baseball in particular. The Canadian Baseball League was formed last December by the Toronto Baseball Association, the Maple Leaf Club, of Guelph; the Clippers, of Hamilton, and the London Baseball Club.

The two veto messages sent to the House yesterday by the President throw some light upon a kind of legislation that consumes a great deal of time in Congress and has heretofore received very little attention at the White House. About 9,000 bills have been introduced in the House since the beginning of the current session.

The spirit of Wilkins Micawber has possessed Wall-street during the past week. Everybody has been waiting for something to turn up. And the disappointed ones were numerous enough to form an army. The week opened inauspiciously with the failure of Tasker Marvin, an operator known in Wall-street for many years as one of the masters of manipulation in the stock market.

READING, Penn., May 8.--The Reading Daily News suspended publication this afternoon. The proprietor, William S. Ritter, states his reasons to be the recent action taken by the typographical union or this city demanding 20 per cent. increase in wages.

The man claiming to be Carl Peters, or Peterson, who voted the Simpson ticket at the Sixth District Republican primary, Friday afternoon, was arraigned in the Essex Market Court yesterday for voting illegally. He has an Irish face, and his real name is said to be Patrick O'Reilly.
The Coney Island Rod and Gun Club will have a shoot at Prospect Park Fair Grounds on Wednesday, and the Unknown Gun Club will shoot at Dexter Park on the following day.

WASHINGTON, May 8.--Major John E. Blaine, Paymaster, has been granted two months' leave of absence.

Events of the week which at any other times would have been all absorbing have fallen fiat in a few hours.

Another bag of the Oregon's mail was received at the Post Office yesterday. It contained newspapers from Great Britain for Boston and was forwarded from Smith's Island, Virginia, where is was picked up on the 5th inst. of the 598 bags dispatched 278 have been found.

Thirty-one species of snakes and two of blindworms (Typhlopidoe) are recorded to occur in Palestine; the larger proportion of the snakes are harmless; the hooded cobra (Naja haje) is rare; it is well known in the plains beyond Beersheba, but does not apparently occur in the cultivated districts.

CHICAGO, May 8.--The Union Mutual Life Insurance Company, of Maine, to-day agreed to relinquish its claims upon the property of the Chicago University upon condition that the Trustees of the university raise by subscription $500,000 cash before the 1st of April, 1887.

WASHINGTON, May 8.--The President left Washington this afternoon for a short visit to Representative W.L. Scott's stock farm, on the shore of Chesapeake Bay. He was accompanied by Representative Scott, Col. Lamont, and Mr. William Woodward, of New-York. The trip was made on Mr. Woodward's steam yacht Wanda, which was brought from New-York for the purpose. The party expect to return to Washington Monday.

MANASQUAN, N.J., May 8.--The twomasted schooner Mary Holly, bound from Norfolk, Va., to New-York, struck the beach at 11:30 o'clock last night, just north of the Berkeley Arms Hotel, at Berkeley, N.J., during a dense fog. Her cargo consists of 200 cords of pine wood, which, owing to the heavy northeast sea, is being rapidly washed overboard and distributed for miles along the coast.

PARIS, April 16.--Another Shakespearean adaptation or translation gave us the "Songe d'une nuit d'ete," or "Midsummer Night's Dream," at the Odeon Theatre. Instead of nine scenes or tableaus in the five acts we have eight tableaus and three acts, which to all Shakespearean lovers must seem almost desecration, as it cuts out entirely whole passages familiar and dear to every schoolboy.

HONESDALE, Penn., May 8.--"There don't seem to be no fun nor no sentiment in canallers on this line no more, "said a veteran boatman on the Delaware and Hudson Canal, who was lying on his oars, so to speak, while his boat was tied up, along with half a hundred others, waiting for the repairing of a break in the canal, down the line.
A verified story is told of two street car conductors going to a Cincinnati clothier and for $10 each purchasing a suit of clothes, uniform with that worn by all other men similarly employed.

DALLAS, Ga., May 8.--Last night there arrived in this city Ben Coalson, his wife, and two children, who went to the house of the Rev. Mr. Coalson. The stranger, representing himself to be a son of the Rev. Mr. Coalson's brother, in South Georgia, was warmly welcomed.

Charles Crocker, the Southern Pacific Railroad magnate, who was lately thrown from his carriage and seriously hurt, is reported now by his friends to be on the sure road to recovery. He has suffered a good deal from the fractured bones and general shaking up that resulted from his accident, but tender nursing and a hardy constition have pulled him through.

Mary E. Suerry arrived at Castle Garden yesterday, on the steamship Edam, accompanied by a young man and a child about 8 years of age. Clerk Silberstein's suspictons were aroused, and he subjected the woman to an examination.

Chief Marshal Jameson received word at Englwood at 10:30 o'clock last night that the burglar who shot George S. Coe, Jr., in the Tea Neck schoolhouse last Wednesday night had been captured, and was under guard in a Hoboken police station.

A circular has been issued by the Secretary of the State Board of Health, directing attention to the prevalence of Asiatic cholera in Italy, France, Spain, and Japan. "The history of this disease is," the Secretary says, "that whenever it has made its appearance in Europe sooner or later it found its way to this country. Already one or two suspicious cases have been reported in the United States."

What would a few years ago have been a difficulty between two eminent Colonels in North Carolina has now shrunk to the proportions of an affair, and now seems likely to dwindle still further to a mere incident. It is well worth noting as an illustration how far modern ideas have penetrated the fastnesses to which chivalry has betaken itself.

The task of procuring a jury to tryAlderman Henry W. Jaehne will be begun tomorrow morning at 11 o'clock, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Judge Barrett. A reporter of THE TIMES ascertained yesterday, that in all likelihood 12 men who cannot be bribed will be selected.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 8.--Rain fell to-day for the first time in several weeks, and it can be said that Newport has been unsually favored for her annual preparations for the coming fashionable season, but it must be admitted that cottage renting has not been very brisk of late. The weather certainly has favored those having cottages to rent.

Last evening's performance of "The Sultan of Zanzibar" at the Academy of Music may have added a small amount to the fund intended to assist the destitute Polish exiles in this country, and if it did its occurrence is not to be deplored.

The fourth annual kirmess for the benefit of the charity fund of the New-York Skin and Cancer Hospital will be held in the Thirtyfourth-Street Park, at Thirty-fourth-street and Fourth-avenue, on Thursday and Friday, May 27 and 28, from 1 P.M. till midnight.

BRADFORD, Penn., May 8.--Millions of wild pigeons are nesting in the woods on the borders of Forest and Warren Counties, in what is known as the Spring Creek region. The country thereabout is almost an unbroken wilderness, a few bark-peelers, log-cutters, and oil well "wild-catters" forming the entire population.

To-day being the Sunday of the Good Shepherd, the members of the Society of St. Vincent de Paul will make a general communion in all parts of the world. In this city the mass for the members will be celebrated in the Lady chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral at 7 o'clock this morning.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 8.--The Union will print to-morrow morning a letter from Congressman Mitchell, in which he positively declines to be a candidate for renomination, on the ground that his Congressional duties occupy too much of his time to the neglect of his private business. The announcement will prove a surprise to his consitutents, as it was already decided that he would be the party's candidate, and his nomination and election was almost conceded.

George Staugel, a German market gardener living in Astoria, was arrested last night on a charge of beating his wife, and was locked up in the First Police Precinet Station in Long Island City while his friends went to procure bail. An hour later he was found suspended by a comforter to a window bar, and dead. He had committed suicide. An inquest will be held on Tuesday. Staugel was 75 years old.

WAXAHACHIE, Texas, May 8.--Six thousand people assembled in Waxahachie to-day to witness the public execution of George Young, convicted of wife murder. The doomed man was conveyed to the scaffold at 1:40 P.M.

EUFAULA, Ala., May 9.--Jefferson Davis and party left here at 9 o'clock this morning, after spending the night. They reached here last night from Savannah at 10 o'clock.

WINFIELD, Long Island, May 10.--George Badger, son of Dr. William Badger, of Flushing, was fatally injured this afternoon, being struck by a baseball bat in the lands of Manuel Alvarez. Both were pupils at Flushing Institute and had been playing ball together.

L.E. Myers has written a letter stating that he has accepted the challenge of W.G. George to run one mile on Saturday evening at the Madison-Square Garden.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 10.--The Senate convened at 10 o'clock this morning, 21 Republicans and 1 Democrat, Mr. Van Cleaf, answering to their names. Early in the morning rumors were current that the party that had so recently stormed Lookout Mountain would return to Columbus during the morning's session and attempt to undo the work of Saturday.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 10.--The General Assembly met to-day at Baton Rouge in biennial session, and the Governor's message was read. Of the finances of the State he says the collection of taxes has been vigorous and close.
The Board of Managers of the New-York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, at the last meeting of the season, yesterday, was told what had been done during the year.

Mrs. Elena R. Smith, a passenger on the steamship Saratoga, from Havana, died at 8 A. M. Wednesday, and was buried at sea.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 10.--In July, 1885, Joseph Groblewski, of Brooklyn, poisoned his wife, Clara. He was tried at the Court of Sessions and sentenced to be hanged. An appeal was taken to the General Term, which court today granted a new trial on the around that there was not sufficient evidence to convict.

OSCALOOSA, Iowa, May 10.--The most violent rain and wind storm of the year struck this city last evening. Heavy thunder was constant and a terrific gale prevailed. The loss to property in this city will exceed $15,000.

The steamer Elm City, on her trip yesterday from New-Haven to New-York, broke down at 1 P.M. off Captain Island. Her passengers were transferred to the steamer Bridgeport, from New-York for Bridgeport, and the Elm City was taken in tow by a tug for New-York.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 11.--John Kelly, a brakeman on the Freight train leaving this city for New-York at 2 A.M., was killed at Westport this morning. In trying to jump on board the moving train at the station he missed his hold and fell under the wheels. Seventeen cars passed over his body, breaking every bone in it and scattering the limbs along the track. Kelly was an unmarried man, aged 21. He lived in Stamford.

WASHINGTON, May 11.--The House Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads took up the appropriation bill this morning, but did not reach the subsidy clause inserted by the Senate. Whether it reaches it to-morrow or next day will not much matter. It will go out and the House will sustain its action in rejecting it.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., May 11.--Sallie O'Neil's trial to-day developed but little new. The Commonwealth closed after calling a number of witnesses to describe the conduct of the prisoner before the killing.

ATHENS, May 11.--M. Papamichalopulos, Minister of the Interior in the late Cabinet, and who favors submission to the wishes of the powers, has agreed to form a new Ministry. He promises to disarm the Greek Army.

Hopson, of Paterson, and a jury of nine men formally investigated the cause of the death of Periko Fernandez and his wife Bella yesterday afternoon, and in an hour and a half a verdict was returned that Mr. Fernandez was accidentally shot by his wife, and that the latter committed suicide.
DETROIT, Mich., May 11.--The second game between the Detroit and New-York Clubs this afternoon resulted in an overwhelming victory for the home team.

An outbreak of typhus fever, discovered yesterday by sanitary officers in the Deborah Nursery, an institution for the care an education of young Hebrew children in East Broadway, caused some excitement in the Health Department.
The twenty-first annual meeting of the National Temperance Society was held yesterday at No. 58 Reade-street, the Rev. Dr. T.L. Cuyler presiding.
FORT WORTH, Texas, May 11.--Fort Worth has had a taste of dynamite. Yesterday morning at 1:30 o'clock an explosion took place which caused consternation among the people who live in the neighborhood.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 11.--The Yale Freshmen held their class athletic games this afternoon and say some pretty contests, but no records were broken.

From Glasgow, Scotland, comes a special cable dispatch to the Nautical Gazette, which that paper will publish to-day.
The statement of the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company for the quarter ending March 31 was put on file with the Railroad Commissioners at Albany yesterday.
DETROIT, Mich., May 11.--The Michigan Car Company's works were opened to-day. About 100 men went to work in the iron departments, but no attempt was made to run the wood working portions.

An entertainment of music and recitations was given at Chickering Hall last evening for the benefit of Messrs. Phipps and Edwards, in which a large number of ladies and gentlemen who have appeared in various places during the last season under the direction of those managers took part.

PITTSBURG, May 11.--At Brandonville, West Va., on Sunday evening, Charles Latael, a shoemaker, killed John Seib, a saddlemaker, by stabbing him through the heart. The cause of the affray is not known.

BOSTON, May 11.--Late yesterday afternoon Dr. Frederick N. Palmer, an old gentleman of 73, left his house at No. 226 West Chester Park with his little grandson, Wendell R. Smith, for a walk, saying he would return in half an hour. When night came and he did not appear his family alarmed.

The New-York hotel keepers have combined to demonstate to 500 visiting bonifaces of high and low degree from all parts of the United States and Canada what Manhattan Island can offer in the way of a gorgeous and luxurious picnic. Never have so many hotel keepers found shelter in New-York at any one time as last night.

The courts have again decided that the Bell Telephone Company cannot be allowed to withhold telephone privileges from persons or corporations on the ground that they are unfriendly to the Western Union Telegraph Company. This time the decision is made in Baltimore.
MAHANOY CITY, Penn., May 11.--The details have just come to light of an elopement which shocks society here. J.H. Hintermeister is known throughout this State and New-York.

STANTON, Neb., May 11.--The main barn of the Stanton Breeding Company, 14 miles south of here, was burned yesterday. Thirtyeight breeding mares, valued at $8,000, and a stallion worth $2,100 perished. A quantity of grain and some farming implements were destroyed. The loss will reach $20,000.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 11.--Michael McGovern, Democratic Register of the Fifth Ward, died at his home, No. 23 Wallace-street, early this morning.

WATERBURY, Conn., May 11.--While a boy named Silvey was stealing a ride on a freight train here to-night he met with a serious accident. In jumping from one of the cars he was caught between the car and a platform and badly crushed. One of his arms was broken and he received internal injuries.

BUFFALO, May 11.--Frank Sipp, son of ex-Assemblyman Sipp, was arrested to-day charged with stealing money from letters while in his possession for delivery as a letter carrier.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 11.--Dr. J.C. Beard, unable to stand the attacks of the Democratic press on account of the manner and character of his nomination by the recent alleged Democratic Convention, to-night sent to the committee a letter declining the nomination. It was accepted after a warm debate.

BATAVIA, N.Y., May 11.--"I have taken poison!" was the exclamation that set the academic department of the high school in Attica, Wyoming County, in a whirl of excitement yesterday afternoon. Miss Katie Schroader, a pretty German girl of only 16 years, was the speaker.

LANCASTER, Penn., May 11.--Last evening Cyrus Sheaffer's large barn at Bareville, this county, was destroyed by fire, with all its contents, consisting of grain, hay, carriages, implements, The loss will reach several thousand dollars, and there is no insurance. A servant girl was accused of firing the barn and arrested. The girl's name is Margaret Hess, and she is about 16 years of age.

HARRISBURG, Penn., May 11.--On information of Insurance Commissioner Forster the court this morning granted an order against the Commonwealth Mutual Fire Insurance Company of Lancaster County citing it to appear in court to show cause why it should not be adjudged insolvent and a Receiver appointed.

Alderman Henry W. Jaehne, indicted for receiving a bribe of $20,000 for voting for the Broadway franchise, entered the Court of Oyer and Terminer at 10 o'clock yesterday morning with a Deputy Sheriff. The Alderman had spent the night in Ludlow-Street Jail, but he had apparently not been neglected by his barber when he arose in the morning.
LIVERPOOL, May 11.--The Queen arrived here to-day for the purpose of personally opening the Liverpool International Exhibition.

BOSTON, May 11.--A large and enthusiastic meeting of the Freshman Class of Harvard was held this evening at Cambridge to take action on the challenge recently received from the Yale Freshmen for a two-mile straightaway race at New-London. E.C. Storrow, the Captain of the crew, presided.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., May 11.--Patrick Noonan, a boy 17 years old, was arrested to night on a charge of throwing a stone at one of Perkins Staples's teamsters named Saint Onge. It struck his head, and it is feared he is fatally injured. Another of Perkins Staples's teamsters, David Averill, fell off his truck to-day, and his back was very badly injured.

Henry Stillman, a young grocer, was sued in the Supreme Court yesterday by Johanna Bohm for breach of promise of marriage. Damages to the amount of $5,000 were claimed. Stillman acknowledged the promise of marriage and offered to marry the girl in court.
PITTSBURG, May 11.--The Pittsburgs won another game from Cincinnati this afternoon by good batting. The visitors also indulged in some heavy batting, but their hits were scattered.

BOSTON, Mass., May 11.--The Supreme Court to-day granted the petition of the Daily Law Record for a mandamus to compel John Lathrop, reporter of decisions, to allow plaintiff to copy the decisions for publication.
H. Hermann, a furniture manufacturer who employs 350 men, closed his shop yesterday rather than shorten working time to eight hours.

MONTREAL, May 11.--The annual statement of the Bank of Montreal was issued today. The business during the year was not so large as had been anticipated. The profits were $1,456,976, against $1,393,116 the previous year, an increase of $72,880, or equal to a little over per cent. on the capital.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 13.--The excitement caused by the disaster of Tuesday has subsided. The search for the bodies in the ruins has been discontinued, as it is considered certain that all have been recovered. A large number of funerals are being held to-day. One or two of the injured are still in a critical condition.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 13.--The east-bound sleeper, due at Worcester at 4:55 this morning, collided with a light engine going west, at a point two and a half miles east of Schenevus, on the Albany and Susquehaunn Road. Both engines were and damaged. The fireman on the light engine, John Legally, was killed, and Engineer Flannery had both legs broken. None of the passengers were injured.

ROME, May 13.--The following are today's cholera returns: Brindisi, 5 new cases, 3 deaths; Bari, 20 new cases, 4 deaths; Venice, 3 new cases, 6 deaths. Quarantine regulations will be enforced along the whole Italian littoral.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 13.--Advices from Newfoundland are to the effect that great destitution prevails in Labrador. The latter part of the Winter was extremely cold and no seals were caught on the coast. A correspondent writing from there says that in a very large number of cases existence is only sufferings.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 13.--Gov. Oglesby last night ordered the withdrawal from East St. Louis of the remaining two companies of militia. This leaves that point entirely unprotected so far as the military is concerned.

Prentiss, President and Cashier, respectively, of the defunct German-American National Bank of this city, were found guilty in the Criminal Court here to-day on five indictments charging them with making false entries on the books of the bank in 1878. He promised to give another exhibition here next Winter, before going to Europe.

He interested one Joseph Tucker, and a banker named Andrews in the scheme, and employed one Bowles to engrave the pictures.

PARIS, April 27.--After the remarkable success of his comedy of "Seraphine," at the Gymnase, in December, 1868, M. Victories Sardou decided on taking a little rest. "Seraphine" had cost him a good deal of labor, it had taken a good deal of time to elucubrate, and he was, emphatically, played out.

Freighted with flowers and with smiling end sobbing humanity, the Cunarder Aurania steamed out of New-York Harbor yesterday afternoon. Augustin Daly, as he stepped aboard, followed by his company, glanced about him inquiringly. He was looking for "standing room only" signs and wondered, in an abstracted manner, why the doors were not closed.

Mr. Joseph is a manufacturer of cigars, his factory and residence both being in the same building.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 15.--George Leppert, a mason by trade, dropped dead of apoplexy in a harness store at Port Jervis yesterday afternoon while buying a leather valve for a pump. Leppert was 67 years old. He was of German ancestry, and leaves a widow and three sons.

Many of us still cling to the old myth about the inability of the average Northerner to speak good English, but we are gradually giving it up. We have learned that some localities in this country were settled by immigrants from certain English counties and that the peculiarities of speech brought from the mother country have been handed down from father to son.

COTTAGE CITY, Martha's Vineyard, Mass., May 15.--The perparations for an unusually brilliant season at this beautiful city of cottages, surrounded by ocean waves, are going on with much rapidity. The cottages are being freshly painted inside and out, and the lawns are now looking very beautiful with the verdure that is seen only in Springtime.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 15.--The Court of Appeals has just handed down a decision in a case of considerable interest to travelers by rail--that of John J. Hallahan against the Erie Railway Company.

Col. Samuel N. Benjamin, Assistant Adjutant General of the Division of the Atlantic, died at his quarters on Governor's Island, at 6 o'clock yesterday morning. He had been suffering for several days with rheumatism, but on Friday night his physician thought that he was much better. The disease, however, attacked the heart, and he died suddenly.

AUBURN, N.Y., May 15.--Henry Dickerson, who killed his wife in the village of Moravia, in this county, last Fall, was to-day convicted of murder in the second degree and sentenced to life imprisonment in Auburn Prison.

Dr. Paul H. Kretzschmar yesterday made a post-mortem examination of the body of Jacob Hertline, of Brooklyn, who was supposed to have died of hydrophobia on Friday. Hertline was bitten by a Newfoundland dog on March 6. Dr. Spitzka assisted in the examination, and the two agreed that there were unmistakable signs of death from hydrophobia.

CHICAGO, May 16.--States' Attorney Grinnell held an important conference at the Central Police Station to-day with Inspector Bonfield, Capt. Ward, Lieut. Shea, and Lieut. Kipley, of the detective force, in reference to the matter of the presentation of testimony before the Grand Jury to-morrow on the dynamite bomb case of May 4.

Ex-President Arthur's condition has been steadily growing worse during the past week, but he has not relapsed so far as to have lost all the ground gained during his unexpected rally of about 10 days ago.

ERIE, Penn., May 16.--Kingtown, a suburb of Erie, had a brutal display of viciousness this evening which will end in a murder. CHICAGO, May 16.--At three of the five leading Chicago playhouses fortnight engagements of moderate success came to an end last night, and at one of them the Summer season, with Summer prices, opened this evening.
PHILADELPHIA, May 16.--One of the events of the present week in Germantown will be the marriage of Miss Mattie C. Button to Edward Goodhall, of New-York.

BOSTON, May 16.--John Thomas, of former slave, was buried to-day. He was born 64 years ago on a plantation near Annapolis, Md., and became so faithful that his master let him to the owners of foreign vessels as a steward.

The Italian congregation which for five years has held meetings in the chapel of the Five Points House of Industry, under the guidance of the Rev. Antonio Arrighi, was last night organized as a church, with 91 members.
BARTOW, Fla., May 16.--Dan and Lou Mann, who murdered Marshal Campbell and wounded Officer McCormick on Saturday, were lynched late last night.

Edwin J. Erwin, of Peekshill, oil buyer of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company, who married Cora Lent, of that place, after she had run away from home with a young man named Rosenheim, has published an advertisement in a Peekskill paper warning all persons against trusting or harboring her.

So much interest has to late been taken in the Kentucky Derby that the great 3-yearold events of the American Jockey Club to be decided at Jerome Park within the next two weeks have been but little talked about.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 16.--A sensation was caused here to-night by the announcement that J.B. Haggin, the Californian, had issued orders to withdraw his string of horses from the track here to take them to Latonia.

WATERBURY, Conn., May 16.--William Meara, known to his friends as "the bull," was arrested here to-day charged with trying to poison three horses belonging to his brother, John Meara, who is a backman.

The Anarchists made another attempt to hold a meeting last evening, but were unsuccessful, as they were not able to secure a hall. At Lincoln Hall, at Allen and Houston streets, the proprietor informed them that he kept meeting rooms for bona fide trades and labor organizations, but did not want to have anything to do with Anarchists.
PORTLAND, Oregon, May 16.--The United States Fish Commissioner's car, in charge of J. Frank Davis, arrived here yesterday. It started with 1,000,000 shad, of which about 300,000 died on route.
The Rev. R. Heber Newton preached the first of a series of sermons on the labor question yesterday. "Labor's View of the Situation" was his topic, and he spoke with more than usual earnestness.
CHICAGO, May 15.--James Jemison's head was almost entirely severed from his body tonight by one slash from a razor in the hands of Charles Jones.

ALBANY, May 16.--Unless a change is made in their programme the Domocrats will devote themselves this week to preventing the McMillan-Barager bill from coming up for action in the Assembly. This is the Prison Labor bill finally agreed upon as a party measure by the Republicans. Until very recently it seemed as though nothing would be done by this Legislature upon this question.

In his sermon yesterday morning in Plymouth Church the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher touched upon national topics and the capability of American institutions to receive and assimilate the vast number of immigrants coming to the country. He began by tracing the growth of the Pilgrim and Puritan idea of State building and the work it has accomplished.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--The members of the special committee which the House of Representatives sent out West to investigate the strikes and the labor troubles on the railroad returned to Washington to-day.

The Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club at its meeting, to be held on Wednesday evening, will vote on several important proposed amendments to its by-laws and sailing regulations.
In his sermon upon the labor question last evening the Rev. Dr. Strobridge, of the Eighteenth-Street Methodist Episcopal Church, said that to solve the labor problem one of three things must be done.

Miss Dora V. Becker, a young violinist of decided promise, will give a concert at Chickering Hall on Friday evening of this week. She will have the assistance of Mr. Donald De V. Graham and that of Miss Agnes Florence.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 16.--The pretty little suburban town of West End was-to-day the scene of a bloody tragedy, in which the Hon. Frank P. Gray, a distinguished lawyer, was shot and killed by R.L. Jones, the town Marshal.

William Gilpin, the English "gentleman rider," who had a terrible fall at the Cedarhurst steeplechases on Saturday, while trying to take the stone wall on his mount, Cyclone, lay all day yesterday in the pavilion at Bellevue Hospital in a semi-stupor.

CHICAGO, May 16.--John L. Sullivan and Charles Mitchell have signed the following: "Articles of agreement entered into between John L. Sullivan, of Boston, Mass., champion of the world, and Charles Mitchell, of England, champion of Great Britain.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 16.--Capt. A.H. Bogardus to-day challenged Graham, the English shot, to shoot 100 birds, London Gun Club rules, for $5,000. The match to take place after Bogardus's circus engagement closes.

The Forty-soventh Regiment, National Guard, attended service at Christ Church, in Bedford-avenue, Williamsburg, last evening, and listened to the annual sermon preached by their Chaplain, the Rev. Dr. Newland Maynard.

LONDON, May 16.--Discount was quiet during the week at 2 for three months and 1 for short. The Stock Exchange loan rate to next account is 2 to 3 . Business on the Stock Exchange was fairly active, and prices showed a tendency to rise until the close of the week, when the improvement ceased, the unsettled state of home politics affecting dealings.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union a resolution was passed protesting against the passage by the Legislature of the bill providing for the addition of 500 men to the police force as a direct menace to the workingmen of the city, and asking the Governor to veto it.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 16.--Mrs. Margaret E. Routh, wife of George L. Routh, died to-day at her home, No. 154 Liberty-street. Some days ago, while she was at work near a stove, her dress caught fire, and before assistance could reach her she was frightfully burned about the head, body, and limbs.

Archbishop Corrigan delivered a short sermon at the 6 o'clock mass and celebrated the 7 o'clock mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning. The mass at 9 o'clock was celebrated by Bishop Spalding, of Peoria, who is a guest at the archiepiscopal residence.
NEWPORT, R.I., May 16.--The past week has been noted for cold, disagreeable east winds and leaden-colored skies. A more disagreeable week could not have been experienced at this season of the year.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., May 16.--The Enterprise Distillery, at Pekin, owned and operated by Edward Spellman and James Doheny, was destroyed by fire at 1 A.M. to-day, together with the distillery office, books, and several cars of grain.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 16.--Another legal complication has arisen out of the Wallingford excitement over the many incendiary fires in that town.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 16.--Medical Examiner Eliot to-day made an autopsy on the body of G.S. Schafer, the St. Louis cigarmaker found dead in North Haven Creek on Friday.
Annie Eplein, 13 years old, who lived with her parents at No. 113 Water-street, Brooklyn, left her home yesterday afternoon and walked over to Fulton-street, where she met a policeman.
A little yellow dog was found licking the blood from the face of a fallen man on the sidewalk at Sussex and Warren streets, Jersey City, late Saturday night.
The forty-fifth anniversary of the South Reformed Church of Brooklyn, at Third-avenue and Fifty-second-street, was celebrated yesterday.

An Eastern paper of recent date contained the following paragraph: "The Vanderbilts have bought 7 farms, containing 2,000 acres, at Burlington, and they will lay out this land in parks, and expend $500,000 this season in improvements. This tract overlooks Lake Champlain, and will be made most beautiful and attractive."

Gov. Hill's connivance with the aqueduct jobbers and schemers in signing the Aqueduct bill is still a fruitful topic of talk among the politicians. John O'Brien and Maurice B. Flynn, the head and front of the men who expect to profit by the Governor's action, are about the only ones who find a good word to describe the action of the Chief Executive of the State, excepting, of course, the Commission.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 16.--The Spring meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club promised to be highly successful in every way. The track at Pimlico is now in first-class condition, having had the benefit of a brisk wind to-day.

The people of Newfoundland appear to have killed the goose that laid the golden egg. Not content with killing all the young whitecoat seals they could reach, they have permitted the unchecked slaughter of the half-grown and old seals.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--The heartiness and enthusiasm with which the project of erecting in Washington a Roman Catholic university has been received by Catholics in all sections of the country are sufficient evidence that it will become a solid and concrete fact before very long. Subscriptions still continue to pour in.
The Columbia College Club will play the University of Pennsylvania nine at the Polo Ground today.
PHILADELPHIA, May 16.--An agreement has been reached between the striking garment cutters and the clothing manufacturers, and the strikers will resume work to-morrow morning.

Capt. Killmer, of the steam yacht Zephyr, last evening reported the capsizing of the catboat Ada and the drowning of all on board. How many persons were drowned he did not know, and the names of the parties on board could not be ascertained last evening.
LONDON, May 16.--The English Government has decided to annex the Kermadec Islands in the South Pacific Ocean.
A number of boys playing ball on Prospect-street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, incensed some Italian ragpickers who lived near by. The boys finally sent a shower of stones into their midst.

SAVANNAH, Ga., May 16.--The Right Rev. Thomas A. Becker, formerly Bishop of Wilmington, Del., was installed Bishop of the Roman Catholic See of Savannah, made vacant by the elevation of Bishop Gross to the Archbishopric...

The conviction of Alderman JAEHNE will do more to purify the murky political atmosphere of this misgoverned city than a dozen citizens' movements could do. In the case of the Aldermen of 1884 civic debauchery had gone too far for preachment, too far for the curative action of reform movements.
The first of a series of excursions under the auspices of the American Yacht Club will be given on Thursday next.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--By gross carelessness, or worse, in the Forty-eighth Congress, the Democrats permitted Postmaster-General Vilas to be saddled with a discretionary and embarrassing statute appropriating $4000,000 to be used in the foreign mail service to pay American vessels.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 16.--An official of the Minnesota and Northwestern Road is authority for the statement that it is President Stickney's intention to begin work as early as possible upon the proposed extension to Duluth. No definite location has yet been made, but for the purpose of making the location a surveying party of 11 was sent north yesterday.

ERIE, Penn., May 16.--There is a very interesting action at law going on here now, in which a widow sues to recover on an ante-nuptial contract. The plaintiff is the widow of the late Matthew M. McClaughrey, of Edinborough, and the defendants are the children of the deceased, and are Mrs. M.E. Cannon, the heirs of Mrs. S. Phipps, and Robert McClaughrey.
The cornerstone of the new St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church at Ashburton and St. Joseph's avenues. Yonkers was laid yesterday morning in the presence of a large congregation.
NEW-ORLEANS, May 16.--THE TIMES'S correspondent has just met Mr. Alfred Pierson, of this city, who has returned from the isthmus of Panama, where he has been for some 13 months past.

TUCSON, Arizona, May 16.--A special from Huachuca says: "Capt. Hatfield, with a troop of cavalry, struck Geronimo a heavy blow yesterday morning at a point 10 miles southest of Santa Cruz, but a few hours later received a heavier blow in return.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 16.--Following are the entries, weights, and betting for to-morrow's races:

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 16.--An Indian Territory special says that within the next 10 days all the intruders or "boomers" upon the Cherokee strip will have been removed, Capt. Price, with a company of the Fifth United States Cavalry, has commenced the work of expulsion, and it will be sweeping and complete.

A peculiar divorce proceeding is pending in Vice-Chancellor Van Fleet's court in Jersey City. The parties to it are John Gschwind, Coroner of Hudson County, who is the defendant, and his first wife, Caroline Gschwind. Coroner was married to his wife in New-York in January, 1867.
One of those curious medley entertainments which have recently been allowed to devastate this community to such an alarming extent took place last evening at the Bijou Opera House.

Charles O'Neill, aged 17 years, shot himself yesterday afternoon while handling a pistol in the barroom of Hall's Hotel, on Chathamstreet. He had been the cashier of the barrom for some time up to about two weeks ago, when he left for other employment.

In St. Stephen's Church yesterday 10 o'clock mass was celebrated by the Rector, the Rev. Dr. Edward McGlynn. The solemn mass was celebrated by the Rev. Dr. Thomas P. McLoughlin, assisted by the Rev. B.J. O'Callaghan and the Rev. John A. Lynch.

PETALUMA, Cal., May 7.--Yesterday, as we had recovered from the bear hunt, the Major suggested that we run over to his model farm on Russian River and he would show us what he would have done with the farm if the climate hadn't been against him. We were surprised to hear the Major bring up this old subject of his model farm.

Actuated apparently by very political economy, Gov. HILL has again seen fit to cripple the State Board of Health by vetoing the small item of $3,000 granted by the Legislature for the constantly increasing duties of sanitary investigation and expert aid in numerous localities. The publislied reason for this retrenchment...

WATCH HILL, R.I., May 16.--The prospect for a Summer season at this resort never was better than at the present time. Applications for rooms at the hotels are numerous and the several proprietors expect to reap a good return from the season's work.
BOSTON, May 16.--The first issue of the Boston Post under its new management, appearing to-morrow, leads off with the following as its statement of principles:

AN AMATEUR BURGLAR'S STORY. On Saturday William G. Adams, a clerk in the employ of Sweetser, Pembrook Co., at No. 376 Broadway, disguised himself as a stoker and made a bold attempt to rob his employers' safe, which contained about $4,000.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16.--In a letter to the Times, which will be published to-morrow, President Franklin B. Gowen, of the Reading Railroad Company, says: "Foreclosure means disintegration. The plan of the reorganization Trustees does not deal with the property as a whole, and involves foreclosure, which must result in disintegration.

DUBLIN, May 16.--News has been received that a mob of Nationalists attacked a number of Protestant peasants while the latter were returning from market at Cookstown, County Tyrone, yesterday. The Protestants resisted the attack and several of them were roughly handled, two being badly burt. No arrests were made.
The bark Vidette, which arrived with a cargo of sugar from Cienfuegos yesterday, was set on fire by a meteor at 1:30 o'clock on the morning of May 5. The Vidette left Clenfuegos on April 22.

Rollin Misplaced Squire, the bad poet from Boston, and humble servant of Maurice B. Flynn, as Commissioner of Public Works, has made a report to the City Chamberlain, which shows up some of the peculiar methods now employed in running the Public Works Department.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 16.--The Board of Mine Inspector Examiners, who have been in session here for a week past comparing papers and examining a number of applicants for appointment as Mine Inspectors, completed their labors at a late hour last night.
The Rev. Samuel D. Alexander, of the Phillips Presbyterian Church, took as the text of his sermon yesterday morning the vision of Joshua just before the taking of Jericho.
PITTSBURG, Penn., May 16.--John Dalzell was nominated for Congress late last night by the Republicans of the Twenty-second District, defeating Gen. Negley, the present incumbent.
ST. PAUL, May 16.--Between 3,000 and 4,000 spectators witnessed the close of the 72hour bicycle race at Minneapolis last night.
ALBANY, May 16.--Col. Thomas S. Henderson, who some years ago was a conspicuous figure in the politics and public affairs of Brooklyn, was found dead in his room at No. 6 Highstreet, this afternoon.
LONDON, May 16.--The Cunard Line steamship Servia, Capt. McKay, sid, from Queenstown for New-York to-day.

TOWANDA, Penn., May 16.--In the Spring of 1882 William Hamilton, a farmer living in the northern oil field, was induced to invest $3,000 in oil land in the then booming Cherry Grove district in Warren County.

With commendable industry Mr. Royce has ransacked many holes and corners in order to find material for this sketch of Californian history. He acknowledges his obligations to Mr. H.H. Bancroft for permission to consult original documents: he has had access to important official documents in Washington, and many libraries...

LOCKPORT, N.Y., May 16.--Oscar F. Richards, of Akron, Erie County, N.Y., was a member of the One Hundreth Regiment NewYork Volunteers, and lost an eye by a musket ball at the battle of Fair Oaks, for which he was discharged.
PITTSBURG, Penn., May 16.--A fight in which five men were cut, two of them very severely, occurred at the Cliff mine, on the Montour Railroad, Saturday night.

The amended Cantor bill is to come up on its final passage this week, and as the Legislature is to adjourn sine die on Thursday but a very short time remains for putting it in a safe form and sending it to the Governor. In its present shape the bill is a substitute for chapter 65 of the laws of this year, and if it passes,...

DENTON, Texas, May 16.--The examining trial of J.G. Grimmitt on a charge of feloniously assaulting Miss Marietta Batchelor closed here yesterday.

Among the arrivals from Europe by the steamship Etruria yesterday was Dr. Valentine Mott, who spent a week or more with M. Pasteur. Dr. Mott brought with him a memento of his visit to the Paris physician in the shape of a rabbit which was inoculated with rabies' virus on the day he left Paris.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16.--A distressing accident occurred to-day on a farm on the Rancocas road, in Burlington County, N.J. Thomas Azey, a farmer, discovered a flock of crows in his field, and securing a gun he went to a window to shoot at them.

The body of Franklin Rupert Reed, of Grinnell, Iowa, the Yale divinity student, which was found floating at the foot of Gouverneurstreet last Thursday, lies in the undertaking shop of Michael. P. Daly, in East Twenty-sixthstreet, awaiting the arrival of Frederick R. Reed, his brother, from Minneapolis, who telegraphed on Saturday that he would come on at once. No further light has been thrown on the...

The programme offered at Koster Bial's last evening was not remarkable for its novel features, but the favorable influence of the cool weather on theatrical affairs counteracted the effect of the familiar representation, and an audience of unusually large proportions filled the hall.

The House of Representatives has a Committee on Private Land Claims, and in the early days of the session it reported bills confirming several alleged Spanish grants in New-Mexico. The committee assumed that the testimony of the claimants and the surveys and recommendations of surveyors-general were trustworthy.
Felix Brecht, who keeps a saloon at No. 197 East Fourth-street, was arrested last evening for a violation of the excise law.
During the unpleasant weather of the last few days Mr. John Kelly has not been as well as formerly. He has suffered from depression of spirits, and his old complaint, insomnia, troubles him again.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 16.--Montgomery Place, near Barrytown, to which Gen. Montgomery's widow retired after he was killed at Quebec, was entered by professional burglars some time before daylight this morning, and they stole nearly 100 pieces of solid silverware, each marked with the shield of the Livingston cost-of-arms.
The Detroits now lead the Chicago Club by three games in the League race, but they have taken part in 14 games, while the Chicago men have only played 11.
The Third-Avenue Company ran cars on regular Sunday schedule yesterday. Traffic was noticeably light, but Sunday has always been a poor day since fares were reduced on the elevated road.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--The public interest in the talk about the President's marriage is probably as great in Washington as it appears to be everywhere else, but up to this time it has been manifested here with a great deal of deference to the President. There appears to be no doubt that he is to be married, but exactly when, or to whom, is not so clear.

The Rev. T. De Witt Talmage delivered the first of a series of sermons on " The Labor Question" at the Brooklyn Tabernacle yesterday morning. The large congregation present were at times very enthusiatic and repeatedly applauded the speaker. Dr. Talmage took for his text Genesis, 1., 2: "And the earth was without form and void."
OTTAWA, Ontario, May 16.--Foster, Minister of Marine and Fisheries, has given notice of a bill to amend the act respecting fishing by foreign vessels in Canadian waters.

We, the undersigned do hereby, agree to run a match race of one and one-half miles, weight for age, between the ch. g. Tyrant, 4 years old, by Great Tom, dam Moselle, and Volante, 4 years old, by Grinstead, dam Sister Annex, for the sum of $5,000 a side, half forfeit, the latter--$2,500 each--being this day placed in the hands of Mr. Phillip Dwyer.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 16.--There has been considerable speculation as to whether the Auditor of the State would issue vouchers for accounts, based upon the action of the Senate since the ousting of the four Hamilton County members.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16.--Charles S. Wolfe, the independent campaigner, has been in the city within a day or two, and it is now quite certain that he will not decline the nomination of the Prohibitionists for Governor if it should be offered him. That it will be is not doubted by any one acquainted with the political situation.

BOSTON, May 17.--The annual Spring Tennis Tournament of the Harvard Tennis Association began this morning on the courts of the association on Holmes's Field. Both the clay and turf courts were used, the latter being considered more desirable.
BOSTON, May 17.--Writing from Meshed, Persia, April 5, 1885 Thomas Stevens, the tourist, who is traversing the world on a bicycle and is now under arrest in Russia, says:

CHICAGO, Ill., May 17.--A restless spirit prevailed in the southwest lumber region this morning. At 7 o'clock Twenty-second and the intersecting streets were lined with a great crowd of men and boys.

After a five days trial in Part II. of the Court of General Sessions, John Miller was yesterday convicted of obstructing a railway by placing a stone in the slot of the Cable Railway at Tenth-avenue and One Hundred and Thirty-second-street.

Another coachman has secured for his bride the pretty daughter of wealthy parents. This event was all that was talked about in Tarrytown yesterday afternoon when it got noised about, although it was the intention of all the parties concerned to keep it a secret and not let it get into the newspapers.

Miss Mary Anderson was warmly welcomed last night at the Star Theatre, where she began a short series of performances, limited to the current week, to close a prosperous season, during which the popular young actress has worked very hard and ...
Promptly at 6 o'clock last evening roan and chestnut wheelers and leaders, a spanking four-in-hand team, drew the big coach Pioneer up in front of the Hotel Brunswick.

As the two houses at Albany have agreed to adjourn on Thursday there are but three days left for closing up the work of the session.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 17.--E.A. Hayes, counsel for Otto, the condemned buffalo wife murderer, has asked Gov. Hill to grant Otto a reprieve if he could not commute his sentence. The reprieve is asked for on the ground of newly discovered evidence. Mr. Hayes says he will move for a new trial if the ruprieve is granted. The Governor stated that he would give his final decision to-morrow.

BOSTON, May 17.--Col. Roland G. Usher, who was appointed Warden of the State Prison by Gov. Butler in 1883, to-day sent in his resignation to Gov. Robinson, with a request that he be relieved some time this month, or early in June.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 17.--Most of the able-bodied residents of Branford came to this city to-day to attend the trial of Nathan Rose, the Post Office clerk accused of appropriating letters belonging to the Branford Card-Printing Company. Post Office Inspector Hartsborn testified that he traced the trouble to the Branford office, but nothing definitely against Rose was proved, and United States Commissioner Johnson T. Platt discharged the prisoner.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17.--Counsel for the New-Jersey Central Railroad Company to-day filed in the United States Circuit Court that company's plea to the bill of complaint of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17.--A special from Easton, Penn., says: "The mystery surrounding the murder of Edna Bittenbender, near Stroudsburg, Monroe County, in 1889, is about being cleared up. Miss Bittenbender was found dead one morning in October of that year in the corner of a field, with her head crushed in by a stone.
WATERBURY, Conn., May 17.--Mrs. George Root, aged 88 years, committed suicide here at her residence on Field-street this morning.

There was a conflict of statements yesterday as to the number of cars on Third-avenue and the number of drivers in the company's employ, the strikers discounting the company's record by about 40 per cent.

The Magazine of Art for June has for leading illustrations a full-sized woodcut of Constable's "The Hay Wain," "Driving Horses in Hungary," after Heinrich Lang, and "A Lady of Old Germany," from a drawing by Gierminsky.
PHILADELPHIA, May 17.--Examiner Pollock began taking testimony in the Reading foreclosure suit under the general mortgage this afternoon.
EUFAULA, Indian Territory, May 17.--Reports reached here to-day that Deputy United States Marshal Andrews and his posse of three were all mortally wounded by Bill Pigeon while attempting his capture.

The trial last week of the engines and boilers of the Essex was yesterday reported as satisfactory. Commodore Chandler has, therefore, declared the vessel now ready to go into commission the moment her officer are ordered to her.
Commissioner Fink has called the meeting of the trunk line pool Presidents for next Thursday. There is likely to be a lively session.
PHILADELPHIA, May 17.--James Scullion, a veteran of the late war, who lost a limb at Petersburg in 1864, is in Moyamensing Prison on the charge of having killed a man with his wooden leg.

WASHINGTON, May 17.--The President has vetoed the bill to establish a port of delivery at Springfield, Mass. "I have just finished one of the pleasantest railway trips I have ever had," said a promineat merchant as he alighted from the Pennsylvania Limited at Jersey City last evening. "I had no idea," he continued, "that the railroad people had reduced the art of travel to such perfection. A business trip becomes a merry holiday, full of comfort, pleasure, and good cheer.

While rowing in Flushing Bay yesterday morning William Brent, of College Point, discovered the body of a man which had evidently been in the water for some time.
"The Black Crook," as it was given by the Kiralfys at Niblo's lately, is now to be seen at the Grand Opera House, and is worth seeing.

LONDON, May 17.--The Mark-Lane Express, in its weekly review of the British grain trade, says: "The floods and snowstorms during the past week have injured crops. The wheat market has not materially altered. Sellers were firm during the week and millers were apathetic.

WASHINGTON, May 17.--The laboring men of the country will probably assume, from the course of the House this afternoon, that the lower branch of Congress is either making a bid for votes or else that it has a conviction that all labor troubles can and should be settled by legislation.

Judge Wallace, of the United States Circuit Court, has rendered a decision on the motion made in behalf of Menacho Co., shippers, of this city, to restrain Ward's and the Alexandre Steamship Line from making discriminations against the complainants in charging them a higher rate of freight than was charged ...
ST. PAUL, Minn., May 17.--A meeting of the east-bound lines was held to-day for the purpose of equalizing the rate on flour from Minneapolis and St. Paul to seaboard points.

WASHINGTON, May 17.--In the Court of Claims to-day, Judge Davis delivered the opinion of the court in relation to the liability of the Government for the French spoliation claims, in which the Chief-Justice and all the Judges concur.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 17.--Charles J. Noel, his wife, mother, grandmother, young son, and a boarder have all been poisoned by eating greens purchased from a peddler. They were taken early this morning with vomiting and spasms. Dr. Rushmore administered antidotes, and it is thought to-night that they will all recover with the exception of Noel's mother, who has just recovered from a severe illness.
The ladies connected with St. Lawrence parish are trying to raise money by a fair to pay for the completion of the parish chapel, at Parkavenue and Eighty-fourth-street.
Signor Salvini is at the Everett House. Count de Lersundi, of Madrid, is at the New-York Hotel.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 17.--Mrs. Eliza Finn, a widow, and her four sons, all young men, were seriously poisoned at the supper table at their home, No. 145 Johnston-street, Newburg, last night, by eating freely of cheese which evidently contained something of a poisonous nature.

James Collins, a porter in the employ of Aaron Claflin Co., of Church-street, NewYork, was arrested yesterday morning on suspicion of wife murder. Mrs. Mary Collins, whom he married 17 years ago, had been found dead in her bed, at her home on Willow-street, Hoboken, ...

The platform of the Madison-Avenue Congregational Church was crowded with Chinese Sunday school men and boys last night. In front of them sat the new Chinese Consul, in what Dr. Deems termed a blue Mother Hubbard.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 17.--The Hartford police have had knowledge for some time of the blackmailing operations of a notorious woman who has obtained money from several married men on trumped-up charges against them, but no way of punishing her has yet been discovered, because the persons who have suffered by ...

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 17.--D.A. Ross, late manager of Dun's Commercial Agency in this city, has been arrested, charged with embezzling $5,000 of the company's money. It is alleged that he reported no collections on account of hard times, and used the money in speculating. The company, it is understood, refuses to compromise.

NASSAU, New-Providence, May 7.--The pineapple crop is large. Last year's prices will prevail. The first shipment of the season was made from Eleuthera on April 29, when a cargo was forwarded to New-York. The sponge market is dull. There is very little Offering. Prices are high.

Benson's Capcine Plasters cannot be sold for 10 or 15 cents. They cost twice as much, and are worth a dozen times as much as any others, that is why they are so largely imitated by the unscrupulous.--Exchange.

WASHINGTON, May 17.--When the telephone investigating committee met to-day, Manager Marean, of the Western Union Telegraph Company, was placed upon the stand and requested to produce certain telegrams sent and received by Mr. Young and other gentlemen connected with the Pan Electric and National Telephone Companies.

GLEN COVE, Long Island, May 17.--Soon after eating their dinner to-day the family of John Glennon, of this village, was seized with violent symptoms of poisoning, and their condition became so critical that Dr. Henry Watson, who was called in to attend them, at one time thought they would all die.

An explanation of the capsizing of the catboat Ada Late was given late Sunday night. At 11 o'clock Sunday morning six young men between the ages of 22 and 25 years, and evidently Germans, hired the boat at Andrew J. Seeley's boathouse at the foot of Hicks-street, Brooklyn.

The very cool weather of the past week has greatly interfered with the plans and calculations of the fruit and vegetable dealers. But it has added handsomely to the profit of the Florida and Carolina growers.

DETROIT, Mich., May 17.--The third week of the strike opens here with matters still in a very unsettled condition. There have been many indications that the men were giving out, and it was thought this morning would see many of them return to work.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 17.--Business circles were startled this afternoon by a triple assignment, which was filed in the County Clerk's office by the firms of Davis, Trabue Co., wholesale dealers in cotton; Trabue, Davis Co., cotton factors, and Davis, Mallory Co., wholesale dealers in dry goods and notions at Nos. 715 and 717 West Main-street.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 17.--Louis Wiegand, keeper of one of the most notorious "fences" in the West, died here to-day. He was out on bail awaiting trial on an indictment for receiving stolen property, and his trial was to have come up this week.
" Amateur."--Calvin McKey. "Joe" Hornung leads the Boston Club in batting.

MADRID, May 17.--Queen Christina today gave birth to a son. In response to a summons there had assembled at the palace to await the accouchement all the Cabinet Ministers, the foreign diplomatic representatives, the principal civil and military magnates, a deputation of members of the Cortes, and other distinguished persons.
William Gardiner, a farmer of Dutch hills, fell into a very old trap yesterday and paid $250 for a bit of experience he might easily have obtained more cheaply by reading the newspapers.
JAMESTOWN, May 17.--Very many cheese factories in Chautauqua and Cattaraugus Counties are being turned into creameries for the manufacture of butter of a high grade.

CHICAGO, May 17.--The number of bushels of grain in the United States and Canada on May 15 and the decrease compared with the previous week will be posted on 'Change tomorrow as follows: Wheat, 39,590,501; decrease, 2,306,397. Corn, 9,818,193; decrease, 803,708. Oats, 1,456,401; decrease, 166,094, Rye, 317,099; decrease, 53,553. Barley, 417,939; decrease, 124,256. The amount in Chicago elevators is: Wheat, 9,713,878; corn, 2,054,635; oats, 389,174; rye, 81,174; barley, 41,645.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 17--The funeral of Col. S.N. Benjamin took place from St. Philip's Church, Garrison's, this afternoon. The funeral party, numbering 100, arrived at Garrison's at 4:05 from New-York, the principal ...
PHILADELPHIA, May 17.--The cessation of the cutters' strike gives employment to over 15,000 men, women, and girls who have been idle for a week.
