The Bohemians are as bitter as ever over the unsuccessful boycott of. Mrs. Landgraf. They finally persuaded two of her old bakers to lease her, but she succeeded in filling their places with better men. one of whom, Emile Weichband, is inclined to return blow for blow at any interference with his work.

CHICAGO, May 17.--The Grand Jury of the Criminal Court which is to consider the cases of the Anarchist leaders was sworn in to-day. Its personnel is good, and there is no reason to expect any of its members are in sympathy with Anarchist doctrines.

ALBANY, May 17.--Upon the application of Attorney-Gerneral O'Brien, made before Judge Parker, in this city, on Saturday last, John O'Brien, the principal contractor on the New-York Aqueduct and the Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, was appointed Receiver of the Broadway Railroad.

WASHINGTON, May, 17.--The Master Builders' Association held a meeting to-night to discuss the labor difficulty, and unanimously decided to adhere to the proposition made on Saturday to the men, that nine hours should be a day's work, and to make no further concessions.
TROY, N.Y., May 17.--Strenuous efforts are being made by the employes of the other collar factories to induce the laundry girls of the Ide factory to return to work to-morrow morning.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 17.--Dr. Charles F. Spaulding, a rather good-looking, middle-aged resident of Springfield, Ohio, is here to-day searching for his young wife, to whom he was married on the 10th inst. by a local Squire.
Annis Montague Turner sang several times with the troupe of the American Opera Company, Limited. She is now suing the company for $3,800.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 17.--The case of the Central Trust Company of New-York against the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad Company and others came up before Judges Jackson and Key, in the United States Circuit Court to-day.

The Jersey City police concluded, after an investigation in the matter of the death of Victor Colquist, who was found dead, with his dog by his side, on the corner of Sessex and Warren streets, Saturday night, that it was not the result of an accident, and at 1 o'clock yesterday morning they arrested a rough known as Porter Flanagan, on a charge of murder.

WASHINGTON, May 17.--A gift of $800,000 of taxes, earned by the people and by them paid into the Treasury, has been proposed by the Republicans in the Senate, assisted by a few Democrats, and the House of Representatives will be asked to-day by Mr. Blount, of Georgia, to refuse to allow this gratuity to be extended.

LONDON, May 17.--The debate on the Home Rule bill was continued in the House of Commons to-night. Sir Richard Assheton Cross, Conservative, was the first speaker. He said that the bill would not secure a good government for Ireland.

BALTIMORE, May 17.--All the Baltimore theatres this week, excepting Ford's Grand Opera House, have reduced admission to 25 cents for the first floor. The Academy of Music gives the comic opera of the "Drum Major;" the Holliday-Street Theatre produces Audran's "Mascot," and Ford's Grand Opera House has a minstrel attraction. The races commencing Tuesday have brought quite a crowd to the city.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 17.--Fred Reiner Oetiker, a young Bavarian Count, is lying at the point of death in the male medical ward at the City Hospital. He came to this country some years ago, after having inherited a large fortune from an uncle.
Wall-street men are much irritated over the action of the trunk lines in trying to keep back information concerning the amount of east-bound shipments.

In a very businesslike sort of way the Suburban Rapid Transit Railroad--practically an extension of the Second-avenue elevated into the annexed district--opened a section of its road to the public yesterday afternoon.

Mrs. Fannie Wolff, wife of Louis Wolff, a well-to-do cloak manufacturer, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by shooting herself five times in the breast with a revolver at her residence, No. 114 East Fifty-fifth-street. The motive for the suicide, if known to the members of the family, was not disclosed by them.

JOLIET, Ill., May 17.--When John Block, a rich German farmer at Frankfort, 28 miles east of this town, died, several months ago, he left a widow 45 years old and several children. Mrs. Block had by a former husband two adult sons.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 17.--At noon the remaining property of the late American Exposition was sold at auction by the Sheriff on one year's credit at 5 per cent. interest.

Baron Farnborogh, better known as Sir Thomas Erskine May, late Clerk of the House of Commons, died yesterday. He was born in 1815 and entered the public service as Assistant Librarian of the House of Commons in 1831.

PARISH, May 17.--The banns of marriage between Patti and Nicolini have been published. The Comte de Paris and his daughter, Princess Amelie, accompanied by a full suite, started for Lisbon to-day. Princess Amelie is to be married to the Crown Prince of Portugal on May 25.

WASHINGTON, Penn., May 17.--After months of search, Prof. Jonathan Emerick, of William and Mary College, has discovered the aerolite which fell in Washington County Sept. 14, 1885. It was found imbedded deep in the soil on Frederick Miller's farm, two miles north of Claysville. Prof. Emerick says it is the largest aerolite on record, and weighs fully 200 tons. Its composition is chrominium, nickel, aluminium, copper, magnesium, and tin.

Judge Edwin C. Woodruff died at his home in Guilford, Conn., yesterday, after an illness of two weeks. He was born Jan. 25, 1852, and graduated from Yale College in the class of '72. For several years he taught school in Elizabeth, N.J., and New-York City, and finally settled down in Guilford, Conn. In 1881 he was admitted to the Bar.

BALTIMORE, May 18.--The first day of the Spring meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club was not so successful as was anticipated. The weather was threatening, and the result was not such good attendance as usual. The races were all well contested and the fields large. It was a bad day for favorites, and the short horses carried off nearly all the purses.

The Captain has received a telegram from the owners ordering him to bond the vessel and leave, but as there is no Consul at Englishtown he cannot do so.

Harlem people believe in the Fourth of July. They believe in it as an educator in patriotism, and think that in these days when Anarchists are trying to make themselves felt such an educator shouldn't be neglected.

DANBURY, Conn., May 18.--Nellie Banks and Maggie McCoy, the two girls who disappeared last Thursday, have not yet been found or heard from. When last seen they were driving about town in a buggy which they had hired at a livery stable.

Henry N. Jaehne, who, according to Capt. Francis J. Twomoy, the Clerk of the Board of Aldermen, is already an ex-Alderman, passed a quiet day in the Tombs yesterday, seeing only his wife and two of his array of counsel. The ex-Alderman sent his kindest regards to the reporters and declined to see them.

A memorial window, designed and executed by Mr. Frederic Crowninshield, and to be placed in one of the Chicago churches, is now on view in the rooms of the Society of Decorative Art, at No. 28 East Twenty-first-street.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 18.--The friends of Divinity Student F.R. Reed, whose body was found in the East River, are busy discussing his fate. One of them remembers that at the time James T. Holland killed "The" Davis.

For a few minutes yesterday afternoon there seemed a prospect that the close of the first day's session of twentieth Convention of the Episcopal churches of the Diocese of Long Island would be decidedly breezy. The Convention was held in Garden City's magnificent Cathedral of the Incarnation.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 18.--A few days ago William Webber, a prominent machinist and an active advocate of Socialism, returned here from Chicago, where he has been employed for the past year. While in that city he became a member of the Anarchist lodge over which Spies and Parsons presided, and he gives his version of the bomb throwing during the recent riots.
HOOKSETT, N.H., May 18.--A frost was discernible this morning in this and adjacent towns. The extent of the damage done is not yet known.

ORANGEVILLE, Ontario, May 18.--Two more dynamite explosions took place here last night--one at the office and the other at the residence of Police Magistrate Monroe.
MADRID, May 18.--The christening of Queen Christina's son will take place on Friday in the Royal Chapel.

CHICAGO, May 18.--Suit was to-day begun against Mandel Brothers, a big State-street dry goods firm, for violation of the city ordinance compelling shopkeepers to provide seats for their women employes.

Miss Maria Lane Tuck, a young songstrees who, for some unaccountable reason, appears but seldom in the concert room, gave a soiree of music at the residence of Mrs. Frederick Robert, in West Twenty-sixth-street, last night.
PHILADELPHIA, May 18.--The action of the Petroleum Exchange in listing New-York railroad stocks has caused a good deal of rivalry to spring up between the Petroleum and Stock Exchanges.

The destruction by fire of Prince Bismarck's saw mills, at Friedrichsruhe, is an uptoward event, for the damage is estimated at 20,000, and only a small proportion is covered by insurance. The whole of the machinery is destroyed, so that the mills will have to be entirely rebuilt.
TOLEDO, Ohio, May 18.--Developments to-day in the case of Louis Weigand, the notorious "fence" keeper, whose death was chronicled yesterday, show that he died from the results of a wager.

STONEHAM, Mass., May 18.--Miss Carrie Dodge, who recently disappeared and was supposed to have eloped with a gypsy, was found in Medford last night and brought home. She refuses to give any account of her wanderings, but it is believed that she married the gypsy, but repented and left the band.

ALBANY, May 18.--Speaker Husted gave another lift to the New-York City Aldermanic bill to-day. He got 65 members to suspend a rule, so that the bill can be read out of its order. Then he offered a resolution suspending a joint rule, so that the objection will not apply that the bill was introduced after March 15.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18.--Morris Levi, of No. 167 Orchard-street, New-York, was employed as salesman in the cloth house of Benjamin Curran, at No. 88 Ludlow-street.

CINCINNATI, May 18.--The seventh biennial May Festival opened to-night. Of the 4,040 chairs in Music Hall as now arranged something over 3,500 were filled.

BOSTON, Mass., May 18.--A letter to the Herald from Reading, Vt., announces the death of Plymouth White, alias Frank Parke, alias "Plinn" White, the notorious confidence man, at his brother's residence in that town on Sunday night from a carbuncle on his neck at the base of the brain.

The bill providing at once for Spring elections in this city and for the choice of the Aldermen on a general ticket was passed by the Assembly yesterday and by the Senate late last night. It is the one measure of municipal reform which it is now in the power of the Governor to bestow upon this city, and it is one full of promise.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 19.--The second lay of the Spring meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club was much more successful than anticipated. Rain fell heavily all night and up to noon to-day, leaving the track in bad condition. There was, however, a very good attendance. The betting was fairly active, and the favorites were promptly taken by their admirers. The winners of the day were Strathspey, Rock and Rye, Young Luke, Little Minnie, and Bersan.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 19.--The suit of the New-York Central Trust Company against the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad Company and others was decided by Judge Jackson, of the United States Circuit Court, to-day.

Twomey, the Clerk of the Common Council, having misstated the question involved in his false certification of the pay roll of the Board of Aldermen in a letter to Corporation Counsel Lacombe asking for an opinion as to his duty in the premises, Mr. Lacombe yesterday gave an opinion which does not decide the point at issue at all.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 19.--The Harvard Freshmen, in their first championship game of this season, defeated the Yale Freshmen by a score of 11 to 4. Plenty of errors were trade on both sides. Yale led until the fifth inning, when Harvard braced and got 5 runs, and good luck was theirs from that point. Base hits--Harvard, 3 for 4; Yale, 3 for 3. Bingham pitched for Harvard and Watkinson for Yale.

Foxhall Keene had his Waterloo yesterday at Cedarhurst, and was beaten for the first time during the meeting. He was riding Zangbar at the top weight in the Hunter's handicap flat race, and rode him well, but the impost was too great, and, though he managed his horse well, had to haul down his colors to Alex Shields.

READING, Penn., May 19.--A Mr. Bolander was killed on the Reading Railroad near Auburn this morning. He had been walking on the track and stepped out of the way of a down train, but was almost instantly struck by a passenger train on the other track coming from the opposite direction.
CHICAGO, May 19.--There is a shattered gas pool in this city, and the ruin will inure to the benefit of consumers on the west side, who are now paying $1.50 per 1,000 feet for their gas.
Several contributions mere made to electrical literature at the general meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, yesterday, at No. 127 East Twenty-third-street.

WASHINGTON, May 19.--"Shame and dishonor," Mr. Holman reminded the House to-day in the course of the debate on the subsidy amendment to the Post Office Appropriation bill, had been the result of an attempt to put a subsidy through Congress. It was a well timed warning.

LANCASTER, Penn., May 19.--Henry Witmer, a well known quarryman, aged 60 years, was instantly killed yesterday while working in Dr. Brobst's large stone quarry at Lime Rock station on the Reading and Columbia Railroad, about 14 miles from this city. A heavy blast had been fired, when a large piece of rock fell upon Witmer, crushing out his life.
The Alumni of Claverack College and Hudson River Institute have formed a Memorial Association for the purpose of erecting a suitable monument to the memory of the late President, Dr. Alonza Flack.

LONDON, May 19.--Lord Salisbury was received with great enthusiasm when he appeared upon the stage of Her Majesty's Theatre this afternoon to address the Conservative meeting assembled there under the auspices of the Primrose League.

LANCASTER, Penn., May 19.--John Eshbach, a well known farmer of Pequea Township, committed suicide yesterday by hanging himself in his barn. His body was found by the son of a neighbor. He was 55 years old and leaves a widow and family. He had been suffering from melancholia for a long time.

French, and Van Vechten; Mrs. Mansfield Davies and Mrs. Wyilis Pomeroy, Marsball O. Roberts and Mr. Sherwood, and in diplomatic circles Mrs. Henry White, wife of the First secretary of Legation.
CINCINNATI, May 19.--The second of the May festival concerts to-night attracted an audience of about 3,000. The programme embraced Bach's mass in B minor and Schumann's Second Symphony.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., May 19.--The Hon. A. E.Stevenson, First Assistant Postmaster-General, arrived here this afternoon from Hot Springs, where he had taken, Mrs. Stevenson. AKRON, Ohio, May 19.--Mrs. Mary Mooney, a widow, residing about three miles north of this city, retired about 9 o'clock last evening, sleeping in the same room with her five children--Thomas, aged 12; Julia, 10; Nellie, 7; Lawrence, 4, and maggie, 2. Bayard, the classification of cutters, sloops, and yawls was so altered that the second class now includes vessels from 55 feet to 71, and the first class those of 71 feet and over.

President Beekman said he was sorry to disagree with the Commissioner, but he believed that one of the chief uses of the Park was to provide a place where people could go on Sunday and seek innocent and healthy outdoor amusement.

The Aldermanic bill, for whose passage he had paved the way by suspending certain rules, was the special order at noon, and the Speaker, leaving his perch, came down into the well. The Democrats were watching him very closely.

Many of the police who were detailed to reserve duty on Third-avenue have been withdrawn within a few days and yesterday there were officers on only about half the cars.

Several entertaining incidents happened at the second and final session of the Long Island Diocesan Convention of the Episcopal Church, at Garden City, yesterday. A number of delegates to the convention had decided that Bishop Littlejohn's salary should be increased, but without taxing the income of the diocese. When Bishop Littlejohn made his headquarters...

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia May 19.--James Purcell, of Port Mulgrave, once of the best informed men on the fisheries question in the Province, in giving a statement of the position of Canada in the fishery matter, says the Gloucester people are unreasonable.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 19.--The joint discussion between Gen. John B. Gordon and Major A. O. Bacon, candidates for the Governorship of Georgia, which opened at Eatonton on Monday and will continue in the leading towns all the week, has already developed features of strong personality.

VALPARAISO, May 19, via Galveston.-- The newspapers to-day contain sentimental articles to the memory of the late Vice-Admiral Don Patricio Lynch. The flags throughout the city are flying at half mast.

DANVILLE, Va., May 19.--No little excitement was created in this place yesterday by the movements of Mr. Richmond Pearson and his friend, Mr. J.R. Hamilton, from North Carolina. These gentlemen had lately figured in an affair of honor, in which Mr. Pearson and Col. Johnston Jones were principals.

Charles A. Chizzola, who managed Salvini's recent appearances in this country, wants part of the $40,000 that the actor made during the season, and which he carried on board the steamship Alaska on Tuesday along with the wigs, costumes, and other accidents of his calling.

BOSTON, May 19.--The Boston Board of Trade has filed a petition in insolvency. A special meeting of the Directors was held May 11. The President, Mr. L.G. Burnham, was in the chair. The financial condition of the board was considered by all the members present, and its legal aspects presented by counsel.
The new police patrol wagon was completed yesterday and taken to Police Headquarters for inspection. The wagon is a very substantial vehicle.

The fishermen of the New-England coast are naturally impatient that their quarrel is not taken up by the Government, and some of them are reported to have gone so far as to put arms upon their vessels with the intention of defending them from seizure.

Henry Lehr, aged 20 years, shot and killed himself at his home, No. 1,116 First-avenue, yesterday morning. He was suffering from despondency caused by a scolding that his mother had given him for giving away a gold ring which had belonged to his dead brother.

A few days ago E.J. Turner, of Philadelphia, issued a challenge to trot a team, to be named after posting the stakes of $5,000 or $10,000 a side with George Singerly, of the Philadelphia Record, against Sir Mohawk and Nellie Sontag, Richard K. Fox's famous team, now being trained by John Murphy at the Gentlemen's Driving Park in this city.

The postponed race in the 2:50 class at the grounds of the New-York Driving Club was trotted yesterday. The track was still heavy. There were three entries, but S. McMillan's gr. g. Hiram Woodruff was drawn after the second heat, and there was only a close contest between ...

SHERIDAN SHOOK, who is a brewer and an ardent Blaine man, was the most active lobbyist in support of the bill giving the appointment of the Excise Commissioners to President NOONEY, of the Board of Aldermen. As a brewer Mr. SHOOK'S interest in the excise question is no doubt...

DETROIT, Mich., May 20.--During John L. Sullivan's stay in Detroit yesterday, on his way to Mount Clemens, the fact leaked out for the first time that the great slugger has consented to make a trip to Australia and other British...
The Grant Monument Association received $115 89 through the New-York Herald yesterday. The fund amounts to $121,145 24.
CHICAGO, May 20.--James J. Mullarkey, a young bookkeeper out of employment, was found dead in his room at No. 73 North Statestreet to-night.
CHICAGO, May 20.--A bill was filed in the Superior Court to-day by John Boyd against the firm of J.T. Lester Co. containing some charges about Lester Co.'s methods of business.
Cars ran about as usual on Third-avenue yesterday, except they carried a reduced number of policemen in the daylight hours.
The ashes of the biggest bonfire seen in the Murray Hill section of the city in several years lay in Forty-ninth-street, near Madisonavenue, yesterday.

The combination sale of trotting stock was continued at the American Institute Building yesterday, with an increased attendance of horsemen. The attraction was the 19 head of stock consigned by Mr. Robert Bonner, which, however, brought only moderate prices.

ERIE, Penn., May 20.--The controversy between the Pennsylvania Railway Company and the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern at Erie over traffic is taking a new form, and now involves the ownership of a whole square of city property worth nearly $200,000.
OTTAWA, May 20.--In the House of Commons to-day Mr. Foster, Minister of Marine, moved the second reading of the bill respecting fishing by foreign vessels in Canadian waters.

The Anti-Monopoly League met last night, at the Knickerbocker Cottage, and adopted an "address to trades unions, farmers, granges, and all other non-political, illegal, and revolutionary industrial organizations."

St. George's Cricket Ground, at Hoboken, held a large crowd of the friends of the lacrosse teams of Harvard University and Stevens Institute yesterday, who witnessed a game in the college championship series.
For the first time in 20 years the President of the National Board of Fire Underwriters failed to deliver his annual address at the annual meeting of the board yesterday at No. 156 Broadway.

A woman who gave her name as Ader called upon the Newark police yesterday and said that her husband, George Ader, was lying at his home, No. 171 Boyd-street, at the point of death from injuries sustained at the hands of Patrick McKenna, a watchman in Lane Co.'s leather factory.

WASHINGTON, May 20.--The House Committee on Naval Affairs to-day practically completed the Naval Appropriation bill, and will probably be reported to the House to-morrow. The bill appropriates about $11,750,000, while the estimates submitted by the Navy Department contemplated an expenditure of $30,836,857.

John Weathen, a ship calker, of No. 119 West Sixty-seventh-street, was married to a Miss Wolf some time ago, and lately there has been considerable trouble between the couple. It is said that the man treated his wife very badly.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 20.--James Furey, wife, and child, and Miss Alice Mitchell, all of Philadelphia, who arrived here Tuesday, ate some bologna sausage and became quite sick. The child, who was in delicate health died in great agony from congestion. The others are doing well. An examination will be made by the health authorities.

The trouble between the tailor contractors and the United Tailors' Union has not yet been settled, and the contractors complain of extortions practiced upon them by the leaders of the union. The members of the contractors' Executive Committee, who yesterday met at No. 412 Grand-street, said that the men began agitating last January, and ordered strikes in various...

WATERTOWN, N.Y., May 20.--Jere Coughlin, an editor of the Watertown Times, was bitten last night by a dog that was supposed to have been rabid. His injuries are quite se vere. The dog was shot several times, and made a wild run before it was finally dispatched.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, May 20.-- From St. George's Bay, on the west coast of Newfoundland, comes the following extraordinary story: "A French vessel arrived here yesterday from Saint Malo, bound to Port au Choix. She came for the purpose of landing Miss Louise Journeaux, who was picked up...

CHICAGO, May 20.--The representatives of the 340,000 Republicans in the State of Illinois were to-day afforded the spectacle of Brotherin-law "David" Littler thrusting his knife under the ribs of the Governor of this State, and twisting it around until his distinguished relative squirmed.
ST. PAUL, Minn., May 20.--The Grand Jury of Ramsey County has submitted a special report on the tax title frauds perpetrated in this county.

Jay Gould's steam yacht Atalanta was moored alongside the Atlas Steamship Company's pier, at the foot of Twenty-fifth-street, before 9 o'clock yesterday morning, to receive the members of the American Yacht Club for the first of a series of excursions which are to be given by the club this season.

DIGBY, Nova Scotia, May 20.--The vessel reported as flying the English flag over that of the United States was the A. Horton, Capt. Joseph Snow. She was returning here after an absence of six weeks, and the Captain wished to display his colors, as is customary on such occasions.

Among the passengers who arrived at this port on the Great Western Line steamer Warwick recently were seven British lads, from 13 to 15 years of age, whose passage had been paid in England and who were on their way to ...
There was great disorder and almost riot in North Tarrytown Wednesday night, which lasted until almost daylight yesterday morning.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 20.--Col. John B. Folsom, grandfather of Miss Frankie Folsom, whom it is said President Cleveland is to marry, died yesterday at Folsomdale, Erie County. He had been an invalid for several years.

BOSTON, May 20.--There has been some excitement, along the water front over the report that a fishing schooner had been arming in this harbor. It is reported that the schooner Augusta Herrick, Capt. William E. Herrick, left New-York four days ago on a fishing trip to the Bay of Fundy.

CINNCINNATI, May 20.--There were two May festival concerts to-day. At the matinee there were three thousand people present. The programme was varied and possessed some notable features. Bram's part songs for women's voices, Op. 17, were sung by a choir of 200 sopranos and 130 altos with most pleasing effect.

ALBANY, May 20.--The closing hours of the session of the Legislature of 1886 were uneventful. The more important bills had been disposed of earlier in the week, and what business remained for the last day was chiefly of a routine nature.

The champion St. Louis players paid their first visit to Staten Island yesterday, and won a game from the Metropolitan team. For six innings the scores were even, and the large number of persons present witnessed a very pretty exhibition. In the seventh inning the visitors made a rally at the bat and settled all doubts as to the game.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 20.--In its weekly review of flour production the Northwestern Miller to-morrow will say: Nearly the full active milling capacity is now in operation, only four mills--none of which have run steadily for a long time--being idle.
Arthur Quartley, the well known artist, died at his home, No. 52 South Washingtonsquare, on Wednesday morning. Mr. Quartley had been sick for a year, suffering from liver trouble.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 20.--The President and Fellows of Yale College, generally known as the Corporation, held the most important meeting to-day that has taken place for years. President Porter's resignation was to be acted upon, his successor chosen, and a number of new Professors and instructors were to be appointed. The meeting was a very long one and was interesting from beginning to end.

William H. Brooks, steward on board the tug Catalpa, lying at the Navy Yard, mysteriously disappeared yesterday morning. He arose early to attend to his work, and it was not until some time after that he was missed.

LONDON, May 20.--The House of Commons this evening, after a heated debate, rejected, by a vote of 210 to 169, the Dundalk Gas bill, as elaborated by a committee which consisted of four English members. The bill increased the powers of a private gas company, ...

The sales at Mrs. Landgraf's bakery yesterday amounted to $3. A man handed her $1 and asked her to send bread to some poor family. Carl Joseph Groeller, of No. 213 East Fourteenth-street, gave her $5 for bread to be...

PITTSBURG, May 20.--A romance full of real life was unfolded at the city poor farm today. The principal actors were a mother and daughter who had not met for so many years that the daughter, now a young woman, had no remembrance of her mother's features.

The announcement of the passage of the bill appointing two additional Police Inspectors for Brooklyn caused much speculation in that city yesterday in regard to the Captains likely to step into the new positions.
BALTIMORE, May 20.--Despite the weather there was a far better attendance at the Pimlico Course to-day than on either of the preceding days.
No uneasiness is felt at the navy yard because the United States steamer Nipsic, which left Montevideo on March 7 for this port, has not arrived. It can hardly be said that she is overdue.
Mr. Joseph Murphy will present the two popular plays of his list, "Kerry Gow" and "Shaun Rue," at the Windsor Theatre next week.
CHICAGO, May 20.--In the case of the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company against the Galesburg Water Company Judge Blodgett has entered a decree of foreclosure and sale.
PHILADELPHIA, May 20.--The team of English gentlemen which is to visit these shores next Autumn is being rapidly organized by Edward J. Sanders, who took charge of the former team.

CHICAGO, May 20.--Within the last day or two the price of beer in this city has been reduced 10 per cent. This action was decided upon at a meeting of the Brewers' Association held on Monday, the object being, it is understood, to freeze out the 10 little brewers who don't belong to the association clean out of the business.

CHICAGO, May 20.--The Grand Lodge Ancient Free and Accepted Masons of Illinois is in a quarrel with the Grand Lodge of England for intervening between the latter and her sister of Quebec over a question of territorial jurisdiction.

There was a meeting of the Catholic Bishops of the Province of New-York yesterday at Archbishop Corrigan's residence, to take counsel regarding the enforcement of the decrees and enactments of the Third Plenary Council of Baltimore.

CATANIA, Sicily, May 20.--The eruption of Mount Etna is increasing in proportions and there is serious danger to the town of MonteRosso from the flow of lava. Measures are being taken for the rescue of the inhabitants. Vast columns of flame are issuing from the crater of the volcano and present a most imposing spectacle.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 20.--The wedding of Miss Anna Laura, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tunis S. Quackenbush, and Mr. John Smith, of the Newburg Bleaching Company, occurred last evening at the residence of the bride's parents, No. 200 Montgomery-street, Newburg.
PHILADELPHIA, May 20.--The Beech Creek, Clearfield and Southwestern Railroad Company will be sold under foreclosure on June 4 and reorganized within 30 days thereafter.

At a meeting of the New-York Yacht Club last night it was decided that the rendezvous for the annual cruise should be at NewLondon Aug. 4. J. Frederick Tams moved that the resolution forbidding the carrying of club topsails on the cruise be rescinded.

CHICAGO, May 20.--The Cook County Grand Jury which is pursuing the investigation of the Haymarket Anarchists began its session about 11 o'clock to-day. At that time there were a dozen witnesses on hand. Some of them were mere boys, and one of the crowd had his arm in a sling on account of a bullet hole through his wrist. When asked his name he said he did not know.

CHICAGO, May 20.--Central Station detectives have made a capture which they think will prove quite an important one. The prisoner is a slight, good-looking, intelligent fellow, about 32 years of age, named Julius Frankel, a native of Posen, Prussia, and has been in this country a number of years.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 20.--The track today was good for the first and second races. The attendance was large and the weather warm. A very heavy rain commenced immediately after the second race and continued all the afternoon. Following were the events:

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 20.-- According to the reports of the 600 correspondents of the Illinois State Board of Agriculture, the Illinois corn crop of 1885, of 230,922,298 bushels, exceeded the average crop of the State for 10 years by more than 3,000,000 bushels.

Wall-street's chief subject for comment and discussion yesterday was the quarterly report of the New-York Central Railroad Company. WILMINGTON, Del., May 20.--The yacht Priscilla left the Harlan Hollingsworth Company's yards shortly before noon in tow for New-Castle, where she will spread her sails and adjust her compass preparatory to sailing thence to-morrow for New-York.
The New-Brighton Tennis Club will give a kirmess at the German Club Rooms, Stapleton, Staten Island, on Thursday and Friday evenings of next week.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 20.--The return of the Democratic Senators who have been camping on Kentucky and Tennessee soil during the past 15 days was not sufficient cause to create much enthusiasm among the brethren.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 20.--In the Battell Chapel to-day the graduating exercises of the Yale Theological Seminary were held, Prof. George E. Day presiding.
CHICAGO, May 20.--The Central Passenger Committee has concluded to wind up its affairs and amalgamate with the Passenger Department of the Central Traffic Association.

BOSTON, May 20.--An appraisal of the estate of the late Henry P. Kidder, as presented to the Probate Court, shows a total of $2,180,624, of which $1,961,224 is in personal and $219,400 in real estate.

WASHINGTON, May 20.--The Administration is not idle about the fisheries dispute that is now causing so much excitement at Portland and elsewhere in the East. As the settlement of the respective rights of American and Canadian vessels is a matter primarily for diplomatic consideration, it is not one about...

DENVER, Col., May 20.--James Whitney, a street car driver, while turning his cars at the end of the Broadway line at 10:30 o'clock last night, was shot through the heart and instantly killed by some unknown person.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 20.--Francis M. Taylor, Probate Judge of Winston County, was impeached in the Supreme Court of Alabama yesterday.

A frightful accident, caused by a runaway in Central Park shortly after 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon resulted in the instant death of Mrs. Alice Pendleton, wife of ex-Senator George H. Pendleton, United States Minister of Germany, and the serious though not fatal injury of Miss Jane Frances Pendleton, their 22-year old daughter.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 20.--As the Maxwell case proceeds the interest in the prisoner and his probable fate increases.
A correspondent is indignant at my recent statement that the only reference made by Lord Beaconsfield to the primrose was in connection with a salad.

Leonard Grover, Jr., Frank E. Lamb, both actors, and Walter L. Sinn, one of the managers of the Brooklyn Park Theatre, became engaged in a wrangle with two cabmen in front of the theatre on Fulton-street, early yesterday...
The marriage of the Hon. John D. Long and Miss Agnes Peirce, late teacher in the High School at Hingham, will occur at the Universalist Church in Attleborough on Saturday next.

LONDON, May 20.--At the Queen's "drawing room" to-day the costly costumes worn by the American ladies present attracted general attention, and the artistic beauty of the various designs elicited unbounded admiration.

BOSTON, May 20.--Representative Samuel Roads, Jr., of Marblehead, has laid before the Committee of Federal Relations of the General Court the following resolutions, which he asks them to report in response to the order presented by him and referred to the committee by the House:
ELMIRA, N.Y., May 20.--Robert Stanley, a young man from Detroit, Mich., was arrested at an early hour this morning for breaking open a lockup last night and releasing a companion.
NEW-ORLEANS, May 20.--Returns from the city portion of the Second Congressional District elect Nathaniel D. Wallace to Congress for the short term, vice Michael Hahn deceased.

The Phi Beta Kappa Alumni of Columbia College met last night at Clark's, in Twentythird-street, to elect officers for the ensuing year, to dine, and to hear Prof. J.S. Newberry read a paper on "The Industrial Arts as Factors in Modern History."

Black Horse and his squaw continued to make Castle Garden their headquarters yesterday. During the morning Black Horse called at the Quartermaster's Department, in Houstonstreet, and says he was told to call again this morning and receive his passes for Dakota.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 20.--Charles Ford, a Middletown colored man, for an assault upon several women at that place last night, was today sentenced by Police Justice Bradner to an imprisonment of five months in the Albany Penitentiary.

BOSTON, May 20.--Vice-President Potter, of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Road, is in Boston for the purpose of conferring with the Directors here relative to the termination of his official connection with the corporation to accept the Presidency of the Cleveland, Columbus, Cincinnati and Indianapolis Road, made vacant by the recent death of Mr. Devereux.

A most important meeting of the Presidents of the railroads in the trunk line pool and the Central Traffic Association is to be held at Commissioner Fink's office to-day. Rates on east-bound freights from Chicago are in a terribly demoralized condition owing to the competition both by the lakes and canal by the part...

GREENFIELD, Mass., May 20.--A tragedy occurred in the quiet village of Deerfield last night by which the home of a once respected farmer is broken up. Eugene Taylor has for 15 years been a hard-working farmer at Deerfield, ...
PHILADELPHIA, May 20.--The second day's proceedings of the Convention of the Catholic Young Men's National Union began in the foyer of the Academy at 10:30 o'clock this morning.
The Caledonian Club, of New-York, visited the club of Newark last night and was given a reception at Saenger Hall.
HAVANA, May 15.--At 7:30 o'clock on the evening of the 10th inst. the sky was illumined by an aerolite of extraordinary magnitude.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20.--It is now stated that the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company will not turn over its New-York traffic to the Wilmington and Northern, at Wilmington, to be shipped via Birdsborough to New-York over the Reading.

ALBANY, May 20.--The Legislature having amended the code so as to remove the restriction on women practicing in the courts, the General Term of the Supreme Court to-day admitted Miss Kate Stoneman, of this city to the Bar. She is the first female lawyer in New-York State.
Nine years and ten months in the State prison for a New-York Alderman--that bids fair to be the gratifying and wholesome result of the case of JAEHNE.

For eight and a half innings the Brooklyn and Pittsburg clubs played yesterday without scoring a solitary run, but in the ninth the visitors made the single one that entitled them to the game. It was purely a pitcher's game, in which Morris, the lefthanded twirler of the Pittsburg nine, excelled.
CHICAGO, May 20.--United States Marshal Marsh served notices to-day on a number of Board of Trade firms, sued for sums aggregating $150,000, among them McFarland Co. and Logan Co.

BOSTON, May 20.--A former case, similar in every important respect to that of the David J. Adams and in many respects to that of the Ella M. Doughty, was that of the Gloucester schooner White Fawn, seized in 1870 on the NewBrunswick coast for buying bait at Head Harbor.

If the record of the Legislature which has just adjourned is not wholly discreditable it is because it has been lashed by public opinion into doing a few good things and deterred by the same force from doing some of the worst that were proposed to it.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 20.--Sight drafts on New-York, 15; telegraphic, 20.

AUGUSTA, Ga., May 20.--In opposing the election of the Rev. J.H. Bryson to be Moderator of the Presbyterian General Assembly, Dr. Flinn, of Alabama, declared that Dr. Bryson had not kept his own house in order and could not be expected to keep the Assembly in good form.

CINCINNATI May 20.--Pains were taken by THE TIMES'S correspondent to-day to ascertain the extent of the feeling which has suddenly developed in Covington, Ky., against returning John G. Carlisle to Congress.

All the chairs and benches in the Court of Oyer and Terminer were occupied at 9:30 o'clock yesterday morning, the seats in the jury box being filled by spectators. Several of the jurors who convicted ex-Alderman Henry W. Jaehne of receiving a bribe of $20,000 for his vote upon...

BERLIN, May 20.--The Reichstag has adopted the bill fixing the duty on beet root sugar at 1 mark 70 pfennigs per 200 pounds and the bounty on exports at 2 marks, until Oct. 31, 1886; 18 marks from Nov. 1, 1886, to Nov. 30, 1887, and 17 marks thereafter.

WASHINGTON, May 20.--The House of Representatives made an admirable record for itself to-day. It voted to reject the Senate's proposed gift of $800,000 to American steamship companies, and the majority against the subsidy was so overwhelming that the Senate, supposed to be deaf to all sounds made...

It was announced in Wall-street yesterday that the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul had just made a contract with a big syndicate, including August Belmont Co., N.M. Rothschild Sons, of London; Kuhn, Loeb Co., and Speyer Co., for the sale of $6,000,000 of Chicago and Pacific, Western Division 5 Per cent. bonds, which are to be issued to provide funds for the construction of the Kansas City and Sioux City extensions.

BOSTON, May 20.--Gen. Butler appeared in the Supreme Judicial Court to-day as counsel for Robert B. Brigham vs. Frances G. Brigham. The case was a cross-libel, but at the last moment the wife, who charged adultery generally, announced through her counsel that she withdrew from the contest. The court thereupon ordered the libel of Frances to be dismissed.

The passage of the Aldermanic bill coupled with a clause providing for Spring elections in this city, was hailed with general approval by the citizens of New-York yesterday. Cot. With the advent of warm weather come thoughts of Summer resorts, and people naturally begin to ask each other, "Where are you going this Summer?" The spell of unseasonable heat which came in the latter part of last month created an unusually active demand for Summer accommodations.

SCRANTON, Penn., May 20.--The Glendale coal breaker, situated about a mile from this city, was struck by lightning during a storm this afternoon and totally destroyed. Loss, $35,000; insurance, $10,000. The property belonged to the Pennsylvania Anthracite Coal Company, and was operated by the Glendale Company under a lease.
Mr. Charles Pope, the St. Louis manager, is in the city engaging a company to support him in a starring tour which he will begin next Fall.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21.--R.D. Wood Co. are among the leading iron manufacturers in Pennsylvania, and have extensive mills in New-Jersey. One of the firm's employes at Millville, N.J., said to-day: "The foundries of R. D. Wood Co., of this city, are likely to remain idle all Summer."

BATH, Me., May 21.--The Republican caucus last night chose delegates to the State and District Conventions, and instructed them to vote for J.R. Bodwell for Governor and Nelson Dingley, Jr., for Congressman.

CHICAGO, May 21.--The Inter Ocean's Knoxville, Tenn., special says: "This morning Samuel Johnson, his wife, daughter, Willis Hall, and two negroes left home, a few miles below this city, for Lenoirs on a boatload of grain and produce. There was a swift current. The boat struck a rock within 20 feet of the bank, and all but Johnson were drowned. No bodies have yet been recovered."
DUBLIN, May 21.--Bank of Ireland stock has fallen to 259. BERLIN, May 21.--Emperor William today attended the Spring parade of the Guards. He is in robust health.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 21.--The following additional candidates have passes their examination for admission to the Naval Academy H.W. Raus, New-York; A.S. Thompson, Wisconsin; M.T. Coleman, New-York; H.J. Ziegeman, Ohio; Z.W. Reynolds, Pennsylvania; F.H. Schofield, New-York; M.M. Taylor, at large; C. G. Ward, New-York.

The Coroner's jury in the case of Mrs. Collins, who was found dead in bed at her home, No. 88 Willow-avenue, Hoboken, last Monday, rendered a verdict last night. Death is attributed to violence at the hands of her husband, John Collins.

TROY, N.Y., May 21.--There is no change in the collar factory lock-out. The knights of Labor are preparing a schedule of wages to be demanded, which will be submitted when the employers finish their schedule.

DOVER, N.H., May 21.--Daniel Hemenway, a messenger between Farmington and Dover for Meserve Co.'s express, who disappeared Jan. 2, 1885, leaving a shortage of $1,200, was arrested in bed in Watertown early this morning and taken to Farmington for a hearing. Hemenway admits his guilt, and says he bet the amount of the shortage on Blaine's election, thinking he was sure to win.
Robbins's circus have performances in Mount Vernon Thursday afternoon and evening.
BOSTON, Mass., May 21.--The demand for Wool has been moderate during the past week and prices remain without improvement.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 21.--The Hon. William Purcell has accepted the position of member of the State Board of Arbitrators.

LONDON, May 21.--In Mincing-lane sugar is full, but is declining; cane is inactive; refined is slow of sale. Prices of Ceylon coffee at the auction sales were firm; Costa Rico and Guatemala are steady. China tea is quiet; Indian is firm. Rice is slow of sale. Cocoa is quiet. Cloves are firm. Pepper is unaltered.
WASHINGTON, May 21, 1886. The House bill providing for closing the busi ness of the Court of Alabama Claims was passed by the Senate to-day without amendment.

CHICAGO, May 21.--General Freight Agent Spriggs, of the Nickel Plate Road, gives notice to agents and connections that, in compliance with the request of the trunk lines, his company will refuse to accept freight from connections if the point of origin and final destination of the freight is not shown on the way bills.

The census of the German Empire taken last December--the official returns of which have just been published--establishes the fact that the preponderance of the female over the male sex is increasing in Prussia.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 21.--The weather was warm to-day, the track slow, and the attendance very good. The following is a summary of the racing:

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 21.--The Government has received the official report from Capt. Scott, of the Lansdowne, of the seizure of the Adams. It confirms in every respect previous advices received by telegraph.
PHILADELPHIA, May 21.--Isaac Rodgers, the former clerk of the First National Bank of Chester, who pleaded guilty to embezzling $27,000 during a period of time extending from ...

The Yale Alumni Association met last evening at the University Club Theatre for the last time before the Summer vacation. President Chauncey M. Depew was in the chair. A resolution expressing the sorrow of the Alumni at the death of Prof. Thacher was adopted.

When Patrolman Connery brought Jamey Burns as a prisoner into the Mercer-street police station last evening his hat was dented and dusty, his uniform coat was torn, and his arms and body were bruised and sore.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 21.--Dr. Sargent, the Chairman of the Athletic Committee and Director of the Hemenway Gymnasium, crippled the prospects of the Harvard Freshmen nine by announcing, this morning, that Hurley, first baseman, and McClellan, third ...

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 21.--Particulars of a crime committed in Lawrence County, this State, a few days ago, reached here to-day. A lady, whose name is witheld, of high standing in the county, gave the alarm that her stepson, 7 years old, had fallen into the well.

ATHENS, May 21.--M. Tricoupis has formed a new Ministry. He assumes provisionally the offices of Minister of War and Minister of Finance. The other Ministers are: M. Lombardos, Minister of the Interior; M. Voulpiotos, Minister of Justice; M. Manetas, Minister of Public Instruction; M. Theokotis, Minister of Marine; M. Dragumis, Minister of Foreign Affairs.

CHICAGO, May 21.--A special dispatch published here this morning asserts that the citizens of Eastern Montana are greatly excited over the proposed action of the Secretary of the Interior in extending the Cheyenne Indian Reservation to Tongue River.

DETROIT, Mich., May 21.--There is a war among the lumbermen of Isabella County over running logs in the Chippewa River. Recently Judge Hart, of that county, granted an injunction forbidding Leaton Upton from obstructing navigation at Pares Brothers' dam at Mount Pleasant, which prevented the running of 50,000,000 feet of logs.
At the Office of Indian Affairs of the United States Government, at No. 67 Woosterstreet, yesterday, the contracts for beef for the year--July, 1886, to July, 1887--were awarded.

WASHINGTON, May 21.--To-morrow will be a field day in the telephone investigation and in the executive session. The Pan Electric Committee will discuss the affidavit of Zenas F. Wilber, handed to the Chairman this afternoon by Casey Young.
The anniversary exercises of the Hebrew Free School Association will take place on Sunday morning in Temple Emanu-el, Forty-thirdstreet and Fifth-avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21.--Another good day's sport was afforded the 1,000 persons in attendance at the trotting races at Point Breeze Park to-day. In the 2:22 class Merry Thought and J.J. Douglass were the favorites before the race, but after seven well contested heats Dick Organ secured the victory.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 21.--Drafts on New-York, sight, 15; drafts on New-York, telegraphic, 30.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 21.--About 80 of the Knights of Labor, coal miners, delegates to the National Convention from Pennsylvania, Ohio, Illinois, Missouri, Virginia, West Virginia, Maryland, and Indian Territory, held their first session yesterday and effected a temporary organization.
RUTLAND, Vt., May 21.--Last Winter W. J. Pieper, claiming to be a well-to-do Philadelphian, and a woman who passed as his wife, came here and engaged board with a widow, Mrs. Bagley.
CHICAGO, May 21.--A creditor's bill was filed in the Superior Court by Mrs. Emma H. Jeffrey, yesterday, on her judgment for $10,753 against the John B. Jeffrey Printing Company.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 21.--Much excitement exists in this city over an open letter to the Common Council published by the Gazette this afternoon charging the Mayor, H.S. Deforest, with appropriating money belonging to the city.

The parade of the Coaching Club, which is to take place to-day, promises to be an interesting spectacle. The meet will be on the West Drive of the Central Park, at Seventy-secondstreet, at 5 P.M. The first operation will be what is called the "move manoeuvre."

A movement has been on foot for some time past among the stove, house furnishing, crockery, and hardware dealers of the west side to close their stores at 7 o'clock every evening except Saturday during June, July, and August.

The report submitted by M. ROUSSEAU, the engineer sent to the Panama isthmus by the French Government, is a very severe blow to the great enterprise which M. DE LESSEPS and his associates have undertaken to carry to completion.

The Metropolitans made a desperate effort to lower the colors of the champion St. Louis Club at Staten Island yesterday, but were unsuccessful, the visitors winning by a score of 3 to 1. Clever work marked the contest from start to finish, and it was only after a hard struggle that the champions won. Caruthers, who pitched for the St. Louis team, was ...
The general sentiment througout the country seems to be one of the thankfulness that the recent Anarchist troubles occured in a city able to take care of itself.
District Attorney Martine and his assistants, De Lancy Nicoll and Col. John R. Fellows, was yesterday disposed to feel content with the laurels won in the Jaehne case.
LONDON, May 21.--The steamship Vancouver, (Br.,) Capt. Lindall, from Montreal May 10 and Quebec 12th for Liverpool, passed Moville today. Arr. to-day, Kennon.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 21.--In the case of John B.F. Davis, of Harrodsburg, Ky., against the New-Jersey Mutual Benefit Association, the Circuit Court jury has decided in favor of the plaintif. Davis was insane and was found dead in his stable.
The June Harper is an able, instructive and inspiring number. The opening paper, on "The United States Navy," is by Rear-Admiral Edward Simpson.

LONDON, May 21.--The remarkable manifesto issued to the Black Sea fleet by the Czar produced a temporary feeling of panic in all the European Bourses, but this feeling was soon removed by the subsequent promulgation of the peaceful views of the new Government of Greece.
The Rockaway Steeplechase Association is to close its meeting to-day. The programme of six races promises some exciting sport, as will be seen by the entries:
PARIS, May 21.--M. de Lesseps, being questioned on the subject of M. Rousseau's adverse report on the Panama Canal, said that M. Rousseau naturally took a pessimistic view; ...

BURLINGTON, Vt., May 21.--An emergency meeting of the Trustees of the Vermont University last evening, after a heated debate lasting six hours, voted to request the resignation of Dr. L.M. Bingham, the Professor of Surgery for whose dismissal the students struck. Dr. Bingham has not yet complied with the request.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 21.--There are significant movements afoot in connection with the projected bridging of the Hudson at Storm King and Breakneck Mountains.

Up to last night no arrangements had been made for Mrs. Pendleton's funeral. The body was lying at the house of her son, Frank Key Pendleton, at No. 105 East Thirty-fifthstreet, and it was said that nothing would be determined on until this morning.

The eighty-first Commencement of Bowdoin College, Brunswick, Me., falls in the week beginning June 20. The main features of the programme for the week are: Sunday, Baccalaureate sermon by the President.

The Atlantic prints a paper on Miss Whitney's statue of Lief Erikson which, to artists and other persons interested in art, has a news value as well as a critical value. Henry Van Brunt is the author of it.

CHICAGO, May 21.--An attachment suit for $125,000 was begun to-day by D.K. Tenney Trustee, against Loyal L. Smith, of Detroit, on a judgment note dated Detroit, May 10, 1886. A writ of execution was issued and returned "no property found."

For nearly four hours, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, Col. Robert G. Ingersoll talked energetically to a jury about the Western Union Telegraph Company, which he described as a gigantic monopoly making use of violent means to keep competitors out of its field, or to expel them from it.

Coroner Messemer yesterday took the ante-mortem statement of John Wheaton, a ship caulker, who was stabbed by his brotherin-law, Lewis Wolf, in a tailor's shop at No. 405 West Forty-second-street, at 9 o'clock Thursday evening. Wheaton stated that he had not seen Wolf in several months, and declared that the stabbing was entirely unprovoked.

The representation of "As You Like It" at the star Theatre last evening attracted the largest audience we remember to have seen in that house. The band was put under the stage and every foot of floor space was crowded.

ST. LOUIS, May 21.--The interest in the Maxwell case continues undiminished, and at the opening of the proceedings this morning the crowd of curious spectators exceeded that in attendance on any previous day.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 21.--The returns from the Second Congressional District, nearly complete, show that Wallace (Dem.) has a plurality ever Martin (Rep.) or 3,296 and a majority over both Martin and Flagg of 2,084. The official returns will not materially change these figures.
The usual circular issued by that National Academy of Design in relation to the Autumn exhibition of 1886 has been sent forth, and a summary of its contents is worth reprinting.

While cleaning house yesterday morning Mrs. Agnes Becker, of No. 32 Eldert-street, Brooklyn, discovered in a closet in her room a box containing two pistols. She took one out and pulled the trigger three times, but no explosion followed.

Ex-Supervisor Daniel W. Wilkes, of Brooklyn, was tossed out of bed early yesterday morning by an explosion which rained upon his head a shower of plaster and shook the panes of glass in houses three blocks away.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 21.--Upon application of C.W. Fairbanks, as counsel for the bondholders of the St. Louis Central Railroad Company, the United States Circuit Court today entered a decree for the sale of the railroad and the property of the company. The sale will take place the latter part of June.
Steamship Elder, (Ger.,) Hellmers, Bremen May 11, via Southampton 13th, with mdse. and passengers to Delrichs Co.

FORT WORTH, Texas, May 21.--Deputy United States Marshall Ben Cable, just in from Wilbarger County, and W.H. Garretton, from the Panhandle, report terrific prairie fires raging, sweeping everything before them.
Miss Dora Valesca Becker, a youthful violinist, whose earliest public performances, last season were interesting through their promise, gave a concert at Chickering Hall yesterday evening.

HAVANA, May 21.--As the period of mourning for the death of King Alfonso has not yet passed the celebration here in honor of the birth of the heir to the throne of Spain will consist only of the singing of the Te Deum in the cathedral next Sunday.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 21.--The bark St. Olaves, of St. John, loaded with deals, for Great Britain, went ashore last night in a storm on the Isle of St. Paul, taking off part of her keel and rudder.

Ex-Alderman Henry W. Jaehne tried to sleep last night on a cot in a cell in the State prison at Sing Sing, and was one of the 1,185 convicts who were presumed to be at rest in that cheerless institution.
Through the exertions of Mr. Guy Wyatt, of the Georgetown Cricket Club of Demerara, the visit to this country and Canada this season of a team of West Indian cricketers is now assured.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 21.--A sensation has been caused here by the publication of a translation of an article that appeared Sunday in Das Volksblatt, Robert Schilling's labor paper. It was translated for the purpose of being placed before the Grand Jury.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 21.--A Grand Folks special to the Pioneer Press says: "In the Summer of 1882 the body of a man named McKenzie was found in the stall of a vicious stallion with the top of his head eaten off and the stall spattered with blood.

CHICAGO, May 21.--A well known dressed man, about 25 years of age, who gave his name as James J. Mullarky, and claimed to be from Cleveland, Ohio, rented a room at No. 73 North State-street, last Monday.

Frank Hankinson is doing fine work at the bat for the Mets, at present. Poorman, an old Metropolitan player, is doing good work for the Bostons. Havard and Princeton will play a championship game at Princeton to-day.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 21.--At one o'clock to-day Andrew J. Wiggin, 30 years old, a bricklayer, and his wife, who is 25 years old and very pretty, were walking toward the corset shop in Dwight-street, where Mrs. Wiggin was employed.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 21.--In the Presbyterian General Assembly at Minneapolis, this morning, the Moderator announced the standing committees. The Chairmen are all ministers but three, as follows: Bills and Overtures--Elijah R. Craven, D.D. Newark, ...

DANBURY, Conn., May 21.--The police last night received word that Nellie Banks and Maggie McCoy, the missing girls for whom search has been going on for 10 days, were to be found at the house of a friend in Brookfield.

If there be any proposition upon which the decent citizens of this State, and especially of this city, are agreed, it is that the course of the Legislature that has just adjourned was discreditable and injurious to the Commonwealth.
The Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn will hold their first annual games to-day on the ground corner of Ninth-avenue and Ninthstreet. Twelve events will be supplemented with a football match.
BERLIN, May 21.--In the Reichstag today Herr Hasenclever questioned the Government regarding Minister Von Puttkamer's decree in reference to the conduct of the police in labor strikes.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 21.--Particulars of a tragedy which occurred in Lawrence County, Tuesday last, have just been learned.
The Mansion House Committee on the proposed improvements in St. Paul's Churchyard yesterday decided to abandon further proceedings in the matter.

Johann Most, the Anarchist, sat on the topmost bench in Part II, of the Court of General Sessions, from 11 o'clock yesterday morning until 2 o'clock in the afternoon, waiting for his counsel to make an argument on the demurrer to the indictment upon which he was arraigned before Recorder Smyth a few days ago.

LONDON, May 21.--Mr. Justin McCarthy resumed the debate on the Home Rule bill in the House of Commons this evening. He said that the prospects of home rule had brightened recently, thanks to Lord Salisbury's revival of the cry of "No Popery."
A Park policeman was somewhat shocked yesterday to find a man swimming in the lake in the upper part of Central Park. The man's clothing lay on the bank.
Lieut.-Col. Charles Heywood, United States Marine Corps. will command the marines, and Lieut.-Commander W.T. Burwell, United States Navy, the blue jackets participating in the Decoration Day parade.
Gen. A.R. Lawton, of Georgia, is at the New-York Hotel. Prof. O.C. Marsh, of Yale College, is at the Buckingham Hotel.

It was announced yesterday that John R. Smith, Treasurer of the Board of Domestic Missions of the Reformed Church in the United States, had appropriated over $25,000 of the moneys of the board to his own use.

WASHINGTON, May 21--Second Lieut. Charles L. Steele, Eighteenth Infantry, has been granted six months leave of absence for disability, with permis sion to go beyond the sea. First Lieut. D.L. Craft, sixth Infantry, has been granted live months' leave of absence.

One of the old-fashioned discussions took place yesterday at the special meeting of the Commissioners of Emigration yesterday, which was to take action as to the final disposition of the eight boys who landed at Castle Garden April 27.
Sixteen Italian and German musicians were arraigned in the Essex Market Court yesterday for obstructing the sidewalk in Fourthstreet, near Second-avenue.

PITTSBURG, May 21.--A Commercial Gazette special from Fayette City, Penn., says: "Seven Mormon missionaries from Utah began a series of proselyting meetings at the Valley Schoolhouse, in Washington Township, one mile south of this place, last Sunday.

ALBANY, May 21.--The Legislature has left in Gov. Hill's hands about 325 bills. The Governor has 30 days in which to dispose of them. His time expires June 19. Such of these as he does not sign in this period fail to became laws.

CINCINNATI, May 21.--The May festival programme to-night, embracing Beethoven's Third Symphony, one of Gluck's recitations, sung by Mme. Hastreiter, and the "Tower of Babel," by Rubinstein, was splendidly rendered.

CHICAGO, May 21.--Indictments for conspiracy to murder and inciting to riot were informally decided upon this evening by the Grand Jury in the cases against August Spies, Sam Fielden, and A.R. Parsons, the Anarchists.

BOSTON, May 21.--An information has been filed in the United States Circuit Court by the District Attorney against the schooner Spring Bird, asking for her forfeiture and sale to pay the fines and penalties imposed upon her master, John Gomez, who is charged with bringing more passengers in the schooner from the Cape de Verde Islands than is allowed by law.

WASHINGTON, May 21.--Attorney-General Garland, Dr. Rogers and his son, and Messrs. Van Benthuysen, Sypher, and Casey Young were in attendance when the telephone investigation committee met today. The Attorney-General was the first witness. His attention was called to Mr. Von Briesen's testimony, and he said there were two or three mistakes in Von Brieson's account of his interview at the Department of Justice.

Another truce is promised in rate cutting on east-bound freights in the agreement of the Chicago and Atlantic and the Wabash Railroads to join the Central Traffic Association for the purpose of restoring rates to conform to the association and trunk line schedules.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 21.--Little Annie Miller, aged 14 years, of Sayreville, a little village five miles from this place, has developed symptoms of hydrophobia. The girl was bitten it is supposed, a week ago by a dog which ran a large at that time, and which it is feared had the rabies.

PORTLAND, Me., May 21.--Gov. Robie was seen this morning. He said: "Maine, with 600 fishing vessels, large and small, is vitally interested in this discussion. The rights of the fishermen will be protected.
BALTIMORE, May 21.--The fourth and last day of the Spring meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club was decidedly the best of the meeting. The weather was bright and the attendance was by far the largest.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 21.--Car No. 3 of the United States Fish Commission reached this city from Washington early this morning, and today was hauled over the New-Haven and Derby Railroad to Birmingham, where its cargo, 980,000 baby shad, was placed in the Housatonic River above the big dam at that point.

The Hudson County (N.J.) authorities have begun suit to recover from Jersey City large amounts of arrearages which the county claims to be due. Judge Knapp granted a writ yesterday requiring the city officials to show cause why a peremptory mandamus should not issue.

Property owners on the line of the proposed Arcade Underground Railway have issued the following call for a meeting, the objects and purposes of which the widely distributed circular fully sets forth:

PHILADELPHIA, May 21.--Thomas H. Byrnes, Secretary of the Catholic Young Men's National Union, announces the reception of a cable dispatch from the Pope granting the members of the union the Apostolic benediction.

DETROIT, Mich., May 21.--The strike is rapidly drawing to a close. Two hundred more Michigan Car Works men went back to work this morning. The shops are running in all departments but not quite full-handed.

The Prohibition Party Association, of the Twenty-fourth Assembly District, held a public meeting last evening at Temperance Hall, Willis-avenue and One Hundred and Fortyfifth-street. Edward J. Wheeler, editor of the Voice, denounced the Republican Party in this State as having repeatedly broken its anteelection pledges.
Recorder Smyth imposed sentences upon a number of persons in Part II. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, May 21.-- Capt. Davies, of the brigantine Latimer, at this port, reports passing a large bark named Gloire abandoned.

A large attendance of Jerry McAuley friends is expected this afternoon at the unveiling of the public drinking fountain erected to his memory at Sixth-avenue and Thirty-secondstreet.

Mrs. Landgraf's little bakery has an entirely changed appearance. The dingy decorations of tissue paper tacked to the ceiling have all been torn down, and with the assistance of a professional decorator and fresh tissue paper of all hues the ceiling has been covered with strange devices that make it look like a badly broken up rainbow.

WASHINGTON, May 21.--The House Committee on the Judiciary to-day instructed Chairman Tucker to report favorably an amendment to the Constitution declaring polygamy unlawful. CHARLESTON, S.C., May 21.--There are heavy freshets throughout Upper Carolina. The Peedee River stands 36 feet above low water, and is still rising. The crops on the river are a total loss. The loss is beyond estimate. Much damage has been done to railroads and crops in the northern and western parts of the State.

Justice Brown, in the Supreme Court, in Brooklyn, yesterday adjudged Margaret Wood to be insane and appointed G.S. Young a committee of her person and estate, the latter of which, it is said, has dwindled from $25,000 to $1,400.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 21.--Twice within three months has this city been the scene of a hanging, the victims on both occasions being wife-murderers. Peter Louis Otto on the morning of Nov. 14, 1884, deliberately shot and killed his wife.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 21.--Col. John B. Folsom, of Folsomdale, N.Y., the grandfather of Miss Frankie Folsom, who, it is said, is to marry President Cleveland soon, died at his home Wednesday afternoon. He was born in Warsaw, N.Y., Jan. 27, 1811.

GREENFIELD, Mass., May 21.--The inquest on the body of George Taylor, the child who was poisoned by its father Wednesday night at Deerfield, disclosed a quantity of strychnine in the stomach, and the medical examiner will render a verdict that the child came to its death from the effect of strychnine administered by its father, Eugene Taylor.

Among her boarders was Gustave Fischer, a coach painter. About last Christmas Fischer got out of work, and Mrs. Dinninger let him stay for some weeks on trust.
A Western editor was thunderstruck when told that monthly magazines sometimes paid as high as $1,000 for a single article.
Wall-street has been indebted to the Chicago men for some activity in the market the latter part of the week. It was dull enough in the first half.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 22.--"Three cents a quart for May mill, and the freight to come out of that price," said a prominent farmer in a tone of deep disgust, referring to the monthly price list just issued by the New-York Milk Exchange.

Special orders No. 36 from General Headquarters of the State National Guard at Albany, dated May 21, was received at Headquarters First Division yesterday. It announced the acceptance of Major-Gen. Stealer's resignation and his full and honorable discharge from the State military service.

PARIS, May 3.--A fortnight ago no one save the readers of the Liberte up to 1883, the subscribers to the Monde since then, and his own personal friends knew that there was such an individual as M. Drumont in existence.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 22.--The yacht Priscilla, which has been lying at New-Castle since Thursday adjusting her compass and canvas, sailed for New-York at 4:35 o'clock this morning. A. Cass Canfield, her owner, is on board.

TUCSON, Arizona, May 22.--A Mexican vaquero who has just arrived here reports that Indians this morning attached Juan Teller's Mountain Springs ranch, 18 miles southeast of Tucson, and carried off two Mexican boys, aged 110 and 12 years.

A shocking accident occurred at Lachine on Tuesday evening. The barge W.H. Lewis was nearing the new dock, when, as is usual, a rope was thrown out and attached to the "snubbing" post on the wharf.
MILWAUKEE, May 22.--The sessions of the Grand Jury already held have resulted in two important arrests.

WASHINGTON, May 22.--The President today informed the counsel for Antonio Nardello, sentenced to be hanged for the murder of Carmine Rotunno, that, after a careful examination of all the facts that have been presented to him in the matter, he is constrained to deny the application for commutation of the death sentence of Nardello to imprisonment for life, and that he finds no sufficient reason for further interference with the course of the law.
Mr. Matthew Arnold will be in this city during the first week in June. He sails for NewYork to-morrow, and will spend but a few days in that city before coming here.

OTTAWA, May 22.--The total value of the imports into the Dominion during April, exclusive of British Columbia, was $6,704,832, on which the customs duties amounted to $1,207,483. The total value of the exports for the same month was $3,648,042. Both the exports and imports, with the exception of a few items, show an increase over those of April, 1885.

The company was organized Jan. 25, 1882, and obtained an ordinance from the city authorizing it to lay pipes, , in the streets of Chicago.

It is a curious fact that when Lord Redesdale succeeded his father in 1830 he was unable to take his seat in the House of Lords for several months, as the certificate of his baptism could not be found, the ceremony having taken place in the house and no legal record having been preserved. The late Lord Chesterfield was kept out of the House for nearly two years through a similar difficulty.

BUFFALO, May 23.--It is stated, on the authority of a Lackawanna official, that that company, in the furtherance of its policy to centralize all its repair work, will before long build large shops for they work at East Buffalo. Heretofore all of the heavy car repairs have been made at Scranton and Kingston, but the necessity of a large car shop at this end of the road has daily become more imperative.

DANBURY, Conn., May 23.--Mrs. Curtis C. Hoyt, of White-street, aged 41, died late yesterday afternoon, after a long and painful illness, during which she suffered from 18 large abscesses. Her sufferings became so intense on Friday that she took an overdose of morphine. Every effort was made to save her life, but she remained unconscious until her death.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 23.--Prof. Brooks, of Phelps, N.Y., discovered still another comet last evening in right ascension, (as determined at Warner Observatory this evening at 10 o'clock,) 11h. 51m. 15s., declination north 8 55'15". It is large but faint, with a slow motion southeast. This discovery secures to Prof. Brooks the first, second, and third Warner prizes of the year.

The trouble among the tailors came to a head yesterday morning, when over 600 members of the United Boss Tailors' Union locked out their operators, numbering in all 5,500. Demands had been made by the journeymen for a change from task work to a uniform ten-hour day, with eight hours on Friday.

When Alfred L. Burgess was broght before Justice Welds, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, to answer a charge of felonious assault preferred by his wife, Mary Ellen Burgess, the details of a conspiracy alleged to have existed between the husband and his wife's sister to murder the wife by poison were partially disclosed. Burgess is a tall, strapping fellow, about 25 years of age, and is employed as a steam fitter.

At 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning Archbishop Corrigan administered the sacrament of confirmation in the Church of the Holy Name of Jesus, at Broadway and West Ninetyseventh-street, to 170 persons. At 4:30 o'clock the Archbishop was received by about 30 Little Sisters of the Poor, at the entrance to their new Home for the Aged, on One Hundred and Sixth-street, near Ninth-avenue.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 23.--This afternoon the horses attached to the vehicle containing Fred Weise and his three daughters became frightened and ran away, and all were thrown violently out. Weise, who is a carpenter, was instantly killed, his head striking a stone. Katie, his daughter, had three ribs broken. The others escaped with painful bruises.

The Detroit Baseball Club maintains its lead in the League contest, and at present is two games ahead of the Chicago team. By winning four of the five games played in Kansas City and St. Louis, the New-Yorks have bettered their condition, and are now third.

An industrious, if somewhat eccentric, gentleman at Berlin has succeeded, after many years' patient labor, in amassing no fewer than 1,000 heels from various kinds of boots and shoes worn by ladies and gentlemen more or less eminent.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 23.--Although the Lansdowne, the flagship of Admiral Scott, of the Canadian Navy, is steaming around the coast and dropping in unexpectedly to the various harbors where American fishermen would likely go to procure bait, up to the present no further seizures of Yankee schooners have been reported.

QUEENSTOWN, May 23.--The Aurania, Capt. Haines, which sailed from New-York on Saturday, May 15, with My. Daly's company of artists on board, arrived here at midnight last night. The passage was a remarkably pleasant one, and everybody was delighted with the trip. Mr. Daly's company are all well and express themselves as having enjoyed the voyage thoroughly.

Mr. P.T. Barnum never lacks amusement when the United States mail service is in working order. Unfathomable are its depths of entertainment for him, but the venerable Yankee showman in a big-hearted way gives over most of the regular joy of it to a hard-shell private secretary. A letter came along the other day, however, that prompted him to a decided personal interest.

NORFOLK, Va., May 23.--While Mrs. Peter Hanlan was kindling a fire with kerosene oil this morning the can expolded, throwing the burning oil all over her body. She was nearly burned to a crisp and died from her injuries to-night.

Many a workingman sat beside the citizen of wealth in the pews of All Soul's Church, in west Forty-eighth-street, yesterday, listening to the second sermon of the Rev. R. Heber Newton's series on the present aspects of the labor problem. "Capital's View of the Situation" was the preacher's theme.

John Robinson, who claims to be the champion amateur swimmer of the Mersey, Wales, and the Isle of Man, England, swam across the Hudson River yesterday, from Nyack to Tarrytown, for a purse of $500 against time, the bet being that he could not cover the distance, about three and a half miles, in one hour and 45 minutes.
About 25 years ago, when one of the diplomats came to this country he brought a man cook with him, and this cook, by the buying of land in Northwest Washington, got a very comfortable competency.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 23.--Walnut Mountain, near Liberty, Sullivan County, and the highest of all the lofty bills in that county, has been purchased by W.T. Holmes, of Ellenville. He intends to build a large hotel on the summit of the mountain, from which the country for a hundred miles around is brought beneath the eye.

NEW-HAVEN, May 23.--John Collins, a resident of Oak-street, got up early this morning to attend to some business affairs. He seemed to be unusually slow in dressing, and when the other occupants of the house heard the noise of a heavy fall they rushed into his room to find Collins lying dead upon the floor. Heart disease ended his life and he dropped dead just as he was drawing on one of his socks.
The Yacht Priscilla, which sailed from New-Castle at 4:35 Saturday morning for NewYork, arrived at 7:45 last evening and anchored off Stapleton.
