ROME, May 23.--Father Masella, of the Austro-German College, will be made a Cardinal at the next consistory.

Mrs. Eva Braun, of No. 625 East Sixteenth-street, was awakened at midnight on Saturday by the groans of her husband, Louis Braun. He was lying prostrate, face downward, on the floor of the bedroom with his throat cut from ear to ear.

The sixth annual Spring regatta of the Yorkville Yacht Club was sailed yesterday over an 18-mile course, from the clubhouse, at the foot of One Hundred and Fourth-street, to the Stepping Stones Lighthouse and return. The weather was not by any means favorable for yachting.

HARRISBURG, Penn., May 23.--A fight which may result fatally to at least one of the participants occurred at the Cumberland Valley Railroad station in this city early this morning. Henry Bender, of this city, met Truman Ormsbee, of Philadelphia, in a disreputable house, where they got into a quarrel.

Murtha as a compliment to the Annie Pixley and Joseph Murphy combinations, and the tickets had been distributed among the theatrical profession with a generous hand.
THE TIMES had nothing to say about its trip, but its Sunday edition was the most complete newspaper that reached Rochester that day.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 23.--William Alexander, for eight years the assorting mail clerk of the Post Office here, was arrested by Inspector Brown, of St. Louis, this morning, charged with robbing the mails. For a long time complaints have been made to the office here about lost packages, money, , but nothing came of it until Inspector Brown way sent for and detected Alexander through decoy money packages.

ERIE, Penn., May 23.--Active trouble began between the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern and the Pennsylvania Company, which operates the Erie and Pittsburg Railroad, this morning, and at this hour matters are in an extremely critical shape and a riot is greatly feared.

PARIS, May 23.--The French Derby was run to-day and resulted in a dead heat between Comte Berteux ch.c. Upas and Baron Schicker's b.c. Sycomore. C.J. Lefevre's ch.f. Fils d'Artois was third.

SUNBURY, Penn., May 23.--During a heavy thunderstorm this evening the house of a man named Shipe, about two miles from this place, was struck by lightning. Two children were injured, one quite seriously.

RICHBURG, N.Y., May 23.--James G. Baine and Stephen B. Elkins have purchased a 500-acre tract of land in Forward Township, Allegheny County, Penn., on the great natural gas belt. The Hon. R.E. Carfull, of this place, has charge of their interests, and it is thought that a company, to develop the territory is being formed.

CHICAGO, May 23.--Strauss's pretty opera "The Queen's Lace Handkerchief" has been the attraction at the Columbia Theatre during the past week, and the performance has been up to the high standard of all the McCaull Opera Company's presentations.

TORONTO, Ontario, May 23.--The Mail printing office was damaged by fire Saturday night to the extent of $80,000. Flames were first observed issuing from the windows on the second floor, which is occupied by Alexander Cable, lithographers, and the fire quickly spread to the editorial and composing rooms above.

A mass meeting of anti-Anarchical Bohemians at No. 533 Fifth-street to denounce the actions of the Chicago riotors and to express regret that several Bohemians had been engaged in the riots nearly culminated in a riot yesterday afternoon through the efforts of a number of Anarchists, who had packed the hall and tried to capture the meeting or to break it up by creating disturbance.

Mr. Horstmann made an excellent Consul, was always ready in his official capacity to assist the American traveler, and, what is more, he knows exactly how to write an exceedingly amusing book. During 16 years at Munich and Nuremberg our Consul kept notes of what was "important, peculiar, or humorous," and he gives them in his budget.

CHICAGO, May 23.--To-day some small boys were playing ball on Robey-street, near the old Chicago and Pacific, or Bloomingdale track, when the ball went into a gutter and under the sidewalk.
It has been decided that the funeral of Mrs. George H. Pendleton will take place at 11 A.M. to-morrow from Zion Church, at Madisonavenue and Thirty-eighth-street.

ALBANY, May 23.--Gov. Hill will give a hearing to the advocates of Spring elections and of a method of electing Aldermen in New-York City that will insure a better class of public officers, and then it is believed he will decline to sign their bill.
The Sunday school children of Brooklyn will have their parade on Wednesday under the auspices ol the Brooklyn Sunday School Union. Fifty-five thousand children wlll take part.

LONDON, May 23.--The betting on the Derby, which is to be run on Wednesday, is nine to four in favor of the Duke of Westminster's colt Ormonde. Only twice during the last half century has a Derby favorite started with similar odds. Sporting circles concur in the belief that it will be a one-horse Derby, and that nothing can touch the favorite.

HAVERHILL, Mass., May 23.--As Harry W. Moody a shoe cutter was catching in an amateur game of baseball yesterday his skull was fractured by a stray ball. His recovery is doubtful.

BOSTON, May 23.--Gen. Butler intends fitting out the America, and everything that can be done to improve her will be done. If she does not sail as fast as any other American yacht it will not be the fault of her owner.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 23.--The officers of the General Assembly of the Knights of Labor were up early this morning and at work. The two tardy members of the Executive Board had not arrived, and no session was held. The headquarters work was several days behind and Secretary Turner and his stenographer, who arrived from Philadelphia early in the day, were kept busy answering letters.

Col. D. Wyatt Aiken, Representative in Congress from the Third District of South Carolina, who is now in his fifth term, will not be a candidate for re-election in the approaching election.

TOMBSTONE, Arizona, May 23.--Capt. Lawton's command, who are now pursuing the Indians, have found and buried the bodies of six Mexicans and one American on the trail taken by the fleeing Apaches in Sonora.

On the Stock Exchange business was stagnant, dealings being confined to foreign stocks. American railroad securities were depressed early in the week, but there was a notable rise and active buying after Thursday, prices at the close being the highest of the week.

The fruit growers of Norfolk and Lower Maryland have been greatly discouraged so far this year. Since the berry season began there has been an unusually heavy fall of rain all over Lower Maryland and the strawberry producing section of Virginia, and for a week or ten days--until Friday last--there was continuous cloudy weather.

COTULLA, Texas, May 23.--George W. Crenshaw and two of his neighbors left Cotulla this morning for their ranches, situated about nine miles south of the town. They were on horseback. When about half way the party met Alexander Irving, a young man well connected and an old acquaintance of Crenshaw.

Anna Tromniur, an 18-year-old German servant girl employed in the family of Morris Sancier, at No. 165 East One Hundred and Seventh-street, disappeared at 7 o'clock yesterday morning with little Eva Sancier and a quantity of clothing.
The House Committee on Public Lands has authorized Mr. PAYSON, of Illinois, to make a favorable report upon his bill to prevent aliens from holding large tracts of land taken from the public domain.

HOUSTON, Texas, May 23.--In a street altercation here last night James Ravell shot and killed George Metcalf. The men had gone outside of a saloon to settle a dispute with their fists, when Ravell drew a revolver and fired five shots. Metcalf was unarmed. During the excitement caused by the shooting Ravell escaped.

The body of the Temple Emanu-El, at Fifth-avenue and Forty-third-street, was filled yesterday morning with the pupils and teachers of the Hebrew Free School Association, about 2,000 in all, and parents crowded the galleries and stood on tiptoe to see their children trip up on the platform and show how far advanced then were in oratory.

It was at once made known to us that the doctor had already formed his plans. Fearing the disquiet of Liverpool at the time of a royal visit, he would leave the town at once and go on to a certain quiet and rare old city, about which all the delightful American authors of his school have charmingly written.
TRENTON, N.J., May 23.--The new game laws have all been approved by the Governor. The penalty for violation is $15 for each bird of animal shot or found in possession.

In the Church of Our Saviour, Fiftyseventh-street, near Eighth-avenue, yesterday morning, the Rev. Joseph K. Mason, the Pastor, took for the subject of his sermon "Pay what Thou Owest on a Church in Danger." This is the Universalist church whose pulpit was filled for a long time by the Rev. Dr. Brooks and afterward by the Rev. Dr. James M. Pullman.

As the meeting of the American Jockey Club begins to-morrow, turfmen hereabout are on the qui vive in anticipation of a series of brilliant events. Yesterday the park never looked better, so far as the surroundings were concerned. The track was "as well as could be expected under the circumstances," and, it may be added, a great deal better.

At 11:30 o'clock yesterday morning the proprietor of Mentges's Hall, at Eighty-seventhstreet and Fourth-avenue, where the Third-avenue strikers hold out, heard a noise on the floor above the barroom, and on going up stairs found that a door into the upper hall from the top of a flight of outside steps had been forced.
EL PASO, Texas, May 23.--As a result of the Denver Railroad convention, the General Agents of the different trunk lines centring at this point will be removed.
CHICAGO, May 23.--Last night was what may be termed the first outbreak at Cummings owing to the labor question, and, although no bloodshed occurred, serious trouble is anticipated.

When James White, of No. 400 East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street, climbed to the platform of the Third-avenue elevated railroad station at Fiftty-third-street at 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning he was so tired that he could not stand up.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 23.--The proximity of Sam Small and Sam Janes, the evangelist declaimers against the wickedness of dancing, has not had any appreciable effect on the attendance at the Naval Academy hops. The participants at the naval cadets' hop last night were unusually numerous, and the proportion of pretty girls was exceptionally large. Two Baltimore beauties, the Misses Moale, ...

BUFFALO, May 24.--The work of the arbitrators in the civil suits between the Thames and Mersey and Union Insurance Companies and the Insurance Company of the State of Pennsylvania against the Continental was finished here on Saturday.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 24.--Each delegate to the General Assembly of the Knights of Labor is supposed to represent 1,000 Knights, or a fraction of that number. Frederick Turner, Secretary and member of the General Executive...

There was a gathering of the Republican clans of the Thirteenth Assembly District last night in Grand Opera House Hall. It was one of the fullest meetings of the committee ever held, and the cause of the unwonted interest was the contest for the chairmanship of...
Recently Thomas Smyth, a Belgian dealer in works of art, imported 21 oil paintings, which he valued at $250, and they were placed in the public stores awaiting clearance.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 24.--The town of Southington, 20 miles north of this city, is greatly excited over what is believed to be a case of attempted murder by the use of poison.

TORONTO, Ontario, May 24.--The Queen's birthday was observed throughout the Dominion as a general holiday. At Halifax, Toronto, and Montreal the troops who were in the Northwest last year during the half-breed insurrection were presented with medals.
HARTFORD, Conn., May 24.--The question of building a bridge over the Asylum-street railroad crossing, in this city, has been agitated in the City Council and Legislature for the past three years.
The funeral of Mrs. George H. Pendleton will take place at 11 o'clock this morning from Zion Church, Madison-avenue and Thirtyeighth-street. There will be no pall bearers.

WASHINGTON, May 24.--Chairman Boyle, of the telephone investigating committee, to-day received the following communication from Prof. Alexander Graham Bell in answer to the recently published affidavit of Mr. Wilber, but as the latter had not been accepted as evidence Prof. Bell's affidavit was also rejected:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 24.--Dr. Lewis Swift says of the comet discovered by Prof. Brooks on Saturday night: "As this is not an expected comet, unless it is Olbor's comet of 1815, which is expected about this time, Prof. Brooks is entitled to another Warner comet prize of $100.

Eva Sancier, 5 years old, the daughter of Morris Sancier, who was abducted from her home, No. 165 East One Hundred and Seventhstreet, on Sunday, by the servant, Annie Weitz, was restored to her parents by the police yesterday ...

Fewer Pastors than usual attended the regular meeting of the Baptist Pastors yesterday morning, at No. 9 Murray-street. Prof. Lincoln, of the Baptist Theological Seminary at Newton, Mass., read an essay on "Tendencies of Baptists." Baptist Pastors in some quarters, Prof. Lincoln thought, were deteriorating.

ST. LOUIS, May 24.--The most sensational of all the sensational incidents of the Maxwell trial occurred to-day when the prosecution put on the stand J.F. McCullough, a detective who had been made Maxwell's jail companion shortly after the prisoner arrived here from Auckland, ...
Claus Boesch, a German immigrant, arrived in New-York about six weeks ago, and a day or two after his arrival he was sent, as a lunatic, to the asylum at Ward's Island.

George Ripley, an individual who keeps a saloon at Forty-first-street and Seventh-avenue, is in trouble. He got fighting drunk last night, and then, with a self-cocking revolver in his hand, sallied forth on a miscellaneous raid.
WASHINGTON, May 24.--The President to-day sent the following veto messages to the Senate:

CHICAGO, May 24.--The production of "Lohengrin" by the American Opera Company this evening signalized what will undoubtedly prove a remarkable and successful season of opera. McVicker's beautiful theatre held fully 2,000 people, representing the music-loving, fashionable society of Chicago.
Money was loaning on the Stock Exchange yesterday afternoon at from 2 to 3 per cent, when suddenly in rushed a broker, who began to bid anxiously for $10,000.

An old-fashioned single wicket match was played on the parade ground, Prospect Park, yesterday. The contestants were James Walsh, of the Manhattan Cricket Club, and John Young, a player from Nottingham, England.

J. Randolph Heiser, of this city, and Harvey McKenna, of San Francisco, began a match game of balk line billiards, 2,000 points up, at Maurice Daly's rooms, on Washington-street, Brooklyn, last evening.
The bright and genial weather of Sunday last tempted thousands of people into the parks, the vacant up-town places, and to the invigorating shores of Coney Island.

MOUNT PLEASANT, Penn., May 24.--Intelligence has just been received here of a heartreading accident which happened yesterday morning to three children of Michael Feehan, a miner residing at Moyer's Works, south of this place.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 24.--Sight drafts on New-York, 15; telegraphic, 20.

HALIFAX, May 24.--The Legislature has refused to approve of the convention between England and France respecting the Newfoundland fishery difficulty, British Commissioner Pennell failing to induce Newfoundland to agree to the arrangement. The treaty is still being considered by a joint committee and a delegation will probably be sent to England to get the treaty amended. All parties in the colony are bitterly opposed to it in its existing form.
Jeff Chandler, of Washington; is at the St. James Hotel.

ATHENS, May 24.--At noon to-day all was quiet on the frontier. The Greeks accuse the Turks of capturing Contra by treachery. They say that while a Turkish officer, with a flag of truce, was parleying with the Greek commander Turkish troops stealthily surrounded and captured two Greek companies.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24.--Fire broke out this afternoon at Rarrison's chemical works, Thirty-sixth-street and Grays Ferry road, and the largest building of the works was completely destroyed. At the time the fire broke out there were about 100 men at work on the five...

PORTLAND, Me., May 24.--There is great excitement here. This morning Capt. Jesse Ellis entered at the Custom House his schooner Sisters from Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, with a cargo of 20,000 mackerel taken last Wednesday, and consigned by W.A. Kellain, of Yarmouth, ...
"Yes," said an official who is deeply interested in the prosecution of the boodle men, yesterday. "we would like very much to see Billy Moloney in this city within the next few days."

OMAHA, Neb., May 24.--New interest has been added to the Loyal L. Smith dry goods failure by the filing of affidavits of Smith and his associates in the case of Halman Lowey of Chicago, who purchased the stock of dry goods ...

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 24.--Rose Wintersmith, widow of John Wintersmith, late Assistant Doorkeeper of the House of Representatives at Washington, has filed suit in the Common Pleas Court against Richard C. Wintersmith for the recovery of certain property.

Charles Frederick Woerishoffer made almost as short a will as is possible. As has been stated in THE TIMES the estate is left to relatives and the will is dated May 18, 1874. He gives $10,000 to his sister. Antonia Ammon, wife of Otto Ammon, of Constanz, Germany.

Last November a woman calling herself Matilda Clifton went to live in a dive at No. 4 Roosevelt-street called the Vermont House. Yesterday, at her own request, she was committed to the House of the Good Shepherd by Justice...
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 24.--The Yale students held their annual wake in honor of the extinct Sophomore societies this evening, and turned out in unusual numbers.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., May 24.--News came from Murryville, on the extension of the Ohio River Railroad, at a late hour to-night, that a riot of serious proportions had taken place there among Italian workingmen, in which one man was killed, two fatally wounded, and a dozen more badly hurt. The outbreak was occasioned by a too free use of whisky. All sorts of weapons--stones, clubs, knives, picks, and revolvers --were used by the drunken Italians.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24.--James H. Lambert, who has been closely identified with the Times for ten years, and for the past five years its managing editor, will sever his connection with that journal about June 1 to accept a position as editorial writer on the Press. Mr. Lambert is a well known writer on State and national politics.
Ex-Alderman Arthur J. McQuade, one of the luckless boodle men now under the cloud of an indictment, attended the Church of the Immaculate Conception, in East ...

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 24.--A great sensation was created at Audenried, a town eight miles south of this city, this morning, by the announcement that Miss Rose Hopkins, the highly accomplished daughter of Richard Hopkins, the General Superintendent of the Audenried Coal Company, had eloped with a common Italian railroad laborer employed on the new Schuylkill branch.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., May 24.--John Russell, an employe in the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad shops in this city, while temporarily insane attemped to kill his wife and child early this morning by cutting their throats.

For a week or two past the employes of the various street car lines of the city, who have been regularly assessed in order to provide funds to carry on the Third-avenue strike, have shown a good deal of impatience because the strikers have apparently accomplished nothing, while the company has gone ahead and manned its cars.
Timothy O'Leary, 42 years old, a trackwalker on the Third-avenue elevated railway, fell from the structure at Twenty-eighth-street yesterday afternoon and was fatally injured.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., May 24.--Extremes met a few days ago in the manner in which a cow belonging to Joseph Westley met her death. Her horns grew out in front and the points nearly met. In attempting to scratch her ear with her hind hoof she caught it in the loop formed by the horns, and in the struggle to release it broke her neck.
BOSTON, May 24.--At the annual meeting of the Boston, Concord and Montreal Road today E.H. Rollins was chosen President and an entire Board of Directors was elected, except one man.
Ex-President Arthur is again practically confined to his bed, and his friends believe that his rides taken on Tuesday, Wednesday, and Saturday of last week did him more harm than good.
Town Clerk W.J. Bennett, of NewLots, began a suit for $5,000 damages against exJustice William Watson, of that town, for assault, in the Supreme Court, in Brooklyn, yesterday.
The hearing in the Morris-Fish reference, before Hamilton Cole, yesterday morning, was taken up entirely with the examination of George E. Spencer, who was cashier of the firm of Grant Ward.

The anniversaries of the National Missionary Societies connected with the Baptist denomination in this country will be held this year at Asbury Park, N.J., beginning this afternoon, when the first services of the annual meeting of the American Baptist Missionary Union will be held.

Mrs. Mary J. Page was arrested at No. 36 President-street, Brooklyn, a month ago for drunkenness, but on the intercession of James A. Newry Justice Massey sent her to the House of the Good Shepherd for six months.

MILWAUKEE, May 24.--The fourth floor of a West Water-street block, occupied by the Brunswick-Balke Billiard Table Company, gave way to-day, carrying in with it the floors below. Property in the way of finished billiard tables, tables in the course of construction, machinery, , will probably aggregate a loss of $10,000. The loss on the building is $5,000.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 24.--The Scranton Convocation of the Episcopal Church assembled here this evening. There were about 70 delegates present.

Alfred L. Burgess, who is in the Jefferson Market Jail, charged by his wife with attempting to poison her, has engaged ex-Assemblyman F.B. House to defend him, and, by the latter's advice, refuses to talk about his case.
PITTSBURG, May 24.--There was another panic at the Petroleum Exchange to-day, but when the smoke cleared away it was found that no person was scorched, unlike the big break of last week.

SLATER, Mo., May 24.--A freight train on the Chicago and Alton Railroad, while approaching this city yesterday morning, dashed into a drove of cattle, killing three of them. Their carcasses threw the engine off the track and derailed 10 cars. The fireman, P. Monday, was instantly killed, and Engineer Love and Brakeman Kueger were seriously injured.

DETROIT, Mich., May 24.--The Michigan State University Rugby Association had a field day at Ann Arbor Saturday, which turned out a notable event in amateur sports. In several of the events the best amateur records of the world were beaten. F.N. Bonine, the famous runner, distinguished himself as the champion record breaker of the day.
LANCASTER, Penn., May 24.--In the Republican primaries held in this county on Saturday the only contests of note were for the State Senatorship of the northern district and the District Attorneyship.

LONDON, May 24.--The Mark-Lane Express, in its review of the British grain trade during the past week, says: "The moisture of the weather has immensely improved the prospects of the Spring crops. The wheat trade is weaker.
PITTSBURG, May 24.--Such a scarcity of miners is reported on the Monongahela River that less than one-third of the mines between McKeesport and Brownsville are in full operation.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 24.--The Grand Jury of Sullivan County, which meets at Monticello this week, will be called upon to investigate some matters of bribery that are alleged to have occurred in the town of Fremont at the general election last November.

A fellow known as Julius, a, runner for immigrant hotels, was caught yesterday in an attempt to swindle three immigrant boys whom he had taken to some hotel, and had undertaken to send to Easton, Penn., by an officer stationed at the Liberty-Street Ferry.

ALBANY, May 24.--Down to Saturday last 433 bills had been passed by the Legislature of 1886, had been reviewed by the Governor and had become laws of the State. At least 100 more measures will in all probability receive his signature, so that the volume containing the session laws of 1886 will compare...

CHICAGO, May 24.--Assistant State's Attorney Furthman opened a sack of Anarchist traps this afternoon under the impression that he was alone. The bag contained empty bombs, pistols of large and small pattern, sharpened tools, and a lot of yellow copy ...

JAMESTOWN, May 24.--The lawless fishermen living along the shores of Chautauqua Lake have for several Winters been kept from spearing bass and pickerel through the ice, which has resulted in a rapid increase of the finny tribe.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 24.--Some days ago Noah Rude, an Erie brakeman, was arrested in Port Jervis on complaint of his wife, who charged him with desertion. Rude was found living with another woman at Port Jervis.

WASHINGTON, May 24.--The President nominated the following army officers for promotion today: First Lieut. Colon Augur, Second Cavalry, to be Captain; Second Lieut. Alonso L. O'Brien, Second Cavalry, to be first Lieutenant; Capt. Edward J. Spaulding, Second Cavalry, to be Major, Eighth Cavalry; Major John H. Minzer, Fourth Cavalry, to be Lieutenaut-Colonel, Eighth Cavalry; First Lieut, Charles E. Hargous, Fifth Infantry, to be Captain; Second Lieut. Charles A. Churchill, Fifth Infantry, to be First Lieutenant.

CHICAGO, May 24.--All grades of Cattle sold with considerable freedom to-day and prices ruled steady at last week's closing figures, or about 15c.@20c. lower than one week ago, especially for common to choice 1,000 to 1,400 lb. Beef Cattle.

The Brooklyn Saturday Half Holiday Association held a special meeting, last evening, and passed a vote of thanks to the various speakers who took part in the recent meeting at the Academy of Music; to the press, which had impartially reported its meetings, and to the merchants, for their readiness in granting their demands.

ELMIRA, N.Y., May 24.--The attention of the police was this morning called by the proprietors of the Delavan House to a man and woman occupying rooms in that hotel who were acting like a pair of maniacs. They had torn the beds to pieces and scattered movable articles about promiscuously.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 24.--John H. Dillon went into Forsyth's laundry, on Statestreet this afternoon, and informed the girl in charge of the office that she was his wife and had borne that relation to him for some seven years.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 24.--During the thunder shower last evening the station of the Lehigh and Hudson and New-York, Susquehanna and Western Railroads at Hamburg, N.J., was struck by lightning, set on fire, and entirely consumed. The electric fluid was conducted to the building by the telegraph wires.
Repeated harassing by city officials, fines and seizures of furniture for alleged blocking the sidewalk have brought up standing the business of B.M. Cow perthwait Co., 193 to 205 Park Row, New-York.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 24.--The weather to-day was warm, the track good, and the attendance at the races large. Following were the events:
CENTREVI LLE HIGHLAND. ULSTER COUNTY, N.Y., May 24. In a little house standing about two miles from this village lives a Mrs. Calhoun, who claims and is believed to be 105 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 24.--A carload of floral contributions from California for the decoration of Gen. Grant's tomb on Memorial Day, gathered through the efforts of the Grand Army of the Republic posts of Oakland, Cal., left this afternoon attached to a regular Central Pacific passenger train. Among the flowers are 3,000 calla lilies, quantities of orange blossoms, tea and camphor plants, camellias, and a life-size floral equestrian statue of Gen. Grant.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 24.--Mrs. B. Beardsley, aged 76 years, and Mrs. C.H. Pember, her daughter, were thrown from a carriage on North Main-street to-day by a collision with a milk peddler's wagon. The former was injured internally so that she probably cannot survive, and the latter had her shoulder and right wrist broken and one leg badly sprained.

Brokers on the Petroleum Exchange were led a merry dance again yesterday. The oil market, opening above 66, took a sudden fumble down three points at one plunge, and no manner of manipulation could raise the price again during the day, the closing quotation being at a fraction above 63.
WHEELING, West Va., May 24.--Joseph Hinton, a young man aged about 25 years, living near Jerusalem, Monroe County, shot and killed himself to-day under peculiarly sad circumstances.
ERIE, Penn., May 25--1:30 A.M.--The watchman's lamp exploded last night in the Eclipse Oil Works, a branch of the Standard, and they were entirely destroyed.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24.--Judge Allison's room in the old Court House was well filled this morning by a big crowd assembled to witness the trial of Abraham Erlanger, an actor and manager, for assault with intent to kill George Herbert...

WASHINGTON, May 24, 1886. The Senate began the consideration of the Bankruptcy bill this afternoon. The District of Columbia Appropriation bill was passed by the Senate to-day substantially as reported by the Senate Committee on Appropriations.
AUGUSTA, Ga., May 24.--"Who was Adam? Who was Adam, anyhow?" The man who asked this question paced excitedly up and down the platform before the Presbyterian General Assembly this afternoon.

Corporation Counsel Lacombe yesterday sent to Controller Loew an opinion as to whether 6,000 cubic yards of slope excavation included in the estimate under the designation of "earth excavation in open trench" can properly, under the terms of the contract for work on Section 9 of the new aqueduct, be paid for as a charge against the city.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24.--Two special races were given at Belmont Park to-day, one a pacing race for $1,000, the other a match race under saddle between the trotters Bob Johnson and McLeod.

Railroad earnings were reported as follows in Wall-street yesterday for the second week of May: Alton and Terre Haute, $11,490 against $10,549 for the same period of last year; Indianapolis and St. Louis, $20,692, against $17,272 in 1885; Marquette, Houghton and Ontonagon, $31,063, an increase of $18,859.

OMAHA, Neb., May 24.--Word has just reached here from Nuckolls County that George Kilpatrick, a railroad contractor, narrowly escaped hanging on Saturday afternoon at the hands of 125 railroad laborers who insisted that he should pay the debts of a subcontractor.
The Spring meeting of the American Jockey Club begins to-day, and although the track will necessarily be heavy after the rain of yesterday the racing promises to be of an exciting character.
Since Dr. Valentine Mott returned from Paris with the rabbit inoculated by Pasteur daily experiments have been made by his father, Dr. Alexander B. Mott, to test the quality of the virus.

When the case of Orrin Skinner, who was released from the Tombs last Friday on $4,200 bail, and who was rearrested on a civil proceeding and sent to Ludlow-Street Jail, was called for trial in Part II., of the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, there was no response from either Skinner, his lawyer, or his bondsman.

LONDON, May 24.--There was a numerous gathering at St. George's Club to-night to welcome Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes. Among those present were United States Minister Phelps, Commissioner Van Wagner, Consul-General Waller, Vice-Consul-General Penfield, Mr. James Russell Lowell, ...

CHICAGO, May 24.--J.C. McMullin, R. R. Cable and T.J. Potter, who were appointed arbitrators a short time ago to fix percentages for the roads in the Chicago east-bound pool, met to-day at the Grand Pacific Hotel to give the managers of the various roads an opportunity to supplement their written arguments with oral arguments.

WILCOX, Arizona, May 24.--A band of eight Indians last night attacked Lime Kilns, 10 miles from Fort Thomas, and killed one man. Troops have started in pursuit of the Indians. All the marauding Indians are heading for the San Carlos Reservation.

ERIE, Penn., May 24.--The hostilities between the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railway and the Pennsylvania Company were transferred to the courts to-day, although the respective forces held their grounds.

LONDON, May 24.--To-day, being the sixty-seventh anniversary of the Queen's birth, was celebrated with the usual ceremonies. The weather was miserable. The Prince and Princess of Wales went to Windsor Castle to congratulate her Majesty.

The Brooklyn Aldermen adopted a resolution yesterday, on motion of Alderman Coffee, rescinding all former resolutions granting, the consent of the city of Brooklyn to the building of elevated railroads in any streets of the city excepting such resolutions as affect the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad Company.
Though the annual report of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company was adopted some time ago it was not officially made public until yesterday.

The general lock-out threatened by the Contractor Tailors' Association, unless about 300 journey men who had struck in 25 shops against the task, system should return to work by Sunday was carried into effect yesterday, and in consequence about 8,000 men and women are now idle.

At the meeting of the Congregational Union in the Bible House yesterday morning Thomas G. Shearman spoke by invitation on "Socialism." Mr. Shearman said he was thoroughly in sympathy with the objects for which earnest Socialists were striving--the amelioration...
PHILADELPHIA, May 24.--It now seems probable that the Rev. Phillips Brooks, D.D., may be the Assistant Bishop of this diocese, after all the positive assertions that have been made to the contrary.
The Brooklyn Excise League, whose object is to stop liquor selling in that city on Sunday and the dealing out of liquor to minors, held a meeting last evening in Historical Hall, ...

LONDON, May 24.--The negotiations between the Chamberlain party and the Government continue, and there is thought to be a fa vorable prospect of a settlement of the home rule question.

AUBURN, N.Y., May 24.--About a year ago Eugene Camp, proprietor of the hotel at Newhope, in this county, took into his employ a young man named Delmer Raymond, keeping him until Spring, when he was discharged because of Camp's suspicion that he was improperly intimate with his wife.

The Church Choral Union of New-York City, an organization understood to represent about 200 churches, gave the first two of a series of three concerts at the Academy of Music yesterday afternoon and evening. The soloists concerned in the performances were not precisely brilliant, ...

The veterans of Duryee's Zouaves celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of their departure for the seat of war by a dinner at Morelli's, in West Twenty-eighth-street, last evening. Nearly 200 veterans were present.

A meeting of property owners opposed to the building of the Arcade Railroad through Broadway and Madison-avenue took place yesterday afternoon in Room C. Stewart Building. Among those present were John Mack, Stephen P. Nash, James P. Kernochan, ...
An order has been made by Judge Lawrence that the mental condition of Bartley Campbell shall be determined by a jury in the Supreme Court on Monday, June 7.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 24.--At 12:45 o'clock this morning an oil lamp exploded in the barber's shop of the steamer Dean Adams. The flames spread rapidly and, although the night watchman promptly gave the alarm, the crew barely escaped with their lives.

Mrs. Catharine Lefferts, who contests the will of Prof. William Darling, claiming to be his daughter, sat at the lawyers' table in the Surrogate's Court with her handkerchief to her eyes and trembling and sobbing for an hour after proceedings were resumed in the will case yesterday.

The Synod of the Reformed Presbyterian Church resumed its sitting yesterday morning in the church on Twelfth-street. The Treasurer of the sustentation fund stated that the amount in hand was $5,500, but that Mr. Alexander Kerr, of Philadelphia, had offered to give $1,000 if the balance of the original sum intended to be raised--$10,000--be subscribed this year.
VIENNA, May 24.--The town of Baligrod, in Austrian Galicia, has been destroyed by fire. ROME, May 24.--In the Parliamentary elections all the Cabinet Ministers were re-elected.

By constant practice Prof. BELL is becoming proficient in the difficult art of making affidavits to disprove the charges of fraud relating to his application of Feb. 14, 1876.

Circles varying in size from a quarter up to a silver dollar represented all the large cities of the country east of Kansas City and north of Washington on a map which hung back of Judge Lawrence, in Part IV. of the Supreme Court yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, May 25.--The Philadelphia Times to-morrow will say that the Textile Manufacturers' Association, though only two weeks old, has developed much strength.

DETROIT, Mich., May 25.--The authorities of Hope College, a Dutch Reformed insitution at Holland, in the western part of this State, have petitioned William III., King of the Netherlands, for a complete collection of Dutch literature for the college library.
NEW-BEDFOED, Mass., May 25.--Manoel C. Freitas shot himself through the lungs yesterday and died to-day.

NYACK, N.Y., May 25.--Considerable interest is connected with the reopening of an old highway, which was abandoned many years ago, between Greenwood Lake and a point on the Erie Railroad a few miles west from here.

PETERSBURG, Va., May 25.--Senator Mahone came down to the city from Washington yesterday to take a hand in the singular political fight which is waging here in the city. It is something remarkable to find a United States Senator actively directing a petty local election in which presumably he has nothing at stake.

Coroner Menninger, of Brooklyn, was requested to hold an inquest yesterday on the body of Charles Darnschidt, 7 years old, who died on Monday at No. 354 Fulton-street, Dr. Stone signed a certificate, giving peritonitis as the cause of death, but the Health Office clerk wanted the doctor to specify the cause of perionitis.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 25.--The hearing in the matter of the charges against P.J. Brumelkamp, Superintendent of the Onondaga Salt Springs Reservation, will begin to-morrow afternoon in this city before ex-Assemblyman Rice, of Ontario County, the Referee appointed ...

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 25.--The Executive Committee of the Lehigh and Schuylkill Coal Exchanges met to-day and agreed to make no changes in the present circular rates for line and city and harbor trades during June. The stocks of coal now on hand are quite low, and the demand from the East keeps up, but the line and city inquiry is unusually dull.

READING, Penn., May 25.--Mrs. Catharine Gable, of Boyertown, died this morning in the one hundred and second year of her age, being probably the oldest person in Eastern Pennsylvania. LIMA, Ohio, May 26.--The boiler in the sawmill of Buchanan Ferguson, near Deshler, north of here, exploded yesterday, instantly killing the engineer, William Smith, and so badly injuring Webb Buchanan and Bruce Ferguson, sons of the proprietors, and William Fleck that they cannot possibly recover. Three other persons were also seriously injured. The building was destroyed.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26.--Manager Abraham L. Erlanger was convicted of assault and battery with intent to kill an actor, George Herbert Leonard, before Judge Allison, this afternoon. Louise Balfe, the actress, and wife of Leonard, was not present. Judge Allison was an hour in charging the jury.

DETROIT, Mich., May 26.--The strike at the different car shops in this city is finally ended. After 23 days' holding out the men go back on the same time and wages in force when they foolishly threw down their tools and walked out.

LEBANON, Ohio, May 26.--The funeral services of Gen. Durbin Ward were held at the Opera House this afternoon.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 26.--Fully 2,000 persons were in attendance at the meeting ofthe American Baptist Missionary Union last evening. The Rev. S.S. Cauldwell, D.D., of Rhode Island, Chairman of the Convention, delivered a stirring address.
CHICAGO, May 26.--The sale at public auction of 33,000 acres of land in Minnesota and Wisconsin was announced at the rooms of the Real Estate Board to-day.

OSKALOOSA, Iowa, May 26.--Cecil Marriage, chief engineer of the water works, and his cousin, Miss Hettie Marriage, were drowned while bathing in the river yesterday.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 26.--About 3 o'clock this afternoon a trim-built schooner might have been seen beating down the harbor. The family of George Randall, of No, 659 First-avenue, have been missing clothing and jewelry recently.

The trial of John T. Bevans, on a charge of shooting and killing his wife at No. 1,903 Second-avenue on the evening of Jan. 10, lasted only a little more than an hour in Part II, of the Court of General Sessions yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, May 26.--Hundreds of spectators crowded all the available space in the Criminal Court room at an early hour this morning in anticipation of the sensational scenes which were expected to occur when the diminutive Maxwell took the stand and told the story of Preller's death.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 26.--The schooner Daniel Pierson, Capt. Harris, from Boston to New-York, in ballast, collided with the schooner Onrust, bound to this port, off Stratford Shoals, 15 miles west of New-Haven, last night.

BALTIMORE, May 26.--The trial of William E. Stone for the murder of his wife in this city in November last was concluded to-day, and a verdict of not guilty rendered.

Mary Freel, who gave her age as 44, but refused to give her residence, was charged, before Justice Walsh, in Brooklyn, yesterday with stealing a lace shawl from A.D. Matthews Co.'s store, at No. 393 Fulton-street.

WASHINGTON, Penn., May 26.--The 24 miners of the Monongahela Valley who have been on trial for the past week, charged with riot and conspiracy, were this evening all found guilty upon the charges of conspiracy and all but two on the charge of riot.

WASHINGTON, May 26, 1886. The revenues of the Government so far this month are nearly $16,000,000 in excess of the expenditures during the same period, and Treasury officials are encouraged to believe that there will be a comparatively large decrease in the public debt--probably about $12,000,000.
A joint conference was held yesterday at Commissioner Fisk's office of the Trunk Line Passenger Committee and the Passenger Committee of the Central Traffic Association.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 26.--In the home rule debate in the English House of Commons yesterday Mr. Trevelyan quoted an alleged remark of Mr. Parnell to the effect that he would not rest until the last link that connected Ireland with England had been broken.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 26.--Springfield's anniversary celebration was continued to-day. The weather was clear, but rather cold. Crowds of people poured into the city this morning from all directions, and the streets presented an animated scene.
The Commissioner of Indian Supplies of the United States Government yesterday awarded the following contracts:
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 26.--Some days ago a number of Itailans bought a small slooprigged boat, and this afternoon a party of them went out for a sail.
CHICAGO, May 26.--The Rev. Mr. Scott, Pastor of the First Congregational Church of Evanston, Ill., has been asked to resign.

EL PASO, Texas, May 26.--A letter was received here to-day from Kingston. Sierra County, New-Mexico, giving an account of the discovery of a remarkably rich deposit of silverbearing ore. The writer of the letter, James T. Foster, was for several years a resident of Houston.

Railroad earnings reported in Wallstreet for the third week of May showed for Chicago and Northwest an increase of $27,200 over the third week of May last year; Buffalo, Rochester and Pittsburg a decrease of $9,257;...
CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 26.--The Latonia races commence to-morrow. The following are the entries, weights, and betting:

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 26.--The usually staid and quiet city of Charlottetown, Prince Edward Island, has just now a social scandal which is the talk and wonder of the hour. About last November a fine looking stranger arrived there.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 26.--In the weekly review of the flour production for its issue of May 28 the Northwestern Miller will say: "More activity is being shown among the mills than at any time since last Fall, and were the wheat capable of as rapid production the flour output would probably approach the heavy work done in October and November.
The result of the great Derby race, which was run on the Epsom Downs yesterday, was placed on the Tickers of the New-York City Press Association just 37 seconds after the race was run.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 26.--Princeton but another notch in the championship record to-day by defeating Amherst. This gives Princeton a score of three games won and none lost in the college championship series. The game was twice interrupted by rain, once in the second inning and again in the eighth.

CHICAGO, Ill., May 26.--Hugh Curry and John McGuire have been hold in bail of $2,000 for examination on a charge of a brutal assault on Curry's sister, Kate, and her betrothed, Fred Koestlin. Koestlin is a German Protestant, and, as Miss Curry is a Catholic, her brother objected to the marriage.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 26.--Judge Marcus Lyon, as Surrogate of Tompkins County, to-day filed a decision in the famous McGraw-Fiske will case decreeing the legacies of Jennie McGraw Fiske to Cornell University of $1,500,000 for library purposes in all respects valid;
The Covert family will hold their annual reunion on June 17 of Lodi Landing, Senecan Lake. The President, John Covert, of Chicago,...
NORWALK, Conn., May 26.--Mrs. Polly Burdick, of Brookfield, now in her ninety-ninth year, is the oldest person in her town or vicinity and among the oldest in the State.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah May 26.--The polygamists in the Utah penitentiary, to whom Gov. West, on the 16th inst., proffered his good offices in case they would consent to submit to the laws, have made a formal reply to the Governor, in which they express...

Mrs. Christopher Becker, wife of the aged scale manufacturer of New-Rochelle, eloped on May 5 with John Sparenburg, one of the hands employed in the factory, and, as she took with her two bonds for $1,000 each, which Mr. Becker had given her, he decided to get them back if he could.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 26.--By order of the Chancellor all creditors' bills will be paid this week by the Dime Savings Bank, of which A.G. Ogilhby was Treasurer, and the first dividend of 50 per cent. will be declared next week.
The Grand Conservatory of Music of the City of New-York celebrated the twelfth anniversary of its foundation by a concert at Chickering Hall last evening.

LONDON, May 26.--The steamship Pontiac, from New-Orleans for Liverpool, which is ashore at Kilmore, is apparently undamaged. She is being lightened, her cargo being put into schrs, for Liverpool. Two steamships have been dispatched to assist in discharging her.

DETROIT, May 26.--During the present week the new United States Circuit Judge Howell E. Jackson, of Tennessee, has been holding court here trying the patent case of Samuel R.C. Matthews and R.D. Wood Co. against James Flower Brothers, of Detroit, for alleged infringement of patent.
MANCHESTER, May 26.--The Guardian, in its commercial article, says: "The market is quiet; the business of Tuesday was not up to the average.

Grand Marshal C.H. Lutjens, AdjtGen. and Chief of Staff D.J. Mallon, and William J. Trimble, of the Memorial Committee of the Grand Army of the Republic, were as busy as bees all day yesterday and until late at night, arranging for the memorial exercises on Decoration...

MONTREAL, May 26.--It is stated here that information has been received by the ecclesiastical authorities from Rome that the Pope contemplates raising Montreal and Ottawa to be metropolitan sees, with the present occupants elevated to the dignity of Archbishops.
MADRID, May 26.--A dynamite factory at Valencia was destroyed to-day by an explosion, which killed 12 men.

LONDON, May 26.--Mr. Gladstone's circular calling a meeting of the Liberal Party for Thursday invites to the meeting "all members of the party who, while retaining full freedom in all particulars respecting the Irish Government bill, are desirous to vote to establish a legislative body in Dublin to manage affairs specifically and exclusively Irish."

Harmony was not restored yesterday between the contractor tailors and the union journeymen whom they locked out on Monday. The contractors, however, said that about 300 of the men had expressed their willingess to leave the union.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26.--The Rev. Dr. Phillips Brooks has finally decided not to accept the position of Assistant Bishop of the Diocese of Pennsylvania. In his letter of May 15 he appeared to be wavering, and hopes were entertained that he was about to accept.
An old man, bent, decrepit, and almost blind wandered into the Charles-street police station house Monday afternoon and begged that he might be taken care of.
TOLEDO, Ohio, May 26.--The appointment of a Collector of Customs for Sandusky has caused a nervous spasm to overwhelm the numerous candidates for the Toledo Federal offices.

After a postponement, which was confidered by many people as unnecessary, the gates of Jerome Park were thrown open to the public yesterday and the Spring meeting of the American Jockey Club began. A great crowd was present and the improvement in the track was favorably commented ...
The great kirmess at the German clubroom at Stapleton, Staten Island, for which elaborate preparations have been in progress for many weeks, will open this evening at 8 o'clock.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26.--The examination of witnesses to prove the signatures to the petition to the Trustee of the Reading general mortgage to foreclose the mortgage was resumed to-day before ex-Gov. Pollock, Examiner in the case.
The new Executive Board of the Empire Protective Association is taking matters leisurely, considering the important business said to be in hand.

A quarter of a century has now passed away since the Ninth Regiment of this city started for the seat of war. To-day it will commemorate that departure, not to keep alive almost extinguished animosities of the civil strife, but to revive old recollections and to encourage a fraternal feeling among the members of the regiment, old and new.

Jay Gould, Russell Sage, G.P. Huntington, Henry Hart, William Remsen, Edward Lauterbach, J.W. Shaw, and J.B. Houston were reelected Directors of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company at the annual meeting yesterday.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 26.--A judgement dissolving the corporation of the McQueen Locomotive Worke was entered at the Counts Clerk's office to-day on the ground that the company has not paid in its stock and has not carried on the business for which it was incorporated.

TRENTON, N.J., May 26.--The call for the Conference of Temperance Republicans drew out so small an attendance at Library Hall to-day that Major Z.K. Pangborn, in accepting the temporary Presidency, apologized for the size of the crowd.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26.--A committee representing the amalgamated iron workers of Philadelphia, headed by Vice-President Lee, of the Amalgamated Association, had a conference with the committees of the manufacturers today at the office of James Rowland Co. in reference to the demand of the men for an advance of 5 per cent. over the present wages.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 26.--Three brothers, Everett, Harry, and John Wright, aged respectively 25, 23 and 19 years, and James Hannis started in their own yacht Saturday night for a sail down the river and have not since been heard from.

CHICAGO, May 26.--A bill, which will make a sensation when it comes to trial, was filed to-day in the Circuit Court by Joseph Dinet against his stepmother, Adele Dinet, and Dr. Charles Venn to set aside the will of his father, the late Joseph Dinet, on the ground of mental unsoundness and undue influence.
People who went to Jerome Park yesterday to look at the second day's racing had to sit in solemn silence in a dual, dark dock" between the races.
NEW-HEAVEN, May 27.--The Connecticut Medical Association held its ninety-fifth convention in this city to-day, nearly 100 old school physicians being present.

As the 200 veterans of the Ninth Regiment marched past the members of their active organization, who were drawn up on the south side of Twenty-sixth-street, between Broadway and Sixth-avenue, last evening, it was hard to realize that 80 of their number had borne the brunt of battle on some of the most bloody fields of the divil war.

Twenty-five young men in swallow tails, boutonnieres, and hectic flushes, born of pleasurable excitement, stood up in the Academy of Music last night and were made bachelors of law on the spot by the Rev. Dr. Henry M. MacCracken, Vice-Chancellor of the University of the City of New-York.

Kellogg, of Chittenango, N.Y.; H.H. Wilder, of Princeton, Mass.; I. C. Wood, of Chicago, and R.A. Woods, of Pittsburg, Penn.

A sad story is told by the officers of the Cunard steamer Catalonia, which arrived here from Liverpool on Saturday. A family of five, father, mother, and three children, the youngest an infant, embarked as steerage passengers at Queenstown, and when out a few days the two elder children sickened and died.
The concert arranged for the benefit of Signor del Puente takes place at Chickering Hall this evening. Mlle. Fohstrom, Mme. Lablache, and Signor Giannini are among the performers that will be heard.
The German Club Rooms at Stapleton were the scene last evening of the most brilliant and successful entertainment that ever occurred at Stapleton, or in all Staten Island.
The misfortunes of Capt. Thomas Cullom, the whilom manager of the Third-Avenue Independent Stage Line, seem to have all come at once. Now he is in the hands of the police.

Charles N. Taintor, John D. Lawson, Granville P. Hawes, and Henry L. Sprague, of the Committee on Contested Seats, appointed at the last meeting of the Republican County Committee, held its second meeting last night at the Cooper Institute. Ashbel P. Fitch, of the committee, was absent.

When the trial of John Most, Adolph Schenek, and Richard Braunschweig was resumed before Reorder Smyth, in Part II. of the Court of General Sessions, yesterday morning, the number of persons who clamored at the door for admission was twice as large as the number of spectators on the hard wooden benches in the court room.

Several months ago the papers on the appeal of Charles A. Buddunsiek from his conviction of manslaughter on account of the killing of a workman by the fall of houses he was erecting in West Sixty-first-street were submitted to the General Term of the Supreme Court.

William M. Tilden, one of the best known live stock shippers in the West, died at his home in Chicago yesterday. Mr. Tilden was born in Oswego County, N.Y., 62 years ago, and was a cousin of Samuel J. Tilden.
LANCASTER, Penn., May 27.--A heavy halistorm passed over Lancaster County this evening, doing great-damage especially to growing fruit. Telegraph wires are prostrated in all directions.

LONDON, May 27.--The race for the Epsom Grand Prize, for 3-year-olds, was run at Epsom to-day and was won by Lord Alington's b. c. Candlemas. Lord Bradford's ch. c. Sir Hamo was second and Y.R. Graham's br. c. St. Mirin third.

The annual dinner of the Lockwood Press, given by Howard Lockwood to the members of his staff, was eaten last evening at the Union League Club. Among the gentlemen present were Augustine Smith, Vice-President of the National Papermakers' Association; the ...

WASHINGTON, May 27, 1886. The conference report on the Shipping bill was adopted by both houses of Congress to-day. The bill contains the Frye amendment authorizing the president to treat foreign vessels in American ports as American vessels are treated in foreign ports.
TRENTON, N.J., May 27.--The residence of W.A. Shreve, in Farnsworth-avenue, Bordentown, was entered by a burglar at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

At a meeting of the Subcommittee of Seventy, held in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel Wednesday evening, the Spring Election and Aldermanic bills were favorably discussed, speeches being made by William H. Webb, O.B. Potter, John Foley, and others in their support.

DETROIT, Mich., May 27.--F.N. Bonine, the record breaker in the recent running matches; F.F. Bumpus, H.S. Tibbits, and John L. Duffy left the State University this morning to enter the intercollegiate contests of the Rugby Association at New-York.

WASHINGTON, May 27.--The Washingtons signalized their return home by treating the champions to a coat of whitewash very skillfully applied. The Western players were unable to do anything with Barr's curves, which were beautifully handled by Gilligan.

BOSTON, Mass., May 27.--As to-day is the opening day of the sixth annual meeting of the League of American Wheelmen in this city there have been large arrivals from various parts of the country, nearly 500 representatives being already on hand.

BOSTON, Mass., May 27.--Mayor O'Brien has received a letter from Gov. Hill, of NewYork, in which he declares his intention to be present at the Parliamentary Fund Festival to be held in this city on June 17.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27.--Anxiety is felt as to the safety of the Austrian ship Miroslav, which sailed from this port Feb.17 for Flume under the command of Capt. Viassich, a skillful navigator and one who thoroughly understands the handling of large vessels.

The tailor contractors and their men held a conference yesterday and the former offered a compromise in which they promised to abolish the task system and to adopt a limited system with classified wages.
LONDON, May 27.--The company of Daly's Theatre began their London season of 10 weeks at the Strand Theatre to-night.
BURLINGTON, Vt., May 27.--Snow to the depth of several inches is reportod in various towns in Northern Vermont, and fears are entertained of severe damage to the crops by frost.

A decision affecting the value of railroad securities, and more particularly the rights of holders of first mortgage railroad bonds, was rendered by Justice Woods on Tuesday in the United States Circuit Court for the Eastern District of Texas.

CRAWFORDSVILLE, Ind., May 27.--John C. Henning was hanged at 1:30 P.M. to-day. The crime for which he was executed was committed at Rockville on Oct. 24, 1885. His victim was a widow--Mrs. Lottie Vollmer--who kept a small eating house in that town.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 27.--The Court of Appeals will meet on Monday, May 31, at Saratoga. The 30 remaining cases on the old calendar will be disposed of before the new calendar is taken up. The day calendar for May 31 is as follows: Nos. 698, 194, 315, 358, 430, 474, 632, 642.

Charles F. Holmes, a cripple in both legs, was locked up in Police Hendquarters, in Jersey City, last night, charged with having committed a criminal assault on his niece, Mary Westcott, aged 7 years. The girl was left by her mother in Holmes's charge while she went shopping. Holmes denied the charge, but the girl insisted that it was true, and a physician who examined her said that she had been assaulted.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 27.--The result of the Domocratic gathering in Columbus yesterday and the meeting held last night, which lasted until the morning hours, was not a success so far as the vindication of the deserting Senators was concerned.

Great excitement and indignation have prevailed in Flatbush Village since Wednesday afternoon, when it was reported that an assault of a heinous character had been committed by an unknown negro upon a little girl, 14 years old, the sister of Mrs. William Pedal.

The decision of the Surrogate of Tompkins County in favor of Cornell University in the suit of Prof. WILLARD FISKE in the matter of his late wife's will is a fortunate one for that institution and for higher education in this State.
Nothing is plainer in the recent developments of the pension legislation of the two houses of Congress than the immense and direct influence of the claim agent.

CHICAGO, May 27.--A capias has been issued for the arrest of George H. Leonard, a well known young lawyer of Hyde Park, as a sequence to an attachment suit to recover $950. The suit was begun by Oliver G. Fessenden as agent of J.D. Fessenden, of New-York, the latter having loaned Leonard $950.
BLOOMINGTON, Ill., May 27.--A curious spiritualistic revelation was made to-day by Mrs. Mott, a lady of Normal, who is said to be possessed of second sight, which she claims is a gift of the spirits.

BALTIMORE, May 27.--The schooner Francis A. Hail, having on board 25 strawberry pickers, capsized yesterday afternoon in the Magothy River, and two of the pickers, a man and a boy, were drowned. Another man was rescued by cuttting a hole in the bow of the schooner.

Miss Frances Folsom, the young lady who is said to be engaged to President Cleveland, arrived here last evening on the steamship Noordiand, of the Red Star Line, from Antwerp. She is described as tall, handsome, and in complexion a light brunette.
WASHINGTON, May 28.--For Maine, NewHampshire, Vermont, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, and Connecticut, local rains, slightly cooler westerly winds, becoming variable.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 27.--A fashionable wedding occurred at Washingtonville last evening, the principals being Mr. Moses Finlay and Miss Emma Bull. The ceremony occurred at the home of the bride and was performed by the Rev. Mr. Hathaway, assisted by the Rev. Mr. Wallace, in the presence of 150 guests. Among the number were several ladies and gentlemen.
CHOCAGO, May 27.--The published statement is made here that Dr. Abbott E. Kittredge, of the Third Presbyterian Church, will leave his present Pastorate at the end of next month.
TRENTON, N.J., May 27.--Attorney-General John P. Stockton wishes it understood that he is not a candidate for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination.

The New-Yorks made their first appearance on the Polo Grounds yesterday since their return from the West in a contest in which they had for their opponents the St. Louis "Black Diamonds." When the Giants emerged from the club house and entered the field they were the recipients of loud and long applause, and several times the brawny athletes were forced to doff their caps in recognition.
About 150 men of sedate appearance, and to whom rings and scarfpins were apparently unknown, met yesterday in the large lecture room of the Cooper Institute.
NYACK, N.Y., May 27.--The Rev. N.M. Skinner, of New-York City, has reseived and accepted a call from the Presbyterian Church of Ramapo, Rookland Count, to succeed the Rev. ...

BOSTON, May 27.--At the anti-rag disinfection hearing before the City Health Committee to-day Edwin Story Smith, an importer of rags, gave his experience in visiting paper manufactories in_Europe, where no restrictions are in force, and where no case of infectious disease from rags was ever known.
OTTAWA, May 27.--In the House of Commons to-day the Hon. Mr. Foster, Minister of Marine, in reply to a question, said that six vessels were being fitted out to protect the Canadian fisheries.
BOSTON, May 27.--The committee of the Legislature which has been hearing Cyrus W. Field's petition in the New-York and New-England bond case is struggling over its report.
PARIS, May 27.--Advices from Japan state that the chelera in the southern part of the country is increasing.
BALTIMORE, May 27.--Richard Chanceaulme, for many years connected with the hotels of this city, cut his throat at his home this afternoon and died in a few minutes.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, May 27.--The western portion of this county was this morning visited by the most terrific storm in its history. It occurred about 2 o'clook, and spread terror and destruction in its path.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 27.--Middlesex County has been troubled for years with the tramps. At the meeting of the Board of Freeholders yesterday action was taken on the matter.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 27.--The Prohibitory bill passed the House this afternoon after a fight of a day and a half. A strong effort to strike out all the sections providing for a State constabulary was defeated by a vote of three to one.

St. LOUIS, May 27.--In the Maxwell trial to-day the diminutive defendant appeared in his true light as the monumental liar of the age. By his wavering, hesitating manner and his contradictory replies upon the cross-examination he reversed the good impression which he made yesterday, and left his previous testimony in a hopelessly mixed condition.

WASHINGTON, May 27.--First Lieut. George W. Kingbury, Twelth Infantry, and First Lieut. H. H. Bellas, Fourth Cavalry, having been found incapacitated for active service on account of disability incident to the service, have been placed on the retired list.
MERIDEN, Conn., May 27.--Ella Wheeler Wilcox, the poet, around whom all literary lights of Meriden revolve, had a narrow escape to-day.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 27.--Two State Conventions of the Ancient Order of Hibernians were held to-day, one in Hartford and the other in this city.

The Electric Subway Commission held its first meeting since the death of Charles E. Loew, over a month ago, yesterday morning, when Roswell P. Power, the new Commissioner, took his seat for the first time.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27.--Fifteen hundred persons witnessed the first representation of Gilbert Sullivan's "Mikado" ever given by a colored amateur opera company, at the Horticultural Hall, to-night. The hall was packed.

WASHINGTON, May 27.--Harmoney has not been a conspicuous feature of Republican Senatorial caucuses during the present session of Congress, and it was lost sight of for a time this morning, when the Republican Senators met to try to agree upon an order of business for the rest of the session.

RICHMOND, Va., May 27.--The returns from the municipal and town elections held in the State to-day show that the Democrats have held their own in all except this city, and make gains in Norfolk and Petersburg, which have heretofore been strongly Republican.

MADISON, Ind., May 27.--The Board of Directors of the Cincinnati, Louisville and Dayton Railroad this afternoon closed a contract with responsible New-York parties at Middletown, Ohio, to build the road complete by December, 1887.
ALBANY, May 27.--That the city of NewYork needs at least 500 more policemen seemed to be the opinion of everybody who watched the recent scenes of lawlessness in her streets.

CINCINNATI, May 27.--The weather today was sultry and the track very dusty, but the attendance at the opening of the Latonia races was good. The betting was light and the 26 bookmakers found time hang heavy on their hands. Following were the events:

It requires a more detailed knowledge of the Parliamentary situation than anybody out of England can be expected to possess to appreciate the manoeuvring of the contending parties in the House of Commons.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 27.--The Knights of Labor do not believe in all work and no play while they are holding a convention. A couple of hundred of them have been in Cleveland for four days. Two-thirds of this number were admitted to the General Assembly, which held its first session Tuesday afternoon. That session lasted for about four hours.
James C. Dennis, a colored railroad porter, 25 years old, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by shooting himself in the right temple in the yard of the Grand Central Station.
TORONTO, May 27.--The arrangements for "Hanlan's great sculling regatta on June 4 and 5 are almost completed.

LONDON, May 27.--The general Liberal meeting called by Mr. Gladstone assembled at the Foreign Office this afternoon. There was a great crowd outside of the building. The meeting was well attended by the Premier's supporters, but none of the known Hartington or Chamberlain dissidents was present.

AUGUSTA, Ga., May 27.--When the Presbyterian General Assembly decided, by a vote of 10 to 1, that man was blown into immediate being by a puff of dust, it was believed the trouble was settled as securely as if written on the rocks of ages.

FORT KEOGH, Montana, May 27.--Deputy Sheriff Mandy and posse, who had been following the trail of the road agents who held up the Melrose stage Saturday and killed the driver, Ferguson, came suddenly upon the rasoals near Dillon yesteday.
BOSTON, May 27.--A public meeting, under the auspices of the Massachusetts Reform League, in support of the Morrison Tariff bill, was held in the South Meeting House to-night.
PITTSBURG, Penn., May 27.--An independent oil refinery is about to be started at Washington, Penn., by the independent oil producers of the Washington district.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 27.--The African Methodist Episcopal church at Goshen was sold to-day under a judgment obtained by the Rev. Mr. Jackson, a former Pastor, for unpaid salary. The edifice was bought in by plaintiff's attorney, and an arrangement is looked for whereby it will still be used for church purposes.
FRANKLIN, Mass., May 27.--A fire started this morning in the old Daniels Building, on School-street, used as a storehouse, billiard hall, and tenement, and the structure was soon consumed.

BOSTON, May 27.--Over $1,000,000 worth of Mexican Central bonds were traded in to-day on the stock market. Mexican Central 7s sold at 37 and 37 , and the 4s at 33 , 35 1/8, and 34 7/8.

The University of Pennsylvania has recently established a limited number of unendowed postgraduate fellowships in Political Science and History. Graduates of any American college, either in arts or science, are eligible.

ROCKFORD, Ill., May 27.--B.B. Northrup, a well known young business man at No. 106 West State-street, was arrested this morning for arson. He left his store at 8 o'clock last night, saying he was going into the country.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 27.--Skull and Bones and Scroll and Keys, Yale's famous Senior societies, gave out their elections to members of the Class of '87 this afternoon, each society taking in 15 men.

BELOIT, Wis., May 27.--On the petition of various persons an alternative writ of mandamus was issued yesterday by order of the Circuit Court at Janesville, directed to the District Board of School District No. 8 in the city of Edgerton, requiring said board to discontinue ...
For several days Secretary Mulford, of the Executive Board, has been uttering dark hints as to some move about to be made in the interest of the Third-avenue strikers.

Rag Disinfector Bartlett manned a tug yesterday, and went sailing down the Bay with the Chamber of Commerce committee which is investigating some of the features of the disinfection game as it is played against New-York merchants by Mr. Bartlett and Mr. Bartlett's friend, Health Officer Smith.

RHINECLIFF, N.Y., May 27.--The position of Military Secretary to the Governor, which has been vacant since the death of Col. Gillett last January, and which is worth $3,000 per year, is to be filled by the appointment of Col. Frank A. Sutton, of Peekskill, a lifelong friend of Gov. Hill.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 27.--Pittsburg won today's game in the eleventh inning on Carroll's single and Kuehne's two-base drive to left field, with only one man out. The home team was outbatted and better fielding was done by the visitors. The features were good catches by Sommer and Barklev and the sharp field work of Whitney, Houck, and Farrell.

The collection of works in oil and pastel by the "impressionists" of Paris, which was lately on view at the American Art Galleries, has been transferred for exhibition to the National Academy of Design, where it may be seen until further notice, together with a few additional specimens of the artist's craft, loaned for the occasion by the owners, who happen to be residents of the United States.

NEWBURG, N.Y., May 27.--Patrick Brogan and Joseph Ashton, of the Newburg bridge bandits, and Thomas Nash, of Middletown, escaped from a Cornwall officer in Newburg last night, near the jail, and were recaptured by Newburg officers.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., May 27.--A terrific explosion, resulting in the death of two men, occurred to-day at the United States Dynamite Mills, owned by Volleney Co., near this place. There have been several oxplosions at this mill, one about two months ago.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 27.--The ship William Law, of Yarmouth, stranded at West Scattarie yesterday and is fast breakingup. Two of the crew were lost.

DETRIOT, Mich., May 27.--The conflict between the Federal and State courts at Marquette was settled to-day by compromise. The attachment cases were argued in the State court all day yesterday and far into the night, the question of jurisdiction being raised.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 27.--Col. Charles Taylor, the manager of the Western Union Telegraph office at Frankfort, passed through the city to-day en route from Columbus, Miss., to Kentucky's capital with the remains of James F. Leonard, who died of typhoid fever at Columbus in 1862 while managing a telegraph office at that place.

The House passed by a vote of 119 to 88 on Friday last a bill forbidding the importation of mackerel (Spanish mackerel excepted) into the United States between March 1 and June 1 for a period of five years. This bill should not be allowed to become a law, and we hope the Senate will reject it by a decisive vote.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 27.--The residents of Jamestown, in Chautauqua County, have long complained of excessive freight rates which have had a bad effect on the growth of the city.

The Young Men's Democratic Club is taking active steps to induce Gov. Hill to sign the Daly Aldermanic bill. Petitions, which will be sent to the Governor, are now being circulated for signatures by members of the club.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 27.--The CourierJournal's tobacco report says: "The market was rather soft and dull to-day for common grades of dark and heavy tobaccos, while medium grades were about steady and the grade above firm.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27.--Under the title of "The Associated Manufacturers of Hosiery and Knit Goods," 47 manufacturers, employing over 12,000 hands, met today at No. 106 Chestnut-street and organized an association for mutual protection. The organization is the result of the recent demands of the employes, and is in response to the following circular, sent in the early part of the present month to each manufacturer in the trade in Philadelphia:
DANBURY, Conn., May 27.--A runaway boy captured here a day or two ago has been identified as Edward Boughton, Jr., of No. 44 Bond-street, New-york City.

CHICAGO, May 27.--The Grand Jury filed into Judge Rogers's court this morning and presented a batch of 21 indictments l0 of them against Anarchists, and the others charging ordinary criminals with their respective offenses.

Inspector Byrnes was all smiles yesterday morning when any one desired to know from him the identity of the mysterious prisoner who was arrested the previous night and taken to the Police Central Office.

The Hoodstown mail bag, which was lost in Vernon Lake three years ago, has just been discovered by men employed on a saw-log drive. The mail matter was in a fair state of preservation. The outside leather bag was almost as good as when last used. There were two cotton bags inside, one containing only the time bill and the other a package of letters, many of which contained sums of money.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 27.--The American Congress of Churches closed to-day. "Readjustments in the church to meet modern needs" was discussed by the Rev. B.B. Tyler and the Rev. Dr. W.S. Rainsford, of New-York; the ...

Mrs. Harvey H. Brown, of No. 100 Hicks-street, Brooklyn, and every member of her family, including the servant, have been annoyed for nearly five months by the continued receipt of scurrilous anonymous letters, all of which have been written by the same person.
PARIS, May 27.--The Government submitted its Expulsion bill to the Chamber of Deputies this evening and demanded urgency for its consideration.

The new sloop yacht Atlantic, built by members of the Atlantic Yacht Club to compete for the honor of defending the America's Cup against the English cutter Galatea, made her trial trip yesterday and proved herself, if not an unqualified success, at least a remarkably fast boat.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 28.--Something before unheard of in the history of lumbering in Minneapolis is the delay this Spring in starting the mills.
Contributions poured in on Mrs. Landgraf to the amount of $9 yesterday. "L., H., S., and C." sent $2 to her through THE TIMES. One man paid her 50 cents for a glass of milk, ...

Brawler John Most and his co-Anarchists, Adolph Schenck and Richard Braunschweig, learned a thing or two about the American idea yesterday. A New-York jury, with exceeding dispatch, found them guilty of inciting to riot, and they were marched off to the lock-up to await the sentence of the court.

BOSTON, May 28.--At the business meeting of the Board of Officers of the League of American wheelmen to-day, the following officers were chosen: President-Dr. N.M. Beckwith, (present incumbent;) Vice-President--T. J. Kirkpatrick, of Springfield, Ohio; Treasurer--Sanford Lawson, of Springfield, Mass. Eugene M. Aaron continues as Secretary, to serve until he is removed by the Board of Officers for cause. The Secretary's report shows a total membership of 8,643, ...

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 28.--Capt. Scott, of the steamer Lansdowne, arrived hero last night. On the train, in conversation with an American, he claimed that the Nova Scotians were right in their position, and that they could afford to be indifferent to the Americans, as they would work up a market in the West Indies and France.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 28.--At 7 o'clock last evening a thundering crash was heard in the Valley City Mills. On investigation it proved to be the giving way of the overladened floors.

WINNIPEG, May 28.--In the Legislature yesterday a motion of confidence in the Norquay Government was defeated. So hot was the discussion thereon ttrat an Opposition member crossed the floor after the debate and called Premier Norquay a contemptible liar. The bulky Premier promptly hit his assailant and a fight followed but the combatants were soon parted.

ELMIRA, N.Y., May 28.--The police have been anxiously on the lookout for a sleek shark that is placing the confidence game in Elmira and neighboring places. Among the names on the Rathbun House register yesterday appeared that of "S. Rohman, NewYork."
