What promised to be one of the greatest rowing contests ever held in this vicinity was prevented by the laws of the Harlem Regatta Committee.

ALBANY, May 28.--Twice Gov. Hill was reminded to-day, during the hearing upon the Nooney Excise bill, that he had recently given utternace to the opinion that the appointment of local officers in the city of New-York should be vested in the Mayor, so that the responsibility for municipal government should rest where it properly belongs. NEWBURG, N.Y., May 28.--The marriage of Miss Mary D. Mills, daughter of the Rev. Dr. S.W. Mills and J. Alexander Stitt, a rising young lawyer of New-York, occurred at the home of the bride's father, in Port Jervis, yesterday afternoon.

DETROIT, Mich., May 28.--The suit of J. Jenks Co., of Sand Beach, against the Western Union Telegraph Company for damages for the non-delivery of a telegram was again brought before the United States Circuit Court in this district yesterday on a motion for a new trial made by a telegraph company.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28.--The Athletics lost a postponed game to-day to Louisville, principally owing to their inabilty to hit the pitching of Ramsey. Only two hits were made off him and 12 men struck out.

WASHINGTON, May 28.--Antonio Nardello was hanged at the district jail near this city at 1:30 this afternoon for the murder of Carmine Rotunno. The execution was conducted quietly and successfully, and was witnessed by about 50 persons.

Surrogate Rollins has decided that Mrs. Emma L. Stanly is the lawful widow of Marcus Cicero Stanly, and entitled to letters of administration upon the estate.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 28.--A Hudson (Wis.) special announces the remarriage at that place, on Wednesday, of T.J. McAfee, the man convicted of bigamy in St. Paul in the Fall of 1884 and sentenced to three years in the penitentiary.

Some time ago a chimney fire broke out in the premises of Peter Stallknecht's apartments on the third floor of the tenement No. 127 Steuben-street, Jersey City, and the firemen cut away the fireplace to reach the flames.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 28.--A local paper to-night charges Hon. C.T. Cowenhoven, Presiding Judge of the Middlesex County Court, with gross neglect of duty.

There never was a better nor a bigger audience inside of the Standard Theatre than there was last night. The students of Columbia College took possession of the house. Over 500 of them were there. They occupied about 400 seats in the orchestra, all the boxes but one, and three rows in the balcony. The boxes were decorated with blue and white bunting and American flags.

LONDON, May 28.--The House of Commons was crowded this evening. Mr. Gladstone, replying to a question by Sir Michael HicksBeach, (Conservative,) said that the Government considered it to be its duty, after the second reading of the Home Rule bill, not to ask the House to go into committee on the measure, but to adopt one of the methods which he (Mr. Gladstone) described at the Liberal meeting yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, May 28.--Since giving to the public an inkling of his true character by his infamous lies and contradictory statements on the witness stand yesterday, Maxwell's chipper manner has undergone a change.
WHEELING, West Va., May 28.--Ritchie County once more comes to the front with one of the worst outrages ever perpetrated within the borders of this State.
All the cars of the little bobtail line from Vesey-street to South Ferry were running as usual yesterday.

An excellent article for home and laundry use is James Pyle's Pearline. Its power for cleaning is acknowledged by housewives and employes in laundries. Not only is it good for washing clothes, but it has been proven a firstclass thing for washing dishes, furniture, and woodwork. Every house should be supplied with Pearline.--New-York Evening Telegram.
SOUTHINGTON, Conn., May 28.--Burglars made a raid upon Plantsville on Wednesday night and secured a good deal of booty.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 28.--The Mott Haven team left Cambridge this morning for New-York to participate in the intercollegiate sports which take place to-morrow afternoon.

CHICAGO, May 28.--The Cattle market to-day was fairly active, and values were without important change. Handy native Steers, averaging 1,000 to 1,500 lb., sold readily, and prices ruled stronger while medium and course heavy grades averaged weaker.

The 2,000-point billiard match between J. Randolph Heiser and Harvey Mckenna, which has been in progress in Daly's rooms, in Brooklyn, since last Monday, ended last evening in a victory for the former.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28.--The charming weather to-day induced a greater attendance at the Belmont Course than on any previous day of the meeting, about 1,000 persons being present. The track was in admirable order, the speculation brisk and the sport good, notwithstanding the favorite in each race proved victorious. Following are summaries:

NEW-ORLEANS, May 28.--For some time past a movement has been on foot to admit the Cotton Press Association into the Cotton Men's Council.
LONDON, May 28.--In the Mincing-lane markets sugar is dull. The prices of beet sugar are declining. Cane sugar is quiet. In refined there is a fall business in pieces and crystals.
The Sanitary condition of the Whitestone (Long Island) public school has led to the illness of many pupils and one teacher.

WASHINGTON, May 28,1886. The President to-day vetoed five more private pension bills, three of which originated in the House and two in the Ssenate.
The Norwegian bark Aquila left Rio Janeiro Feb. 11 for New-York in command of Capt. Stray.

There was no nonsense about the way the New-Jersey Prohibitionists finished the work of their convention at Newark yesterday. They adopted a platform that has strong language in it, and nominated Clinton B. Fisk for Governor. The convention was earnest and enthusiastic all day. No such assembly of Prohibitionists had ever before been held in the State.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 28.--After working a year to disentangle the affairs of bankrupt John H. Deane, of New-York, so far as they bore on Deane's relations with the American Home Mission society, the investigating committee made a report to-day, over which some members of the society grew quite warm. Many spoke and all were saddened.
"The Khedive" will be the name of Gilbert and Sullivan's next comic opera. It will probably be produced at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre about Nov. 1.

MERIDEN, Conn., May 28.--Katie Baker, the 2-year-old daughter of Robert Baker, who lives on South Broad-street, this city, was drowned Wednesday afternoon. The child was playing in the back yard of her father's place, and, tripping, fell into a washtub full of water. Her mother, who was but a few feet from her, reached the tub only to find her daughter dead.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 28.--Cigarmakers' Union No. 2 has demanded an increase in the scale of wages, in some cases amounting to $3.50 per 1,000.
RICHMOND, Va., May 28.--The election in this city yesterday has resulted in the over-- whelming defeat of the regular Democratic nominees.

SPRINGFIEID, Ill., May 28.--There is a lively war of words and an open rupture in this district, which may tend to decrease Congressman Springer's heretofore large majorities. The Illinois Freie Presse, the leading Democratic German paper of Central Illinois, took occasion a few days ago to criticise Congressman Springer for his ill-advised recommendations for Federal appointments.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28.--Bishop Stevens has issued a call for a special convention of this diocese of the Protestant Episcopal Church to elect an Assistant Bishop, the position which the Rev. Dr. Phillips Brooks recently declined.

WASHINGTON, May 28.--The leave of absence granted First Lieut. Edward S. Farron, Twenty first Infantry, has been extended to Oct. 1, and the leave of First Lieut. Nathanniel Wolfe, Second Artillary, has bean extended six months.
Some stockholders of the former Oregon Steam Navigation Company brought suit in the United States Circuit Court against the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company and Henry Villard.
The stockholders engaged in fighting the Missouri Pacific consolidation obtained $459,000 and discontinued their suit.
CINCINNATI, May 28.--The report of Williams, the expert accountant, of his examination of the books and records of the Hamilton County Infirmary was submitted to the County Commissioners to-day.

The grand stand on the St. George Ground at Staten Island looked almost deserted yesterday. There were about 300 persons there, but its immense size made the crowd, which had assembled to see the lacrosse teams of Princeton College and New-York University play a match in the intercollegiate championship series, appear very small. The Princetons were much the heavier men.
SAULT STE. MARLE, Mich., May 28.-- The steamer Ontario, of the Surnia Transportation Company, stranded on Green Island shoal, off Mississuaga, yesterday. The passengers were landed at Bruce Mines.
The Park Commissioners applied to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday for $5,000 to purchase a rhinoceros, the largest in captivity, being 11 feet long and 5 feet high.

The promised testimonial concert tendered to Signor del Puente took place at Chickering Hall last evening and was quite numerously attended. With the exception of Signor Giannini, for whose absence an apology was offered--the gossip of the lobbies attributing its cause, by the way, to the seizure of the tenor's garments, just as if he were an ordinary impresario--all the artists announced on the programme took part in the performance.

The last meeting of the special committee of the Chamber of Commerce to investigate the so-called disinfection of rags at this port was held yesterday afternoon at the Chamber of Commerce rooms. Besides the members of the committee, there were present Augustine Smith, Paul Hanneman, Health Officer Smith E.B. Bartlett, Elliott F. Driggs, B.F. Einstein and Prof. J.W. Pollock.

The Democratic State Committee has issued blanks for the organization of Democratic clubs throughout the State, and is sending out circulars urging that such clubs be formed and report for duty with the least possible delay. These circulars are dignified, in tone and vigorous in suggestion. They will have a tendency to stir up the Democrats of the State to more determined, and, what is better, to more systematic action.

CHICAGO, May 29.--After the opening of the Board of Trade to-day Secretary Stone announced from the balcony that all calls on John W. SCHENECTADY N.Y., May 29.--This morning Mrs. Elizabeth Carpenter, a widow, aged 88, went to get her weekly poor order from the Police Justice. CHICAGO, May 31.--At a meeting of the City Council to-night Mayor Harrison vetoed the ordinance passed immediately after the Haymarket massacre providing for the addition of 50 men to the police force. The Mayor held that there were no funds legally available for the payment of the new men. He also declared that recent events had shown there was no necessity for the appointment of additional police.

READING, Penn., June 8.--A number of the comrades who participated in the collation at the reunion of the Pennsylvania Reserves, in this city yesterday, were attacked with violent vomiting and purging an hour after, caused, it is said, by the green pickles and corned beef which they ate. Several physicians were summoned. All parties are out of danger this morning. The physicians declare it to be a case of poisoning.

WHEELING, W.Va., June 10.--The large woolen mlll of the Barnesville Manufacturing Company, at Barnesville, W. ADAMS, Mass., June 11.--Two sons of Edward Howland, 7 and 11 years old, started for school Wednesday morning, but did not reach there. LONDON, June 11.--The Crawford-Dilke divorce case was in court again to-day, on the issue of Sir Charles Dilke's right to have the Queen's Proctor re-open the case in order to enable the member for Chelsea to produce testimony in his own vindication.

HARTFORD, June 11.--Mr. William H. Barnum is making hay on these sunshiney days up here in Connecticut. His mind is set on the United States Senatorship, and he is bound to succeed Gen. Joe Hawley if there be any merit in Barnumese tactics, backed by lots of energy and cold cash.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 11.--At the Democratic State Convention, on the thirty-first ballot. Thomas Seay, for Governor, received a large majority over both competitors. The other names were then withdrawn, and he was nominated by acclamation.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 11.--Chief-Justice Park to-day gave his decision on the case of Attorney Charles S. Hamilton, of this city, who some months ago was suspended from practice in State courts for one year.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 11.--The Right Rev. Thomas Francis Hendricken died in his armchair at his home here this evening. He suffered with asthma for years.
The Polytechnic Institute team and the Nationals and the Ticonderogas and Bedfords will play championship games in the Metropolitan Amateur Junior Lacrosse Association series to-day at Prospect Park.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., June 11.--In Ohio County, Ky., yesterday, John Hunter, a negro, charged with stealing $18, was tried and convicted, and, as he had served three terms in the penitentiary before, the jury fixed his punishment at the full extent of the law--life imprisonment.

A shock of earthquake, lasting about one minute, was felt at Sandy Hook at midnight feet night. The tower of the signal station was shaken and the windows were rattled. The shook was also felt at Quarantine.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 11.--The Synod of the Reformed Church adjourned at noon to-day, to meet next year at Catskill, N. Y. The Synod declared in favor of temperance, but voted down a resolution trying to put it on record as in favor of prohibition. A committee of five was appointed to make overtures to the Reformed Church of the United States looking toward a union.

PARIS, Texas, June 11.--Officers captured a girl named Bettie Travis to-day near the town of Baird, 10 miles from here. She was a raving maniac when found and had taken possession of a corn crib on a farm near the town, and, armed with rifle and pistol, would allow no one to come near.

HAMILTON, Ontario, June 11.--The Grand Secretary of the Grand Masonic Lodge of Canada has received from the Grand Secretary of the order in England a jewel for Sir John Macdonald as the representative in Canada of the Grand Lodge in England. The jewel is an exceedingly handsome one. With it came a letter to the following effect:

ALBANY, June 11.--If anything further was necessary to disprove the wild story of a rupture between President Cleveland and Gov. Hill it could be furnished by a printed copy of the former's letter to the Governor concerning the celebration of Decoration Day in New-York and Brooklyn.
The sale of the B. Homer Dixon cabinet of arms and armor which began on Thursday at Leavitt's auction rooms on Broadway was concluded yesterday afternoon.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 11.--Wilson Waddingham, the millionaire, has bought Hamilton Park from the Trustees of the insolvent estate of Edward E. Hall, of the city. There are 51 acres in the park, and it is understood that the price paid was $60,000. It is not yet known to what uses the park will be put by Mr. Waddingham.
HARVARD, Ill., June 11.--The sale of his business by Charles Baltz, of Chicago, and the failure of W.A. Boles has precipitated the failure of Horton Gillis, of Bigfoot.
John Mazzanovich, the once famous scenic artist, lies buried in the Actors' Fund plot in the Cemetery of the Evergreens.

When asked if he intended to do anything in regard to Dr. Spitzka's dog experiments on Friday evening, Henry Bergh said yesterday that no comparison could be made between the New-Jersey cases and what Dr. Spitzka has done.
DANBURY, Conn., June 11.--Zachariah Wixon, aged 40, who lived, with his family, on Lake-avenue, started to walk into town last night.

The Lewiston Mills, manufacturers of cotton goods, ducks, osnaburgs, tickings, , at Lewiston Me., have suspended. The concern had a capital of $500,000.

AUGUSTA, Ga., June 11.--The strike in the Algernon Mill here turns out to be a serious affair, and unless the operatives return to work by noon on Monday all the mills in town will shut down, and over 3,000 workmen will be turned out of employment.

DETROIT, Mich., June 11.--The product of the Lake Superior copper mines for May was: Calumet and Hecla, 2,605 tons; Quiney, 261 tons; Franklin, 202 tons; Atlantic, 181 tons;...

The funeral of Mrs. Erminie A. Smith, who died on Wednesday at her home in Pacificavenue, Jersey City, took place yesterday from the Lafayette Reformed Church. The Rev. Dr. Duryea. Pastor of the church, conducted the services. The interment was at the New-York Bay Cemetery. The funeral was largely attended. The Daughters of AEsthetics, of which Mrs. Smith was the President, was largely represented. Several members of Sorosis were also present.

LITCHFIELD, Conn., June 11.--This famous Summer resort, the queen of all Connecticut towns, presents anything but an attractive appearance this afternoon with its business block gone and the smoke still rising from the ruins of some of its finest buildings.

Ludlow-Street Jail is not a pleasant summering place. Charles De Becker has been confined in it since Wednesday, and is anxious to get out. Miss Florence Smallcombe is the immediate cause of his enforced retirement.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 11.--In the Diocesan Council election for Assistant Bishop of Minnesota, the Rev. M.N. Gilbert, of St. Paul, was elected on the fourth ballot.

Bandmaster Harvey B. Dodworth met the men who were to have accompanied him to the State encampment at Peekskill, at Eckstein's saloon, in East Fourth-street, yesterday morning, and asked them to decide at once whether or not they would remain with him in spite of the Musical Mutual Protective Association.

FORT KEOGH, Montana, June 11.--A dispatch from Limestone, Idaho, says that four horse thieves, who had been hanging around for some time, were pounced upon by a party of vigilantes last Tuesday and hanged.

The rules and regulations for the twentyfirst anual regatta of the Atlantic Yacht Club, to be sailed on Tuesday next, were issued yesterday. A special class has been created for the sloops Puritan, Priscilla, Atlantic, and, if entered, the Mayflower.

Shut away from all civilized and healthy humanity, Father Damen has for years been a willing prisoner in the island, in which are collected and confined the lepers of all the neighbouring Sandwich group.

LITTLE ROCK, ARK., June 11.--The Republican State Central Committee has decided to call the Republican State Convention July 22, to consider the propriety of putting a Republican State ticket in the field.
The annual report of the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange was adopted yesterday as presented by President C.G. Wilson.

CHICAGO, June 11.--Mayor Harrison today opened a genuine boycott on the Chicago newspapers and has taken vigorous steps to make it effective.

The American Association, at its special meeting in Columbus on Wednesday, opened a new vista for the baseball world by taking steps to restore the game from its present development of a wrangle to its former state of an amusement.

The voice of the Presidential boomer is beginning to be heard in the land. It is again raised in behalf of Blaine, of Maine, in connection with that gentleman's recent speech on home rule for Ireland.

The twentieth anniversary of the Home for Incurables, at Fordham, was celebrated yesterday. A special train of three crowded cars carried up many visitors, while others, swelling the crowd to 300, drove thither from neighboring country seats. After a trip through the wards the company assembled in the new chapel at the west end, the gift of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin H. Field.

The attendance at the combination sale of thoroughbred stock at Madison-Square Garden yesterday was not large, and the eloquence of Mr. Easton was unavailing in bringing forth spirited bidding, except in the sale of the Spendthrift yearlings.
At the Brighton Beach track yesterday Daphne won the five-eights mile race for 2year-olds, with 101 pounds up, in 1:06 . Jennie June was second and Nat Goodwin third.
BELFAST, June 11.--The rioting last night was less disastrous than on Wednesday. After their day's labor had ended thousands of workingmen gathered in the vicinity of the Bowers Hill police barracks.

BOSTON, June 11--Guy O. Hunter, the stamp clerk of the Lowell Post Office, who was arrested Wednesday on the charge of stealing letters, was taken before United States Commissioner Hallett yesterday, and acknowledged his guilt. He was held in $2,000 for the June term of the District Court.
Amateur athletes will have a gala day at the grounds of the New-York Athletic Club, in Mott Haven, to-day. The members of the club have their eighteenth annual Spring games then and there.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 11.--The Cininnatis won to-day's game through superior fielding, McPhee played a good game at second and made two fine catches. Smith did well for the Pittsburgs in the same position.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 11.--The June meeting at the Hudson River Driving Park closed to-day with much enthusiasm. The meeting has been a success throughout, and has developed one important fact, that good racing, with able management, will succeed, notwithstanding...
LONDON, June 11.--In Mincing-lane the sugar market is depressed; beat is very fist; cane is dull of sale; refined is in fair demand at steady prices.
Adolph Ettinger was a member of a union of workingmen that boycotted Peter Doelger, the brewer.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 11.--Yesterday there arrived in the city from Limon, Costa Rica, a party of ladies and gentlemen, natives of that little and progressive republic, who are on their way to Europe by way of Washington.

Another great day's racing is promised at Sheepshead Bay to-day, as of the six races three are stake events, with animals of a high class to take part in them. The Brooklyn Stable will be strongly represented in all three of them, and as McLaughlin did not win a race on Thursday he will try hard to redeem himself.
BALTIMORE, June 11.--Henderson was reinstated to-day by the Baltimore management, and faced the Brooklyns in a very unsatisfactory manner. The visitors batted him freely.

AMHERST, Mass., June 11.--Amherst easily defeated the University of Pennsylvania to-day. They hit Ely terribly, making four hits, with a total of eight, in one inning.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 11.--The college championship game of baseball here to-day between the Williams and Princeton College Clubs resulted in a victory for Princeton by a score of 4 to 0.

PORTLAND, Me., June 11.--A committee representing the clergymen of Portland is obtaining the signatures of many druggists to a paper promising to close their stores from 10 A. M. to 5 P.M. on Sundays.
Gen. Paine, the spirited owner of the yatch Mayflower, belongs to an old and distinguished Boston family, known in Boston annals for over 150 years.

BOSTON, June 11.--Gov. Hill, of NewYork, will be the guest of the Bay State Club on Friday, June 18, at the Parker House.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 11.--The strike of the journeymen bakers employed in the 70 shops in this city, which has lasted 10 days, has ended, and the men returned to work to-night with nothing gained but what had been conceded them before they struck.
CHEYENNE, Wyoming, June 11.--A family named Armstrong, consisting of husband, wife, two sons, and one duughter, went up the Little Mountain Valley last Fall and settled.
Chief Engineer Robert B. Hine, the last of the officers lately attached to the Nipsic, received his detachment orders yesterday.

NORFOLK, Va., June 11.--A correspondent of the Virginian, writing from Seaboard, N.C., to-day, says that the heaviest rain fall known in years occurred there yesterday. The damage to crops is unparalleled. Cotton and corn were laid flat by the wind, and acres are under water and sand.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 12.--The California Sugar Refinery to-day announces a reduction of 1/8 cent per pound on all grades of sugar. By this reduction Cuba sugar is selling at 5 7/8 cents, the lowest figure ever reached here.
VALPARAISO, June 12. via Galveston.--A strong norther set in here last night, and at midnight there was a very heavy sea. Several vessels were lost.

It will arrive in Hartford at 5.30 o'clock. Copies of THE TIMES can be found regularly at all the drug stores. No sales of papers are allowed on the streets after 10 o'clock.

The Metropolitans played handsomely in their contest against the Athletics, at Staten Island, yesterday, and won a game by figures of 2 to 0. Lynoh was in good form, and his curves puzzled the batters of the visiting team to such an extent that they gained only two single hits.

The Sheep Killers' Union held a secret meeting in Canal-street yesterday morning. There are about 400 sheep killers in the union, which represents this city, Brooklyn, and NewJersey. The union boasts that every dexterous sheep killer in the territory mentioned is a member.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 12.--Four thousand people saw the Pittsburgs defeat the Cincinnatis today in an exciting contest. Mullane was put in to pitch for the home team, and was batted considerably.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 12.--Edward O'Gorman, a railroad laborer, disappeared from his house on Monday night. To-day his body was found in the canal. The Dead was nearly severed from the trunk. He was of dissipatd habits, 48 years old and leaves a widow and two children.

MUNICH, June 13.--King Ludwing to-day took his departure for Berg Castle, on Lake Starnberg. The scenes along the route of the journey were very affecting. The peasants knelt in the roadways weeping. The King responded to their greetings mournfully, but kindly. He looked pale and weary. The utmost precautions have been taken to prevent him from committing suicide.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 13.--The baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class of Brown University was delivered this afternoon by President Robinson. The text was "Thou shalt worship the Lord thy God, and Him only shalt thou serve." The sermon gave a clear and forcible definition of what constitutes true worship and the importance of consecration to the true worship of God.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, June 14--Robert Rose, of Berlin, Mahoning County, a veteran of the war of 1812, died last niget at the age of 104 years and 3 months. Up to three weeks before his death he was healthy, hearty, and able to do light labor about the farm.

CHARLESTON, S.C., June 14.--Robert Robinson, aged 16, of Wadesborough, died yesterday of hydrophobia after 24 hours suffering. He was bitten on the left arm by a mad dog two years ago, and a few days ago was stung by bees on the same arm.

EL PASO, Texas, June 14.--The Collector of Customs for this district has received information of an important capture made yesterday near Deming, New-Mexico. A band of Mexican smugglers was overhauled and surrounded. They had a dozen pack mules loaded with goods and were driving a large herd of horses and cattle, all of which had been smuggled across by a circuitous route. Five Mexicans were arrested and lodged in jail.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 14.--The funeral services of the late Mayor Doyle took place at the First Congregational Church this afternoon. At 12:30 o'clock a long procession of officials and prominent citizens was formed at the City Hall.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 14.--Harvard easily defeated Amherst this afternoon by the score of 10 to 0. Allan, the catcher, was injured in the third inning by splitting his finger. The change battery was then put in, and Smith struck out the Amherst men with the greatest of ease. It is hoped that Allan will recover in time for the Yale game next Saturday, but that is hardly probable.

BOSTON, Mass., June 14.--The Washingtons made their first appearance on the Southend Grounds to-day and took a game from the Bostons. Both batteries proved about equally effective. In the eighth inning the Washingtons bunched their hits, and, aided by a poor throw and several stupid plays by the home team, succeeded in scoring 5 runs.

Palmer's Madison-Square Theatre Company, of NewYork, was received by and large and very fashionable audience at McVicker's Theatre to-night on the opening of the second week of its season. "Saints and Sinners" was the play, and both company and piece were greeted with enthusiastic demonstrations of approval.

GALVESTON, Texas, June 14.--This island was visited by an exceedingly heavy storm last night. A gale set in at sundown, blowing from the east. It reached its height at 4 o'clock in the morning, when the wind registered a velocity of 50 miles per hour. Torrents of rain fell.

MEDFORD, Mass., June 14.--Class Day exercises were held at Tufts College to-day. The oration was delivered by H.H. Dunhnm, the class history address by F.K. Sweetzer, and the class poem by J.W. Carney. R.E. Joslin delivered the valedictory. The exercises were followed by "spreads" given by the graduates.

TRENTON, N. J., June 14.--Freta Arend, the 4-year-old daughter of Henry Arend, of No. 728 Prospect-street, was waving a small flag out of the seond-story window this evening as some Turners, who are holding a festival here, were going by. She lost her balance, and falling head foremost to the sidewalk below was instantly killed.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 14.--Capt. William Davis, for many years Superintendent of the Western and Atlantic Railroad, committed suicide on a Great Southern south-bound train last night by taking paris green. He leaves a large family, who can assign no cause for the deed.

Hendee, residing about three and a half miles south of Leroy, Greene Country, while driving home last evening were struck by the east-bound Delaware, Lackawanna and Western train, and were, together with their house, instantly killed. Hendee was a well-to-do farmer.

WASHINGTON, JUNE 14.--The McCaull Opera Comique Company opened the Summer season at the new National Theatre, Washington, to-night, with a performance of "The Mikado" to an overcroweded house, and a great number were turned away from the doors unable to obtain seats. TRENTON, N. J., June 14.--Jeremiah C. Bruton, a hotel keeper at Edinburg, six miles from here, was instantly killed at Princeton Junction at 4 o'clock this afternoon.

A suit was begun in the United States District Court yesterday, in which Gen. Thomas Jordan is interested. Gen. Jordan was a Captain and Quartermaster in the United States Army from 1841 to 1861. After the latter year he joined the Confederate Army and became a member of Gen. Beauregard's staff.

The triennial convention of the Bohemian Mutual and Death Benefit Lodges of the United States was opened yesterday morning at the Bohemian National Hall, in Fifthstreet, between Avenues B and C. There are at present 132 lodges in this order, which is 33 years old, and has a membership of 6,878.
QUEENSTOWN, June 14.--The National Line steamship Egypt, Capt. Summer, from New-York June 5 arr. here to-day.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 14.--several hundred delegates to the Republican State Judicial and Gubernatorial Convention have arrived. A ticket for the Supreme Bench will be nominated to-morrow and a candidate for Governor on Wednesday. The Hon. D.A. Nunn, of Haywood County, seems to be in the lead for the Gubernatorial nomination.

DANBURY, Conn., June 14.--John Murray, while crossing a pasture lot near this town yesterday came across a large blacksnake. His only weapon was a short stick, with which he struck at the "racer," which in return stung him on the back of one hand. Murray hurried home, and his friends filled him with as much whisky as he could hold.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 14.--Albert Joseph Young, a member of the Freshman Class in the Shefield Scientific School, died here this afternoon of typhoid fever. His home was in Evanston, Ill. His parents, who had been summoned East, were present at his deathbed.

LOUISVILLE, KY.,June 14.--A meeting of prominent residents of this city was held at the Galt House to-night at which resolutions were adopted to the effect that Louisville will form an auxiliary company and will subscribe $25,000 toward the capital stock of the American Opera Company.

Mrs. Lena, Salomon arrived at the Grand Central Station last evening with her three little children from Boston. Her husband was to have met her, but failed to do so, and, as the woman had no means and no friends in this city,the police took her and her children to Police Headquarters.

AUGUSTA, Ga., June 16.--There is a deep and well defined movement in the stock of the Georgia Central Railroad. A strong inquiry is made in home markets, and to-day a plan was developed showing that outside capitalists were trying to get possession of the property.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 16.--Yesterday articles of incorporation of the Columbia and Rensselaer Railroad Company were filed in the office of the Secretary of State, at Albany. The capital of the new corporation is $300,000.

NYACK, N.Y., June 16.--The beautiful little steam yacht Annie A., owned by Mr. Alexander Pollock, of Upper Nyack, was built and fitted up expressly for the use of Ferdinand Ward, who is now contemplating the things of the world through prison bars. Mr. Pollock purchased the yacht at private sale from the Receiver, Judge Holt, and has made many improvements in her. The boat is quite an object of curiosity on account of its history.

RACINE, Wis., June 16.--At 10:30 o'clock last night a dynamite bomb was hurled at the carriage way to ex-Mayor M.M. Secor's house. The bomb exploded with a report that startled the whole city. Mr. Secor drove over the fuse that exploded the bomb about 15 minutes previous to the explosion.

EAST TAWAS, Mich., June 16.--A terrific windstorm, accompanied by heavy rain, passed over here last night. It broke the United States signal staff, and leveled Richards Brothers' large block of stores being erected. Trees were blown down and a large quantity of lumber was blown into the bay. Tne residence of James Shaw was moved bodily off its foundation and carried nearly five feet.

CHICAGO, June 16.--There are no indications that the Western and Northwestern passenger war will soon come to an end. No direct cuts have been made during the last 24 hours, but considerable skirmishing is going on and there is no telling where lightning will strike next.

CHICAGO, June 16.--Only 18 of the 67 police officers wounded at the Haymarket riot have returned to duty. Seven men have died, four are in a critical condition, and two of these will probably die. Twelve others are still unable to leave their beds, and 42 in all have not reported for duty.

This will be the semi-centennial of the First Reformed Church of this place, and an elaborate programme is being prepared for the event, in which all the people here feel an interest.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 16.--The boycott conspiracy cases brought by the NewHaven Journal and Courier against Benjamin F. Glidden, John F. Busche, Thomas F. Mulcahy, and David T. McNamara came up in the City Court to-day.

The piano factory of Augustus Baus Co., at No. 251 East Thirty-third-street, was burned out early last evening and its contents were destroyed. The progress of the flames was so rapid that the 25 or 30 workmen in the factory had to fly for their lives.
The Brazilian Prince and the naval officers who are with him made a trip to Mount Vernon to-day accompanied by Commander McCalla, United States Navy, and Chief Clerk Brown, of the State Department.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 16.--Superintendent Sherwood, of the Dominion police, has returned from Quebec where he accomplished a mission on behalf of the Department of Justice, arresting an English fugitive embezzler named Griffith Lewis, alias John Hughes.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 16.--The biggest, hottest, and most destructive fire that New-Haven has seen for years broke out this morning, and before it was under control one of the largest establishments in the city was gutted.

WASHINGTON, June 16.--At a convenient hour to-morrow Mr. Morrison will ask the House to take up the Tariff bill. He does not expect that the House will consent to take it up. For months, as he says himself, be has known that he was beaten.

CHICAGO, June 16.--John Slavin is in the county jail, charged by Rebecca Fullen with illegitimate parentage. The woman says that a month ago, finding herself soon to become a mother, she set out a foot from her home in Buffalo, N.Y., to find Slavin, who, she learned, was living in this city.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 16.--At 10 o'clock this morning the State Republican Gubernatorial Convention was called to order in the hall of the House of Representatives, and in less than five hours had nominated a candidate for Governor, adopter a platform, listened to addressee, and adjourned sine die.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 15.--As each class graduates from Yale, one of its number, known as the statistician, issues a pamphlet giving as much information about his classmates as they have been willing to confide to him.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 16.--At a mass meeting of the miners of the Third District, held here to-day, a strike throughout the district was ordered. This is a case where arbitration was a failure. The Board of Arbitrators appointed by the miners and operators over a month ago at first fixed the price of mining at 67 cents.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 16.--The weather was warm and threatening to-day, and very heavy rains fell after the second race. The tracks was slow and the attendance moderate. Following were the events:

Starin's Glen Island was opened for the season yesterday. The day was hardly hot enough to drive people to the pleasant resort on the Sound in great numbers, but there was a good gathering there and all seemed to enjoy themselves thoroughly. The sail up the Sound was delightful.

Joel B. Erhardt, Receiver of the NewYork City and Northern Railroad Company, reports the earnings of that company for the 10 days ending June 10 as $15,397.50, an increase of $2,638.61 over the same period of last year.

CINCINNATI, June 16.--The fear that others will follow the example of Infirmary Director Herrmann in "squealing" as to the doings of the municipal plunderers and ballot box stuffers, is becoming too great for the guilty to disguise.

Josef Echteler, of No. 110 River-terrace, Hoboken, has just completed a design for a monument to Gen. Grant. His design represents a monument 18 feet in height, surmounted by an equestrian figure of Gen. Grant.

As Uncle Rufus Hatch lounges in the room of the City Court, in which the suit of Brewster Co. against him is on trial, he looks to a distant observer startlingly like Gen. Butler. His face is as full and round and his big head is as destitute of hair.

There has been a temporary lull in the controversy among the barbers, but it is not the lull which presages tho coming of peace. NEWBURG, June 16.--Charles A. Douglas, Cashier of the First National Bank, of Middletown, N.Y., was married this evening to Miss ah M. Puffer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A D. Puffer.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 16.--The Governor has signed the act promoted by Erastus Wiman and others, amending the law regarding imprisonment for debt. Hereafter six months is to be the limit Of imprisonment on arrests in civil actions, and the operation of the law releases within five days all prisoners in Ludlow-Street Jail, New-York, and elsewhere who have been incarcerated beyond six months.

The funeral of Mrs. Margaret O'Leary, wife of Dr. C.M. O'Leary, for many years a Professor of Manhattan College, was held at the Church of the Annunciation, at One Hundred and Thirty-first-street and the Boulevard, yesterday morning.

BUSHNELL, Ill., June 16.--A furious wind storm this afternoon, accompanied by rain and hail, flattened to the ground, Wallace Co.'s circus canvas, injuring about 30 people, several dangerously. Fences and tress were blown down and considerable damage done to the growing crops.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 16.--About 20 years ago a maiden lady named Susan A. Hoffman, then 25 years of age, came to Elmira from Virginia. She was an eccentric person, was full of the Southern spirit that prevailed at that time, and became possessed of the idea that the people of the North were her enemies and would eventually murder her.

The Dayton Journal, one of the ablest Republican papers in Ohio, has the following in regard to the nomination of Mr. Blaine: "We have great admiration for Blaine, but we don't want to run a serious risk of another defeat of the Republican Party. We know that the issue with Mr. Blaine at the head of the ticket would be doubtful."

SANTIAGO, June 16, via Galveston.--During the elections here yesterday a great riot occurred. Forty persons were killed and many wounded. The hospitals are full of injured persons. Senor Dinator, a prominent member of the Radical Party, was killed. The result of the elections is supposed to be in favor of the Liberals.
ITHACA, N.Y., June 16.--Notwithstanding the fact of the Kappa Alpha reception Monday evening the armory last night was the scene of one of the finest balls ever given in Ithaca.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., June 16.--Six wearied gentlemen alighted in the Boston and Albany station, in Boston, at 6:30 o'clocK this morning, rubbing their eyes and languidly looking at one another. They had had a hard night of it.

James Connors, a laborer, who says that he was once in the employ of Samuel J. Tilden, was arrested on Tuesday at No. 207 East Twentieth-street for following and annoying Annie Millett, or Connors, of No. 243 West Thirtythird-street.
HAVANA, June 16.--In a railroad accident near Macagua yesterday, caused by a train running off the track, 14 persons were wounded.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 16.--The Remsen-Avenue Baptist Church has extended a call to the Rev. J.M. Bruce, of Hudson, N.Y.

Those who many think that Troubadour is the equal of Miss Woodford will have an opportunity of seeing him tried to-day without waiting for a match to be arranged. Both are announced to start for the Coney Island Cup, one mile and three-quarters, together with such great long-distance horses as Eole and barnum.

TORONTO, June 16.--Sunday afternoon John and Frederick Miller and Alfred Frost started out in a sailboat from Toronto for a port a few miles west on Lake Ontario. Yesterday the boat drifted ashore at Mimico, west of this city, with the dead body of John Miller in it.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 16.--Passengers on the Erie Railroad passing over the great Chester onion meadows at night between Greycourt and Chester are attracted by myriads of lights that gleam in all directions over the meadows. There are hundreds of them.

MONTPELIER, Vt., June 16.--The early proceedings in the State Republican Convention to-day were tame and uneventful. Contrary to general expectation, Lieut.-Gov. E.J. Ormsbee was nominated for Governor on the first ballot.

BALTIMORE, June 16.--The first wheat of the crop of the present year was offered on 'Change to-day. It was grown in the Rappahannock region of Virginia, and sold for 80 cents per bushel. The small lot was of the Fultz variety, and very green and wet.

PITTSBURG, June 16.--The conference committee of the iron manufacturers signed the scale of the Amalgamated Convention this evening, and the iron mills throughout the country will run another year without stopping through labor troubles.

ALBUQUERQUE, New-Mexico, June 16.-- Middleton Ogdon committed suicide at San Philipe on Monday. He arrived Sunday night from El Paso, but did not show any symptoms of mental trouble, though he wanted to get a doctor.

GALVESTON, Texas, June 16.--The Gulf, Colorado and Santa Fe Railway system has been formally turned over to its new purchasers, the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Company. PORTLAND, Me., June 16.--The preliminary meetings of the State Prohibitory Convention were held here today. The day was passed in prayer and speechmaking, preparatory to the more serious business of the convention to-morrow.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 16.--The one hundred and sixteenth annual Commencement of Rutgers College Grammar School occurred to-night. Arthur Spaulding was valedictorian and Robert Schmidt, of Egg Harbor, class leader. There was 19 graduates, 17 of whom will enter Rutgers College. The committee awarded to Alexander Van Wagoner, of Paterson, N.J., the prize for being the best speaker.
LONDON, June 16.--Lord Hartington has issued a manifesto to the Rossendale electors. He says: "I regret the loss of the confidence of the majority of the Liberal Council.

PARIS, June 16.--The Senate Committee on the expulsion bill has elected M. Barthelemy Saint-Hilaire President.
The New-York Society for the Prevention of Contagious Diseases has been recently incorporated, with Dr. Herman Loewenthal as President, Dr. John Alsdort Secretary, and John J. Bowes Treasurer.

The grounds of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, at Mountain Station, Orange, N.J., were thronged yesterday by fashionable people, and any number of handsome carriages lined the roadway around the grounds. Many people remaitied in their carriages and witnessed the games in ease and comfort.

LONDON, June 16.--The House of Commons reassembled to-day for the transaction of nothing but absolutely necessary business. The attendance was small and the opening proceedings were uninteresting, it having been expected that here would be no opposition to passing the Appropriation bill.

The forty-first annual regatta of the NewYork Yacht Club will be sailed to-day by a large fleet of yachts, including the four big sloops. Instead of creating a special class for those big racers, as was done by the Atlantic Club, this club has added another to its regular stoop classes.

District Attorney Martine has become very tired of hearing the question, "Which of the boodle Aldermen will you next try?" Although he declines to disclose his plans to the public it is believed that he will next try a bribe giver.

The Brooklyn Academy of Music was crowded last night with people who seemed deeply interested in the Commencement exercises of the Brooklyn Collegiate and Polytechnic Institute. Orations were delivered varying in subject matter from Russian aggression to heroism in the discharge of duty.

ALBANY, June 16.--Attorney-General O'Brien listened this afternoon to arguments in the application for him to take such action as may be necessary to have determined the right to office of the Commissioners of Excise in New-York City. John H. Strahan appeared as counsel for the old Commissioners and Elliot Sandford for the gentlemen claiming to be Excise Commissioners, but did not oppose the action asked for.

At the meeting of the Aqueduct Commissioners yesterday Chief Engineer Church submitted a report in answer to a resolution of the commission at its last meeting requesting information as to the quality of the cement used in the construction of certain parts of the new aqueduct.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 16.--The funeral of Corlos Mauran, better known as Harry Bloodgood, took place here yesterday afternoon according to the Episcopal form. There was a large attendance, including a sprinkling of theatrical people. The interment took place in Swan Point-Cemetery.

BEAUMONT, Texas, June 16.--Ever since the big gale of Sunday night and Monday morning, there has been a great deal of apprehension here regarding the situation of affairs at Sabine Pass. All railroad and telegraphic communication with Sabine has been cut off since Sunday night.

CINCINNATI, June 16.--Frank Strichler, Richard Clark, and Edward Ladd have been arrested for passing counterfeit silver. A quantity of counterfeit money was found on Strichler and Clark. The last named confessed that he made the money at his room, where dies and coin were found. He claimed to be a machinist from St. Louis.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 16.--Late last night a middle-aged man, who gave the name of Christ A. Strang, a tailor by trade, applied at a police station for a night's lodging. From his appearance and the story he told it was decided that he was out of his mind.

James B. Shevil sued Lawyer Sidney V. Lowell in the County Court, in Brooklyn, yesterday, to recover the half of $432.51, the amount of a verdict awarded his father, James Shevil, who had brought suit to recover an excese of assessment paid on the improvement of Flushing-avenue.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 16.--The Northwestern Miller says of the flour production and market: Notwithstanding the excessively hot weather of last week, which hindered rapid work, the output of the mills showed a small gain.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., June 16.--The strike of the cooks and waiters ended last night, the restaurant owners agreeing to modify the objectionable rules to meet the views of the strikers and to make 11 hours a day's work, instead of 13 as heretofore.

A train which left the Grand Central Station at 5:18 o'clock last evening was stopped at Seventy-second-street by the disabling of the engine, and it was delayed an hour and five minutes. About 300 persons were in the cars bound for White Plains and intermediate stations.

READING, Penn., June 17.--Jacob Weller, who quite recently received $1,700 back pension money from the Government, and who was a boarder at Yoder's Hotel, at Lobachsville, was strangled to death at the supper table yesterday, a piece of meat having lodged in his windpipe. He was 62 years old.

LONDON, June 17.--The Greenland seal fisheries have been an entire failure.

The annual Commencement of the Ursuline Academy, at East Morrisania, was held in the large hall of the institution yesterday afternoon.
PARIS, June 17.--If the Senate passes the Expulsion bill M. Waddington will resign the French Ambassadorship at London, and other French Ambassadors will do likewise.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 17.--The Louisvilles were defeated this afternoon in an interesting contest. Good fielding and free batting made the game lively from beginning to end.

Holders of the income and land grant mortgage bonds of the Texas and Pacific Railway Company received a report yesterday from their recently appointed committee which was charged with inquiring into the rights of this class of securities in the matter of the company's proposed reorganization.

Evidence corroborative of the theory that Winfield B. Thompson, who shot his wife and himself at the Sturtevant House on Tuesday because he was out of money, appeared yesterday upon an examination of the young man's effects at the Sturtevant House.
The new North German Lloyd steamship Trave was inspected by the public yesterday at her dock in Hoboken. Crowds visited her, notwithstanding the frequent heavy showers.
The Juniata sent the link block of her engine to the machine shop yesterday morning for repair. It will take about four days to finish the job.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., June 17.--The Rev. Kenloch Nelson, of the Alexandria Theological Seminary, has declined to accept the Bishopric of the Diocese of Easton, to which he was elected on the 2d inst. He is the third minister who has declined after being elected.

CHICAGO, June 17.--Maria P. Storey, the first wife of Wilbur F. Storey, who secured a divorce on the ground of desertion in the year 1868--21 years after she married him--has at last taken a hand in the litigation of the Storey estate on her own account.
STILLWATER, Minn., June 17.--An immense log jam occurred in the St. Croix at Taylor's Falls, 30 miles north of Stillwater, last Sunday, which continues to grow at the rate of 700,000 feet per hour.

NORFOLK, Va., June 17.--The mystery surrounding the disappearance of Miss May Hatch from her home in Baltimore last Monday has been cleared up. Miss Hatch came here Tuesday on the steamship Chatham, of the Merchants and Miners' Line.
RALEIGH, N.C., June 17.--The wheat, oat, and rye crops were never better in this State than now.

LANCASTER, Penn., June 17.--Henry C. Trout, who has been employed as ashpit man by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company at Leaman Place for some time, was killed near that station last night and his body was found on the track this morning with the skull crushed. It is not known how the accident happened. Trout was 42 years old and unmarried, but supported his mother. The body was sent to his home near Belimont.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 17.--A very important bill which has hitherto escaped public attention has been signed by Gov. Hill. The bill possesses interest to all officers of justice in the entire State.
PARIS, June 17.--The Senate committee has rejected by a vote of 6 to 3 all proposals for the expulsion of the Princes.

With a view to hunting up American defaulters who have taken refuge on this side of the line 45, a Free Press correspondent has made the round trip. The police authorities have been seen, and from them everything learned which they considered it prudent to tell.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., June 17.--The boat race advertised to take place this afternoon on Chautauqua Lake between Griffin, of Buffalo, and Enright, of Toronto, for $1,000, was postponed on Enright's account, he having eaten too late and hearty a dinner. The attending spectators were thoroughly disgruntled.

A beautiful and lifelike picture of a child, which may be referred to as notably successful because of the felicitous reproduction of a child's expression--one of the most difficult things for a portrait painter to achieve--is now of view at Goupil's.

WEST MIDDLESEX, Penn., June 17.--The dry goods and grocery store of W.B. Burnett, established 25 years ago, was closed to-day by the Sheriff. The assets are $15,000; liabilities not stated. The failure was caused by the suspension of Veach's bank on Tuesday.

It will surprise many, and may interest a few, of your readers to learn that there died at Moffat, on the 13th of last month, a veritable, though illegitimate, daughter of the poet Burns. The old lady in question, Helen Armstrong by name, who was 97 or 98 years of age, resided for many years in Moffat, in the same little back street in which she was born somewhere about the year 1788.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 17.--The nomination of the Hon. A.A. Taylor, of East Tennessee, by the Stace Republican Gubernatorial Convention will, it is generally believed, cause the Democrats to select as his opponent a strong man from the same section.

DANA, Ind., June 17.--Two 6-year-old boys, one a child of H. Wells and the other the son of J.L. Herr, while playing in a bin of shelled corn in an elevator, to-day, were caught in a vortex of sinking grain and smothered.

RALEIGH, N.C., June 17.--Peace and quiet usually rule in this tree-shadowed town, broken only by the thunder of railway trains and the occasional assault of some overbold comic opera company. But just now the place is writhing in an agony of legal doubt. Men are going about with an expression of pain and anxiety on their faces and a gnawing at their hearts.

LONDON, June 17.--Mr. Gladstone started this morning at 11 o'clock on his Scotch campaign. He was accompanied by Mrs. Gladstone. Thousands of people congregated at the railway station to witness his departure. The crowd was simply enormous.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 17.--Mrs. Albert J. Hart, who has been making a visit in Florence, Mass., came back to this city to-night and began a vigorous search for her husband. A few days ago Hart went to his neighbors in tears and told them that his wife was dead.

BELAIR, Md., June 17.--Caleb Spicer, a farmer, 62 years of age, living near this place, last night came to town and indulged freely in liquor. He returned home at an early hour this morning and began abusing his wife.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 17.--The TyrantVolante race set for to-morrow is now regarded as certain to occur. It has been thought by the horsemen attending the races here that the race would never take place, and this opinion has been strengthened by the non-appearance of Haggins's flyer, which up to a day or two ago has been quartered at Sheepshead Bay.

Quebec furnishes a beautiful instance of the operation of the protective system. A tax was imposed on Lennoxville bakers seeking orders in Sherbrooke, and the former village will now impose a tax on Sherbrooke bakers delivering bread in Lennoxville. Each village will thus be amply protected against the other, and the happy people will be secured in the privilege of paying the tax in the enhanced prices of their bread.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 17.--Vincent, the 2-year-old son of City Auditor Bernard Keating, yesterday got hold of some carbolic acid which had been used in polishing furniture and swallowed some of the poison. He died last night.

BOSTON, June 17.--Boston's chief pride is in her schools. Boston's schools are managed by a School Committee. That is a fact about which there is no question. Is the School Board the best method for managing these schools? That is a fact about which there is much question.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., June 17.--This afternoon the Common Council granted the right of way to the Street Railway Company, though only after three days and nights of manoeuvring which included several very lively tilts. Mayor Price and the Council had to back down, and that portion of the public that patted them on the back for tearing up the company's track now berates them for their weakness. The track will be completed at once.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 17.--The twentieth anniversary of Hudson River Lodge, No. 607, F. and A.M., was celebrated at Masonic Hall, Newburg, last evening.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 17.--John Burnett, a farmer aged 68 years living at York, 15 miles south of here, went to the house of his mother-in-law, Mrs. Jackson, where he shot and mortally wounded his wife and also shot and seriously wounded Mrs. Jackson. He was arrested. His wife was 35 years old and had left him. He was jealous of her.

PORTLAND, Me., June 17.--The Prohibition Convention was called to order this morning by the Rev. Mr. Parks, of Presque Isle. The temporary organization of yesterday was made permanent, and a number of Vice-Presidents were chosen.

Among the battle-scarred veterans of the civil war who went from Maine is John F. Chase, of Augusta. He was a rugged farmer's bov, 18 years of age, when prompted by a sense of loyalty, he rallied to his country's defense. He was the fifth one who enlisted in this State under the first call for troops in 1861.
LONDON, June 17.--Honorary degrees were conferred upon Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes at Cambridge to-day in the presence of a brilliant assemblage.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 17.--The eighteenth annual Commencement of Cornell University occurred here to-day. There were 83 graduates. Eleven advanced degrees were conferred. For the first time in the history of the institution the degree of LL. D. was conferred.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 17.--Dr. Virgil D. Thompson, the insane Fallsburg dentist, who disappeared from New-York three weeks ago and again after he had been found, was discovered at Ellenville this afternoon. His friends have been sent for, and as he is detained it is expected that he will this time be safely returned to his home or otherwise taken care of.

While Guatemala boasts more ruined aboriginal cities, Central Honduras was once the scene of a high condition of civilization. Near the source of the winding Chemelicon, on the left bank of the river, are situated the ruins of Copan, the capital of a great and powerful aboriginal kingdom.

DETROIT, Mich., June 17.--Both Conway and Getzein were hit freely to-day, but the former's support was miserable, while that of the latter was perfect. The catcher for Detroit was Gansell, and for Kansas City Hackett.
The Commencement exercises of the Drew Ladies' Seminary, at Carmel, N.Y., were begun on Sunday evening last, when President Smith delivered the Baccalaureate sermon in the Methodist Episcopal church.

ERIE, Penn., June 17.--Miss Nellie McBrier and Mr. Marias Duvall, of Baltimore, were married to-night in the presence of the leading representatives of Pittsburg, Baltimore, Chicago, and Philadelphia society. The bride is the danghter of James McBrier, the most prominent lumber merchant and lumber vessel owner on the chain of lakes.

The President has approved the act for the relief of Chester A. Arthur and William H. Robertson and the act authorizing the construction of a bridge across the Staten Island Sound known as Arthur Kill, and to establish the same as a post road.

It is currently reported that the signing by Gov. Hill of the bill amending the law relating to imprisonment for debt has created as much joy among debtors as it has sorrow among creditors, but not more. There are several claimants for the credit of having pushed the measure to a successful issue.

Edward Knox threw a bombshell into the camp of the Committee of One Hundred last night in one of the parlors of the Murray Hill Hotel. Mr. Knox's bombshell was a resolution to the effect that no one should be eligible as a member of the committee if a candidate for any office of if he carried a candidate in his pocket.

FORT WORTH, Texas, June 17.--A Judge and jury in a Texas District Court have found a man guilty of stealing his own horse, and sent him to the penitentiary for twelve years. It is a most remarkable case.

Controller Loew yesterday opened proposals, in the presence of his colleagues on the Sinking Fund Commission, for $2,000,000 of additional water stock of the city, exempt from city and county taxation, redeemable in 1904.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 17.--The Cornell crew will not row at Philadelphia for the Childs Cup this year as expected, on account of lack of funds, there being but $25 in Commodore Hyat's hands with which to maken four hundred-dollartrip.

MONTREAL, June 17.--At the annual meeting of the Merchants' Bank George Haughe, the General Manager, warned traders against speculating in New-York and Chicago, by which many were rained every year, and counseled young men to devote their energies to taking up land in the Northwest in preference to engaging in business.

OLYMPIA, Washington Territory, June 17. --The trial of Hetzel, Gooding, Bales, and Jones, under indictment for conspiracy in connection with the anti-Chinese agitation last February, began here Monday. PANAMA, June 10.--The late civil and military chief of this department of the republic has been succeeded in his office by Senor Don Amados Guerrero, a gentleman much esteemed and highly popular.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., June 18.--The schooner Laura L. Rose, Capt. Lorrin N. Willis, picked up the body of a woman about 12 miles south by west of Block Island. She was about 20 years of age, dressed in a large brown yesterday dress. On several pieces of her clothing was found the name "M. Hatch."

Visitors to ex-Alderman Henry W. Jaehne, in Sing Sing Prison, report that he has gained 11 pounds in flesh since his admission to the prison. His appetite is good and he sleeps well. He is very anxious, notwithstanding the benefit to his health which imprisonment confers upon him, to quit the place at the earliest possible moment, and expects that the Court of Appeals will grant him a new trial.

The steamer Celtic has just undergone extensive improvements that have added much to the comfort of the passengers. The sixteenth Corinthian race of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club will be sailed to-day over the the club course. The course for the first, second, and third class sloops and schooners is the same as that of the New-York Yacht Club, except that it begins below instead of above the Narrows.
NEWBURG, N.Y., June 18.--The man who committed suicide in the old Mount Ida Cemetery, near Troy, has just been identified as Hugh O'Donnell, a former hotel proprietor at Wallkill, Ulster County.

The grounds of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, at Mountain Station, N.J., were yesterday visited by a large number of people to witness the contests in the open lawn tennis tournament. Owing to the rain of Thursday the playing off of the finals was postponed until to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18.--There was an uncommonly interesting session to-day in the proceedings before Examiner Pollock in the suit of William R. Robinson, of New-York, to foreclose the Reading general mortgage.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., June 18.--The Grand Lodge of the Ancient Order of United Workmen visited Minneahaha and St. Paul by special train, had a ride about the latter city, and a banquet in the evening.

The graduating exercises of Grammer Scool No. 3 took place yesterday afternoon. The school room was crowded.

Margaret Guyon was on trial in Part II. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday on a charge of receiving stolen goods. The case was ended early in the afternoon, and the jury retired to a separate room.

The July number of the Magazine of Art has for its leading engraving a wood cut of W.H. Weatherhead's "Chelsea Pensioners." This work attracted marked attention at the Royal Institute exhibition this year. The wood cut is excellent.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 18.--Col. G.N. Tillman to-day forwarded to President Cleveland his resignation as United States Marshal for the Middle Districts of Tennessee.
PHILADELPHIA, June 18.--George Coard Charles, an actor, committed suicide in the lodging house at No. 236 North Ninth-street last night and his body was discovered at about 9 o'clock this morning.
WHEELING, West Va., June 18.--On April 25 last James Sturms, a popular young man of Calhoun County, was murdered by Samuel Sickles and his father, James Sickles.

Henry Ward Beecher bade his congregation farewell last evening. He sails for Europe to-day on the steamer Etruria, and will remain abroad about three months.

Mrs. Landgraf has decided to wash her hands of the bakery business and let the Bohemian boycotters have the victory. Her receipts yesterday were 75 cents and the day before only $2. The United Order of American Carpenters and Joiners held their third annual picnic and Summer night's festival yesterday at Sulzer's Harlem River Park. A large number of trades unionists came up to visit the carpenters and joiners.

Justin Wohlfarth yesterday obtained from a jury before Judge Larremore a verdict for $1,500 in a suit against Ward B. Chamberlin to recover damages for a breach of contract. The suit was on trial for three days.

The new apse of the Lateran Basilica was inaugurated yesterday with much pomp. BOSTON June 18.--The oldest citizen of Boston does not remember ever having seen a Governor of New-York in the Bay State. A Governor once ventured across the line, and some of the histories preserve any but fragrant memories of his visit.

DETROIT, Mich., June 18.--The Rev. F.L. Hayes, Pastor of a large Boston church, has been elected to the Presidency of Hillsdale College, in this State, which has been vacant for a year past.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 18.--Fire broke out at about midnight to-night in the shops of the Missouri Car and Foundry Works. The flames, owing to the inflammable nature of the contents of the building, spread rapidly despite the firemen's efforts. The works were almost completely destroyed. The loss is estimated between $150,000 and $200,000; partially covered by insurance.

AMHERST, Mass., June 19.--Amherst was defeated by Williams here to-day by 11 to 5. Williams bunched her hits and took advantage of Amherst's errors, while her own errors were not costly.

Wall-street is feeling cheerful. Bull points have been distributed plentifully during the past two weeks, and in only one or two instances have they failed to prove good ones. Business has been quite brisk, and there is a fairly broad market.

PORTLAND, Me., June 19.--Timothy Wade, a section hand, was cut in twain by a shifting engine in the Grand Trunk Railroad yard here to-day. He was surrounded by brother workmen at the time, but none of his companions know of the accident until Wade's dead body was found.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 19.--Mr. William H. Granby, a prospector, yesterday discovered a jet of natural gas near Knowersville, 17 miles from this city, at the foot of the Helderberg Mountains. The gas was obtained by bailing out a spring and inserting a pipe where the water entered. A flame sufficient to heat water to the boiling point was produced.

RUTLAND, Vt., June 19.--David J. O'Hearne, one of the village Trustees, who keeps a grocery store here, was convicted yesterday of selling liquor, and fined on 93 counts. His fines and the costs will amount to over $1,200. The prosecution is probably the outcome of a political controversy.

NEWPORT, R.I, June 19.--The funeral of the late George Tiffany was a very notable event, but everything was conducted in a quiet and unostentatious manner. It took place at Trinity Church, the Rev. G.G. Magill officiating. The Health Home is intended for the reception of sick infants, and will be open during the Summer months.

TOMBSTONE, Arizona, June 19.--Word has been received at Fort Huachuca, from Capt. Lawton, who has been following the hostiles in Sonora, that he was driving the band before him, and that the Indians were making their way to their stronghold in the Sierra Madres. Robinson, and has received $2,600 damages from the railroad company for his injures.

An interesting archaeological discovery has been made in the interior of the city of Vienna. A dog fell into an opening at the halfdemolished Jesuit monastery. While efforts were being made to rescue the dog a large vault containing 90 coffins was discovered. From tablets, on the coffins it was found that the Jesuit brothers and the nobles supporting the order during the greater part of Maria Theresa's reign were buried in this vault.

BRUSSELS, June 14.--The distance from Belgium's beautiful capital to the battlefield of Waterloo is about 10 miles. On the evening of June 15, 1815, when the officers of the allied armies were tripping around the ballroom of the Duchess of Richmond, and the rank and file were snoozing quietly in their respective billets, few of the peaceful inhabitants of Brussels knew how far it was to Waterloo.

PEEKSKILL, June 26.--Shortly after 3 o'clock this afternoon the steamer Henry E. Bishop slowed up at the little landing place at Roa Hook, and in a few minutes 782 men of the Eleventh and Thirty-second Regiments were struggling up the steep dusty road leading to the State camp on the heights above.

A member of a Kansas firm of horse dealers has just purchased 56 Clydesdale stallions for 15,000 from Mr. Riddell, the owner of the famous Blackhall stud in Renfrewshire. He has also bought a number of French horses for exportation to America.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., June 26.--A special from Meedville, Penn., on Friday night gave a rumor that a mortge on the Titusville Morning Herald had been foreclosed and the paper had permanently suspended. No mortgage has been foreclosed; the Herald has not suspended, and there is not the remotest probability of it so doing.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 27.--President Porter preached his last Baccalaureate sermon in the Battell Chapel this morning, and every seat in the building was occupied by the members of the Faculty, the students, and their friends. The steam yacht Corsair, bearing the Presidential party, arrived here at 1 o'clock this afternoon from her cruise down the Potomac and Chesapeake Bay. The party are all well, and state that the trip was a very enjoyable one. They did not land at all, and did very little fishing. The President is very much sunburned, and his appearance indicates that he has been benefited by the short vacation.

William H. Doble, the turfman, was 70 years old on Saturday, and celebrated the event at his roadhouse at the westward of Fairmount Park. Saturday was also the fourteenth anniversary of the day upon which Doble drove Goldsmith Maid at Mystic Park, when that famous trotter made her fast record and the fastest time ever made up to that date.

For more than 35 years Ogden Hoffman has filled, and ably filled, the positton of District Judge on the Pacific coast. During all these years cases of great magnitude have been before him, cases in which, had he been a corrupt or unjust Judge, he might have made a fortune.

LONDON, June 27.--In Ireland 77 Parnellite candidates will meet with no opposition and 7 seats will be contested. In London 9 Tory seats will not be contested. In Scotland Unionists and Conservatives will contest 60 out of 72 seats.

CHICAGO, June 27.--The session of the Third Presbyterian Church, of Chicago, has decided to recommend to the congregation at a meeting to be held on Wednesday that the Rev. J.L. Withrow, of Boston, be invited to fill the place made vacant by the departure of Dr. Kittredge.

Sending out homing pigeons from shipboard 109 miles at sea with messages for friends on shore is no doubt an interesting proceeding, and the interest is heightened by the news that the gallant voyagers of the air have safely reached their destination. But when we consider that the poor castaways must fly for it or drown a tinge of cruelty appears in the performance at the starting point.

MILTON, Penn., June 27.--Robert Hillands and wife, of Chillisquaque, aged 60 and 50 years, respectively, were instantly killed by the newspaper train at the Mahoning-street railroad crossing this morning while on their way to church. Their horse was badly injured and their carriage was broken into splinters.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 27.--Louis Cscanyan escaped from the Hudson River State Hospital at 3 o'clock this afternoon. Tonight a man fully answering his description bought a ticket at Staatsburg for Rhinebeck and boarded the train going north at that place about that time.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 27.--William Brady, a tough character, was found lying near a saloon at the corner of Lazelle-street and Third-avenue at 2 o'clock this morning, with a pistol-shot wound through his head, and died soon after his discovery.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 27.--A.V. Wandle, for several years train dispatcher for the Eastern Division and branches of the Erie Railroad at Jersey City, has retired from the position and is to run as conductor on the Port Jervis milk train.
NEW-ORLEANS, June 27.--The Senate of Louisiana has been engaged in a most remarkable piecs of by-play, the impeachment of a Judge who has not been in office for two years.

The Hon. J.R. Bodwell, the Republican candidate for Governor of Maine, has introduced this paragraph in his platform: "When a man and a woman are doing the same work it is unjust not to pay them equally. My opinion is that the rate of wages should not depend upon whether the laborer is a man or a woman. The rule should be, same work same pay."

Ferdinand Schiverea, the evangelist, having been prevented from preaching in the streets of Brooklyn from dry goods boxes, horse blocks, and other like pulpits, proposes to spread the Gospel about the city under a license, which he will apply for to-day.

TRENTON, N.J., June 27.--After a continuous fight of nearly 40 years in the Court of Chancery, in New-Jersey, the estate of Dr. Zacharias Read, of Mount Holly, has been settled and the money will be divided among the heirs.

ERIE, Penn., June 27.--A gasoline stove exploded to-night in the residence of Mark Sheldon, in Corry. Mrs. Sheldon, who was cooking the supper, was enveloped with the fiery fluid and burned to death after a few hours' excruciating agony. The children were also slightly injured, but not seriously.

Lawton is still on the trail between Vanamique and Senoquipe, Mexico.

WILLSPOINT, Texas, June 27.--A terrible shooting affair occurred here to-day at about noon between John and James McKee and Will Peace on one side and Alexander Board on the other, in which Board was instantly killed, having received nine shots. One shot entered the head above the right eye, one pierced his neck, two entered his side under the arm, and two penetrated the bowels.

BATAVIA, N.Y., June 28.--Samuel Schmid, who came to Batavia from Buffalo 10 years ago, died this morning. Craig. The consideration is said to be $61,000. Mr. Craig will act as managing editor and the force of writers will be increased, but no changes will be made at present.

MERIDEN, Conn., June 30.--The 20-mile road race given by the Meriden Club today was participated in by teams of three men from Hartford, Bristol, East Hartford, and Meriden. H.E. Miller, of Meriden, was second; Harding, of Hartford, third, and Mills, of Bristol, fourth, The team prize was taken by Meriden.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 1--Edward Boyliss fatally shot his wife at their home in Nanticoke early this morning. Jealousy was the cause.

CHICAGO, July 1.--"This is a New-York crowd," said a disgusted friend of the home team as he listened to the yells that greeted every play of the visitors in the early part of the New-York-Chicago baseball game to-day.
SHENANDOAH, Penn., July 1.--A terrible accident, by which one man was killed and two fatally injured, occurred at Turkey Run Colliery here to-day.
CHICAGO, July 1.--The City Directory for 1886 has just been issued. It contains 1,996 pages, being 138 more than last year's volume.
Judge Barrett sat for a while yesterday as an expert on anatomy, without the signal success that habitually attends his work on the bench.

The announcement that State Insurance Superintendent Maxwell had reported the National Benefit Society of New-York City to be wound up, for doing business not allowed by the terms of its charter, was a surprise for that company yesterday morning.

BOSTON, July 1.--The Herald's staff correspondent cables from London as follows: The return without opposition in Liverpool yesterday of three Conservatives--Whitley, Royden, and Baron Henry De Worms--signifies nothing.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., July 1.--This morning the First and Sixteenth Massachusetts Regiments dedicated their monuments on the Emmittsburg road, near the Rogers Building, and they were transferred to the Battlefield Memorial Association.

The colors of Canada and of the United States were intertwined, last night, in the rooms on the lower floor of the Dominion Club, at No. 12 East Twenty-ninth-street, where the anniversary of the confederation of the States of the Dominion was celebrated by a dinner.

CHICAGO, July 1.--As part of the foreclosure suit against the Wabash, St. Louis and Pacific Railway a petition was filed to-day before Judge Gresham, by Henry Lardner, of Niles, Mich., representing that he is the owner of 17 bonds of $1,000 each, on the Chicago Division of the Wabash Road.
ALBANY, July 1.--Gov. Hill was a colse listener this afternoon to the arguments upon the charges of Mayor Grace against Gen. Alexander Shaler, president of the Health Board of New-York.
GAINESVILLE, Texas, July 1.--Ten men were arrested to-day charged by the Coroner's jury with having taken part in the hanging of the negro Ed Williamson on Monday night.

Millionaire Russell Sage is having a good time this Summer. A month ago he accepted the invitation of his friend Millionaire Jay Gould to make a visit to the latter's country place up at Irvington, and now every afternoon he goes sailing up the Hudson after the Stock Exchange is closed.
The Board of Managers of the Seventh Regiment Veterans met yesterday afternoon at Cable's restaurant and discussed their proposed reply to Col. Emmons Clark's bombshell.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 1.--Detectives to-day broke up a gang of counterfeiters in Brighton, a short distance east of the city, that for some time past have been carrying on extensive money counterfeiting operations, principally in American bills.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 1.--The firm of S. Caye, Jr., Co., proprietors of the Kentucky Tobacco Warehouse, made a general assignment for the benefit of its creditors this afternoon.
