ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 1.--Sergt. Bree and Officer Wall last night arrested Harry Richardson, of Anna, Ill., charged with embezzlement, on a telegram from the Marshal of that town. Richardson is only 18 years old.
COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, July 1.--Officer Price, of the Milwaukee Road, was attacked by a gang of 21 tramps in the Milwaukee Railway yards last night.

"Falka" is shortly to be revived at Wallack's by Mr. McCaull. New scenery and dresses are being prepared, and the operetta, which is one of the best of the Vienna lot sung here, is to be given a setting as magnificent as that provided for it during the McCaull administration at the Casino.

BOSTON, July 1.--Wendell Baker, Harvard, '86, holds the best intercollegiate records in the 220 and the 440 yards'. Not long ago, at Beacon Park, he broke the record in the 220, making the distance in 22 seconds.

CHICAGO, July 1.--The weather was again delightful to-day, the track fast, and the attendance at the races very large. The feature of the day was the Oakwood Handicap, in which Spalding broke the record.
MEDINA, N.Y., July 1.--Joseph Eleson, 64 Years old, a thriving raiser of small fruits, living near this place, committed suicide this morning.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 1.--The first meeting of the Twin Cities Driving Club opened at the State Fair Grounds to-day. The chief interest centred in the free-for-all race for a purse of $1,500, for the reason that A. Rohrbach's b.g.

BOSTON, July 1.--The creditors of the Lewiston (Me.) Cotton Mills, at the adjourned meeting yesterday, received the report of the committee of investigation. This was a long document covering in detail the inside history of the company.

CHICAGO, July 1.--Sid Kent is engineering the biggest kind of a corner in wheat, and the foreigners who have been making fortunes on a declining market are going to get "squeezed" if Mr. Kent and his associates can do it.

Pool Commissioner Fink's office will be used to-day for a meeting of the trunk lines' Executive Committee. The object is to take some action on the cutting of passenger rates by the Baltimore and Ohio out of New-York, especially on second class business. The growth of this business has been so great that other trunk lines are feeling its effects.
District Attorney Martine yesterday received from Gov. Hill a letter asking for the facts concerning the trial and conviction of Miguel Chacon, the murderer condemned to be hanged on July 9.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 1.--The jury in the case of Robert Schilling, the Knight of Labor organizer, who was tried on a charge of boycotting the cigar firm of Segnitz Co., disagreed and was discharged this afternoon. The date for a new trial has not yet been fixed.

The employes of the elevated railroads who belong to the Knights of Labor are alarmed over the prospect of being discharged from the employ of the company if they do not sever their connection with the order.

RENOMINATED TO CONGRESS. BURLINGTON, Vt., July 1.--The Republicans of the First Congressional District to-day renominated Congressman John W. Stewart, of Middlebury. The nomination was unanimous. The resolutions indorse the State platform and commend to the support of Republicans the present Representatives in Congress from this State.

Mrs. Landgraf was disappointed yesterday at the result of her visit to court, but hopes that more will be accomplished to-day, when she will be accompanied by several new witnesses. Johann Renz, the witness who was not present yesterday, she also hopes will make his appearance.

BUFFALO, July 1.--There is an organization in this city known as the Citizens' Reform Association, whose object is to obtain a strict enforcement of the laws, particularly those relating to excise matters.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 1.--Quite a serious accident occurred at the new Grand Theatre at noon to-day. A heavy crosspiece which had supported the roof became loosened and fell, striking several workmen who were clearing out debris just below.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 1.--The residents of the usually peaceful little village of Sugar Grove, which is situated just over the New-York State line in Pennsylvania, are in an incendiary frame of mind.

There is a chance for live young men not afraid of hard work to get Professorships at Oxford. Applications must be made in the handwriting of the applicants, and it would be advisable to write on only one side of the sheet of paper.
LONDON, July 1.--Up to midnight 16 Tory candidates, 9 Unionists, 8 Liberals, and 3 Parnellites had been elected to the new House of Commons in uncontested districts.

ASHLAND, Penn., July 1.--The Reading Company's North Ashland colliery resumed operations to-day after a suspension of 15 months, caused by a fire in the mines necessitating the flooding of its workings.

LONDON, July 1.--At Newcastle to-day the North Derby, for 3-year olds, was won by C. Perkins's b.c. Hawkeye. Lord Hastings's b.c. Seaton was second, and Sir R. Jardine's c. f. Day Dream third. There were five starters.

LYNN, Mass., July 1.--Last evening, in the presence of a large crowd of wheelmen, W. A. Rowe covered four miles in 11:10, and five miles in 13:34 4-5, beating the records. George M. Hendee made one mile in 2:30, which is the most marvelous performance on record.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., July 1.--The St. Louis express on the Erie Railroad, drawn by two locomotives, when a mile east of Susquehanna, at 5:30 o'clock this morning, was derailed by a misplaced switch, while running at the rate of 25 miles an hour.
INDEPENDENCE, Cal., July 1.--Nearly the entire city was destroyed by fire yesterday. The loss is estimated at $200,000; insurance, $40,000.

A young man wagered on Saturday night in a Derby-square barroom that he could drink seven "schooner" glasses of beer in succession. The wager was $10. The man succumbed on the fifth, and couldn't raise the sixth to his lips.

RUSSELLVILLE, Ark., July 1.--The boiler of a new saw mill, situated three miles west of Atkins, and belonging to T.R. Adams, exploded to-day, killing T.R. Adams, J. Clark, and Nelson Wilson, and mortally wounding John Wells and James Anderson. Clark's body was blown 150 feet into the air.

The cornerstone of the new synagogue of Congregation Beth Israel (Bikur Cholim) was laid yesterday afternoon. This new house of worship is on the northeast corner of Seventysecond-street and Lexington-avenue. It is of brick, and when completed will cost $125,000.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 1.--With due and fitting ceremonies to-day Yale College installed her twelfth President, Timothy Dwight, grandson of the scholar of the same name who became the executive head of the institution in 1795.

The military pedestrians at Glen Island this week are making creditable records. The only one in the race who shows signs of weakening is Wood, who only walked two miles yesterday.
LONDON, July 1.--Henry Ward Beecher preached a sermon to-day in the City Temple. He was introduced by Dr. Parker, Pastor of the City Temple.

Last evening, at No. 205 West-street, the cane was formally presented to Mr. Gallagher, President of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, who will sail for Europe to-day.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 2.--The breeding farm of C.F. Emery, nine miles south of Cleveland, was visited by fire this afternoon. A large barn valued at $15,000 and a small one worth $3,500 were entirely consumed.

There was weeping and wailing and gnashing of teeth last night in select sporting circles when it was whispered that the great slugging match between John L. Sullivan, the pride of Boston, and Charles Mitchell, the aesthetic English pugilist, was "off."
A double marriage, by which two NewYork families were closely united, took place on Thursday at Trinity Chapel. The two bridegrooms were the brothers of the two brides.
Patrick Brady, a teamster, while driving a truck at Fort Hamilton yesterday morning, fell from the seat and the truck passed over him, inflicting fatal injuries.
NEWBURG, N.Y., July 2.--William Carroll, of Matteawan, in whose building Ferry Napier's hat shop was situated, which was burned last Friday, will probably lose the amount of his insurance--$33,000.

The American Yacht List for 1886, just issued, has many improvements over the previous editions. The list of yachts comprises 1871. It is brought down to the present time, and includes all the new yachts appearing in the present season.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 2.--Telegrams rom Dubois, Penn., say that the starting up of the soft coal mines is not attended with the most fraternal feeling. All the mines are in peaceable operation at that place, so far as can be ascertained, except the Rochester.
The Eighth Regiment, the "Washington Grays," will go to the Camp of Instruction at Peekskill this morning. The start from the armory, on Ninth-avenue, will be made at 10:30.

The Ransom Post, G.A.R., gave a farewell banquet to Gen. Sherman in St. Louis, on Saturday night, June 26, over 200 being present. Gen. Sherman, on rising to respond to the toast in his honor was greeted with tumultuous cheers and for some seconds could not obtain a hearing.
La Bourgogne, the new steamship of the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique, will start to-day on her first trip to Havre from this port well loaded with passengers.

CHICAGO, July 2.--District Assembly No. 24 of the Knights of Labor, after a hot debate to-night, voted to expel all Anarchists from the Assembly and to admit none to membership in the future. The assembly represents over 100 local assemblies, with a total membership of 20,000. It includes among its members Parsons, the Anarchist, now on trial for murder.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 2.--A writ of habeas corpus came before Judge Barnard today. About a week also John Barker, a farm laborer, real estate owner, , entered Mary Doran's saloon, and when ordered out refused to go.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 2.--The Louisville Bridge Company to-day filed suit in the Common Pleas Court against the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad Company for $26,531 62.

CLEVELAND, July 2.--Tthe little town of Chagrin Falls, about 18 miles from here, has been greatly excited over a highly sensational malpractice case, the principal parties to which are leading members of society.

The racing season at Monmouth Park will begin to-day with a programme of seven races, and among them contests for the Hopeful Stakes, for 2-year-olds, the Ocean Stakes, for all ages, and the Long Branch Handicap.

ABILENE, Texas, July 2.--Discouraging reports are received here daily concerning the Texas wool clip this season. The average annual Texas clip is 40,000,000 pounds; this year's clip is short by 15,000,000 pounds.

The Staten Island Amusement Company has decided to open its Casino at St. George for the accommodation of visitors to the island tomorrow. No liquors will be sold, but refreshments will be served as usual. The admission to the Casino will be free.
NEW-ORLEANS, July 2.--Two murders of children occurred to-day. The first was the killing of Josephine Acosta, a young Cuban girl, 14 years of age, by Felix Alvarez, a boy of 13.

The air was cool and pleasant at Weston's military walking match on Glen Island yesterday, and the men walked in good form. The day's work for each man was as follows: O'Connor and Beckley, 35 miles each; Gager, 34 miles; Lawson, 30 miles, and Northridge, 27 miles. Wood did not make his appearance. The total score last evening stood: Gager, 154 miles; Beckley, 152 miles; Lawson, 146 miles; Northridge, 137 miles, and O'Connor, 130 miles.
GETTYSBURG, Penn., July 2.--The reunion of the Third Corps was held this morning in the rink building, and was the feature of the day.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 2.--Company D, of the Twelfth New-York Regiment, will arrive here at 10:30 to-morrow night on the steamer L. Hasbrouck wah 100 soldiers and others in the party.
WAKEFIELD, Mass., July 2.--John Measures, a prominent resident of Stoneham, took a drive with his wife and two children, aged 7 and 10 years, last evening in a covered buggy.
LONGVIEW, Texas, July 2.--County Attorney John F. Teague was shot and killed, this morning, by City Marshal George M. Tabler.
DETROIT, July 2.--When the second reading of the Home Rule bill was defeated in Parliament it was promised that $1,000 would be sent as campaign expenses for each Irish member voting for it.

LONDON, July 3.--The steamship Lamport, (Br.,) Capt. Cross, from Baltimore June 16 for London, passed the Isle of Wight yesterday. The steamship Warwick, (Br.,) Capt. James, from New-York June 21 for Avonmouth, passed Brow Head yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 2.--Attorney Foster did most of the talking in the Anarchists' trial today, and 44 new jurors were questioned by him. The five accepted jurors looked resigned. Major Cole, especially, came prepared to make himself oblivious to his wearisome situation with a paper-covered illustrated novel.
NAUGATUCK, Conn., July 2.--Dr. Austin E. May, a physician who has been engaged in his profession in Naugatuck for several years, sold out his practice to Dr. Hamilton, of Guilford, a few weeks ago.

The centennial volume of the New-York City Directory has just been issued and will be ready for the public on Tuesday. The first edition of what is now the Trow City Directory was issued 100 years ago by David Franks, from No. 66 Broadway.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 2.--Two fishermen, William Buchanan and James Peterson, were drowned in Shelburne Harbor last night by their boat being swamped. A companion, Rufus Holmes, saved himself by floating on an oar until picked up.

WASHINGTON, July 2.--Major-Gen. A.H. Terry and Assistant Surgeon-General Glover Perin have been relieved from duty on the Retiring Board at Fort Snelling, Minn., and Brig.-Gen. Thomas H. Ruger and Assistant Surgeon William L. Kneedler have been detailed in their places.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., July 2.--Everything is in readiness for the race to-morrow between Bowdoin and Pennsylvania, which will he rowed at 11:30 A.M. The afternoon trains brought in many strangers, and the race will probably be witnessed by a large crowd.

A letter just received from the youngest sister of the late Major-Gen. George H. Thomas, by her cousin, Miss Mattie Tyler, the granddaughter of President Tyler, conveys the sad intelligence that the General's oldest sister, Judith, who partly reared him after their mother's death and impressed upon him to no slight extent his great qualities of head and heart, is now lying at the old homestead in Virginia at the point of death.
The Britannia Cricket Club will play a game with the New-York Cricket Club's second eleven at Central Park to-day.
Mrs. Landgraf and her son and daughter sat within the bar at Judge Barrett's court yesterday, near the 16 Bohemians who are indicted for boycotting her.

Li Hau, a despondent Chinaman, about 30 years old, committed suicide yesterday in a peculiarly tragic manner. He had formerly run a laundry on Sixth-avenue, but the establishment did not pay, and he sold it out and went out of business.

TORONTO, July 2.--The Health Officer of Ontario this week made an inspection of the means taken by the Canadian Government to quarantine ocean ships on entering Canadian ports which have infectious diseases among passengers or crew.

Jay Gould is to retire from the Western Union Telegraph Company. He is to be paid $90 a share for his stock. The telegraph and cable wars are to be forthwith settled. The Baltimore and Ohio Company is to be swallowed up by the Western Union. The market price of Western Union stock is going right up above par.

At yesterday's meeting of the Executive Committee of the trunk lines it was agreed to put the east-bound passenger agreement into effect from July 1 instead of the much earlier dates, for which there had been contention.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 2.--Arthur G. Ogilby was taken to the State prison this afternoon to serve a sentence of four years imposed on June 30 by Judge Scudder for embezzling $86,000 from the Dime Savings Bank of New-Brunswick, of which institution he had been Cashier.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 2.--Harvard failed this evening to carry out its carefully arranged programme to race Yale out in the first mile of to-day's university race, and in consequence was badly beaten by Yale, seven boat lengths separating the crews at the finish.

Undoubtedly, the most extraordinary class in point of height that will be graduated from any institution in America this year is that of Nichols Latin School in this city. The total height of the seven members is 42 feet, an average of 6 feet each.
William Ellis, a steerage passenger on the steamship City of Chicago, which arrived here yesterday, developed symptoms of insanity soon after the vessel left Liverpool.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 2.--Before Judge Brown, to-day, in Supreme Court, Chambers, testimony was concluded in the case of Hugh Lowrey and Mary A. Sears, as Executors of the late Rev. John Erskine, of Walden, against the niece of the latter, Sarah Erskine, of St. Louis.

WASHINGTON, July 2.--The President and Mrs. Cleveland, accompanied by PostmasterGeneral Vilas and wife, occupied Manager Rapley's private box at the new National Theatre to-night, and witnessed the McCaull Opera Comique Company in the "Black Hussar."

The American people are giving so much more time to amusements now than formerly that the demand for clothing suitable for their leisure hours is increasing enormously. Knickerbockers are seen everywhere in the country.

Vancouver, Washington Territory, recently destroyed by fire, is being rapidly rebuilt. The majority of the new buildings will be of brick, with stone foundations.

MOREHEAD, Ky., July 2.--The feudal war between the Tolliver and Martin factions that made Rowan County a most unpleasant place of residence for peaceable and law-abiding citizens two years and less ago, bids fair to break out afresh and more violently than ever.

MUNICH, July 2.--The Cabinet, of which Dr. Baron J. von Lutz is President, has resigned. BERLIN, July 2.--Emperor William has granted $7,500 to the town of Crossen, Prussia, to aid the people in recovering from the heavy losses inflicted upon them by the recent storms.
The Third Methodist Church, on Washington-street, Brooklyn, was mortgaged yesterday for $15,000, to pay off an old debt.

Dove, N.J., July 2.--Ten men were whirled into eternity this morning by the explosion of more than a ton of nitro-glycerine on the outskirts of the little village of McCainsville, distant from this place about five miles.

Mr. Louis Cronenberg was badly bitten yesterday by his mammoth turtle. The "varmint" took a hold on Mr. Cronenberg's slippered foot, and in endeavoring to force the turtle's mouth open to release his foot, Mr. Cronenberg had a finger bitten to the bone. Fortunately it was thundering at the time, and the turtle let go his hold without further trouble.

Carl Reuter, a German, age 25 years, was arrested at Mount Vernon yesterday for committing an assault on the 5-year-old daughter of Niels Hansen. He was sent without bail to White Plains Jail by Justice Edmonds.

A lady living in Pratt-street, Fulton, was recently frightened into hysteries by seeing her own shadow and thinking it was a burglar. She has been contined to her bed for several days from the fright.
